On Wed, 29 Dec 2004 10:26:04 +0530, Suresh Ramasubramanian
<linux@frodo.hserus.net> wrote:
> 
> Narayanamoorthy Srinivasan <narayanamoorthys@gmail.com> wrote:
> >  Is there any way to use SMTP AUTH first and RBL next.
> 
> 1. Patch qmail
> 
> or
> 
> 2. Run a separate instance of qmail on port 587, and dont run rblsmtpd
> on it - limit access to this qmail instance only to smtp auth'd users,
> and to IPs that are in your dialup pool / LAN etc (IPs that you normally
> relay for)
> 
>     srs
> 
>
From trshash84 at gmail.com  Sat Jan  1 08:37:32 2005
From: trshash84 at gmail.com (T.R.Shashwath)
Date: Sat Jan  1 20:32:09 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Do I need GRUB or LILO
In-Reply-To: <94bbbbe204123023165a4e6731@mail.gmail.com>
References: <94bbbbe204123023165a4e6731@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <200501010837.32328.trshash84@gmail.com>

It might be possible to do it without a bootloader, but it's always better to 
have one. That way, you have one more fallback in case of crisis, especially 
with grub.

There is also the possibility of having two or more kernels, or two or more 
configurations for the system. Best to have a boot loader then.

On Friday 31 Dec 2004 7:16 am, Arjun Baskaran wrote:
> I have only linux in my box and is lilo or grub a neccesary one ?
> I know to set timeout to 0 in case of grub and so incase of lilo but
> when i  switch on the PC i would like to see the linux kernel
> immediately loading........
> Can i do that?
> Please Reply

From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Sat Jan  1 12:01:21 2005
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi S)
Date: Sat Jan  1 23:18:55 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] One Day One Command
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0412311305040.4360-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

One Day One Command :-
-------------------

man - Format and display the 'man'ual pages.

Summary : 

Most of the Linux commands are comes with a specially formatted
manuals, which explains "how to use the command and list options
etc..". 'man' is used to view the manual page. This command has 
no .of useful options like -f, -k, -K, ...

Read    : man man

Bye :)
-- 
Bharathi S

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Sat Jan  1 08:50:32 2005
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Sat Jan  1 23:20:52 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Xserver
In-Reply-To: <20041231075228.26830.qmail@web50610.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20050101165032.30192.qmail@web50206.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

--- radha krishnan <itradha_mit@yahoo.com> wrote:
> could u guide me how to configure the Xserver

You should know your display's horizontal
synchronization rate (HSYNC), vertical refresh rate
(VFSH) and video memory size. 

If you are using XFree86 use either "xf86config"
(script) or "xf86cfg" (graphical) to reconfigure your
X server setting.

If you are using Xorg use either "xorgconfig" (script)
or "xorgcfg" (graphical) to reconfigure your X server
setting.

K Shakthi

From trshash84 at gmail.com  Sat Jan  1 23:12:26 2005
From: trshash84 at gmail.com (T.R.Shashwath)
Date: Sat Jan  1 23:21:27 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Xserver
In-Reply-To: <20041231075228.26830.qmail@web50610.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20041231075228.26830.qmail@web50610.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <200501012312.26578.trshash84@gmail.com>

Get to the console (Ctrl+Alt+F1), login as root, and run:

X -configure

This will drop an XF86Config (or xorg.conf if FC2 uses xorg) in /root. Copy 
this file (or move it if you prefer) to /etc/X11

If this doesn't work, manually configure using either xf86config (text mode) 
or xf86cfg (gui). XOrg's equivalents are xorgconfig and xorgcfg.

That should be all that's necessary, unless you want some extra things - then 
you've got to edit the file.

Hi All,

I am using Mandrake 10.1 distro. Recently i purchased
a linksys wireless network card and managed to get it
configured with the help of driverloader. 

I am able to list the accesspoints with iwlist and
have set all the necessary parameters for wirless with
iwconfig.  After this when i try to bring the wireless
interface with ifup, it fails to get an ip address. 

The message i get in /var/log/messages point to
failure in dhclient. Could some one help me why i am
unable to get a ip address with dhclient.  

Thanks for ur help.

regards,
kannan.

From tuxkumar at yahoo.com  Sun Jan  2 09:05:50 2005
From: tuxkumar at yahoo.com (Saravana Kumar)
Date: Sun Jan  2 09:03:48 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] [COMMERCIAL] Linux System Administrator required
Message-ID: <cr7q1c$ka0$1@sea.gmane.org>

Hi list,

We at Cobra Analytic Solutions are looking for System Administrator. Cobra
Analytic is a BPO with its parent based in California.

Desired Profile: Atleast 2 years of experience in Linux with good exposure
to the following

named, squid, apache, nfs, nis, samba, iptables

The candidate must be able to take care of a network with Linux and Windows
environment. He must have experience in working with LUGs. With a thirst to
explore new things he should be able to suggest ideas and come up with
proposals for implementing things in system and network.

Joining Time: Immediate or in a week's time.

Salary: No bar for the right candidate.

please send your resumes to careersindia@global-analytics.com

SK

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Sun Jan  2 10:54:55 2005
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Sun Jan  2 10:55:07 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Help on wireless configuration ...
In-Reply-To: <20050102012805.69256.qmail@web52005.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20050102012805.69256.qmail@web52005.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <41d785a7.QQqT4QVxbA+qK9D4%linux@frodo.hserus.net>

kannan krishnan <kannank_udt@yahoo.com> wrote:

> My wireless device gets listed as eth2. Here is
> iwconfig output.
>
> eth2      IEEE 802.11-DS  ESSID:"sri-linksys" 
> Nickname:"sakthiman.myco.com"
>           Mode:Managed  Frequency:2.462GHz  Access

Configure an entry for eth2 in /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/

Check if there's a file ifcfg-eth2 there, if not create one (look at ifcfg-eth0
in the same directory for a hint)

	srs

Message-ID: <20050102080706.GA5858@cs.utexas.edu>

On Sun, Jan 02, 2005 at 01:08:15PM +0530, Sridhar R wrote:
> 
> I mean delete .bash_history when closing the session (shell), so that
> you do not miss the history feature and also gain some privacy.
> 

I guess, doing an
$ rm -f ~/.bash_history

and then logging out is not going to work, because the file is going to get
created again when the shell exists.

By the way, if the system administrator wants to know what a user is doing,
(s)he just has to add a few lines of code to the kernel and log the execve
system call.

Suriya

Joe Steeve wrote: 
,----
| I  dont think you'd  have to  download NVIDIA's  drivers., if  you are
| using `sarge`., it should support NVIDIA.
`----

Sarge does not come with  the non-free nvidia driver. The sarge driver
is the  native XF86  nvidia driver that  does not support  a gazillion
other features that are supported by the non-free driver from NVIDIA.

cheers,

  -Suraj

,-----------------[http://www.symonds.net/~suraj/]---o

From andyetitmoves at gmail.com  Sun Jan  2 15:36:24 2005
From: andyetitmoves at gmail.com (Ramkumar R)
Date: Sun Jan  2 15:36:37 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Do I need GRUB or LILO
In-Reply-To: <200501010837.32328.trshash84@gmail.com>
References: <94bbbbe204123023165a4e6731@mail.gmail.com>
	<200501010837.32328.trshash84@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <9a9bfc17050102020690549ce@mail.gmail.com>

it used to be possible but afaik, linux removed the standalone boot
support in recent kernels - anyway it doesn't hurt keeping a boot
loader...even as far as the timeout 0 is concerned, ensure that your
boot command is correct before doing that - or atleast get a rescue
disk - any error would otherwise make your system unbootable. Even
then, keeping a timeout of say 2 seconds is better - enables you to
change your command line in case you need it - say you want a runlevel
of 3 - well, you won't be able to do much in 2 seconds anyway :)

it moves on...

On Sat, 1 Jan 2005 08:37:32 +0000, T.R.Shashwath <trshash84@gmail.com> wrote:
> It might be possible to do it without a bootloader, but it's always better to
> have one. That way, you have one more fallback in case of crisis, especially
> with grub.
> 
> There is also the possibility of having two or more kernels, or two or more
> configurations for the system. Best to have a boot loader then.
> 
> On Friday 31 Dec 2004 7:16 am, Arjun Baskaran wrote:
> > I have only linux in my box and is lilo or grub a neccesary one ?
> > I know to set timeout to 0 in case of grub and so incase of lilo but
> > when i  switch on the PC i would like to see the linux kernel
> > immediately loading........
> > Can i do that?
> > Please Reply
>

Many of the configuring tools have very limited capabilities...editing
by hand is the best solution...man xorg.conf (or XF86Config) is
excellently maintained..I had a similar problem, and the culprit was
the hsync and vsync ranges of my monitor - I had to pull up my monitor
manual and key in the values.

it moves on...

Yes  I too had edited /etc/X11/XF86config.In the monitor section I deleted hsync and vsync line.When I executed startx it  probed the monitor (xfs it-self updated into CF86config) and I could get into GUI , but I am scared to suggest this, it had worked for me many times.

Hi,

Enabling the Legacy mode in BIOS Disk Mgmt. helped me install Fedora. You
may try booting in Legacy mode with 1 SATA & 1 Parallel IDE.

Best Regards,
Mahesh.

From kmshiva at gmail.com  Mon Jan  3 10:18:45 2005
From: kmshiva at gmail.com (Shiva KM)
Date: Mon Jan  3 10:18:54 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Nvidia problems in debian
In-Reply-To: <557E17BE74D22143B7BE70EB60E33E9914D30CBC@shlmsg01.ad.infosys.com>
References: <557E17BE74D22143B7BE70EB60E33E9914D30CBC@shlmsg01.ad.infosys.com>
Message-ID: <654433ee0501022048781fbf50@mail.gmail.com>

Hi,

> I seem to be having much better performance with the native "nv" driver
> than the "nvidia" driver.

What do u mean by 'better performance' ? As far as 2d is concerned I
haven't found much of a difference between the two drivers - apart
from the fact that the non-free driver has one or two strange and
irritating bugs - such as - the screen flickering and tearing when I
use 'gmplayer' to play movies - the commandline version, i.e. mplayer
works just fine.

> I don't use OpenGL much in any of my apps so I stick with the "nv"
> driver for most of the time.

As far as 3d is concerned, the non-free driver is pretty damn good - I
get better performance  in linux compared to the windows as well -
almost 5 to 10 fps difference in quake3.


-- 
Thanks and Regards,
shiva
--
Avoid the Gates of Hell.  Use Linux
From Toufeeq_Hussain at infosys.com  Mon Jan  3 10:59:52 2005
From: Toufeeq_Hussain at infosys.com (Toufeeq Hussain)
Date: Mon Jan  3 11:02:59 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Nvidia problems in debian
Message-ID: <557E17BE74D22143B7BE70EB60E33E9914D31052@shlmsg01.ad.infosys.com>


Hi,

> I seem to be having much better performance with the native "nv" 
> driver than the "nvidia" driver.

>What do u mean by 'better performance' ? As far as 2d is concerned I
haven't found much of a difference between the two
>drivers - apart from the fact that the non-free driver has one or two
strange and irritating bugs - such as - the screen >flickering and
tearing when I use 'gmplayer' to play movies - the commandline version,
i.e. mplayer works just fine.

The "interactivity" seems to be much better when I use the "nv" driver.
With the non-free driver the pointer seems to skip a lot.
Switching between workspaces is much faster too.

> I don't use OpenGL much in any of my apps so I stick with the "nv"
> driver for most of the time.

>As far as 3d is concerned, the non-free driver is pretty damn good - I
get better performance  in linux compared to the 
>windows as well - almost 5 to 10 fps difference in quake3.

Yes, 3D is much better with the non-free nvidia binary.

Regards,
Toufeeq Hussain

From lug at chandrashekar.info  Mon Jan  3 12:42:18 2005
From: lug at chandrashekar.info (Chandrashekar Babu)
Date: Mon Jan  3 12:40:31 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Nvidia problems in debian
In-Reply-To: <557E17BE74D22143B7BE70EB60E33E9914D30CBC@shlmsg01.ad.infosys.com>
References: <557E17BE74D22143B7BE70EB60E33E9914D30CBC@shlmsg01.ad.infosys.com>
Message-ID: <20050103124218.2b81ef51.lug@chandrashekar.info>

On Mon, 3 Jan 2005 09:07:11 +0530
"Toufeeq Hussain" <Toufeeq_Hussain@infosys.com> wrote:

> I seem to be having much better performance with the native "nv"
> driver than the "nvidia" driver.

On my machine, I've found both the "nv" and "nvidia" driver perform
equally well for most 2D apps (atleast I could not differentiate their
performance/stability). However, "nvidia" driver performs best
for 3D apps (high-end games and other OpenGL applications). Infact,
UT2004 runs stable and fast on Linux when compared to Windows
2000 (with nvidia detonator drivers installed on my machine earlier). 

> Also, has anyone managed to get the nvidia drivers running with 2.6.10
> ? The driver install fails with "Cannot determine the kernel version"

I've got it working on Slackware (2.6.10-cko patched kernel) with
1.0-6629 version of nvidia driver.

Chandrashekar Babu
http://www.chandrashekar.info/

From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Mon Jan  3 13:17:58 2005
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi S)
Date: Mon Jan  3 13:19:34 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] One Day One Command
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501031310370.8507-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

One Day One Command :-
---------------------

apropos - search the whatis database for strings

Summary: 

This command will search the given string the Whatis DB and list the
matchs on the screen. For example, the following command will list the
available (in the whatis DB) compilers: apropos compiler

Read: man apropos, whatis

Bye :)
-- 
Bharathi S

Hi,
> -----Original Message-----
> From: ilugc-bounces@ae.iitm.ac.in

> On Mon, 3 Jan 2005 09:07:11 +0530
> "Toufeeq Hussain" <Toufeeq_Hussain@infosys.com> wrote:
> 
> > I seem to be having much better performance with the native "nv"
> > driver than the "nvidia" driver.
> 
> On my machine, I've found both the "nv" and "nvidia" driver 
> perform equally well for most 2D apps (atleast I could not 
> differentiate their performance/stability). However, "nvidia" 
> driver performs best for 3D apps (high-end games and other 
> OpenGL applications). Infact,
> UT2004 runs stable and fast on Linux when compared to Windows 
> 2000 (with nvidia detonator drivers installed on my machine earlier). 

My issues are purely 2D and under heavy load.
Heavy load for my desktop is 
*Firefox (5+ tabs)
*X-Chat (5+ tabs)
*Thunderbird
*GNOME 2.8
*GAIM
*gnome-terminal (3+ tabs)
	-- tab1 runs apt-get
	-- tab2 runs kernel/software compilation
	-- bash
*XMMS
*OOImpress + gedit

The box is a Pentium 4 3.0Ghz /w 512M
Graphics Card is a GeForce FX 5900 XT /w 128M

Try running the following apps, first with "nvidia" and then with "nv"

With "nv" the interactivity is fluent where as with "nvidia" my mouse
skips a few events.
Workspace switching is slow.

Probably because this is a kernel issue.
I'm running 2.6.10 /w ckdev patchset + inotify.

Also the best test would be to cat a huge file to /dev/null or /dev/zero
And then generate random X Events and check the interactivity.

> > Also, has anyone managed to get the nvidia drivers running 
> with 2.6.10 
> > ? The driver install fails with "Cannot determine the 
> kernel version"
> 
> I've got it working on Slackware (2.6.10-cko patched kernel) with
> 1.0-6629 version of nvidia driver.
> 

Ah, a -ck patchset user :)

Also, I run the same driver version on Sarge.
I've tried the following methods but still no success

* A plain run of the installer
* installer with the -ae switch
* extract the package and running a "make-install"

The driver installs fine on my stock Sarge Kernel.

Regards,
Toufeeq Hussain

From lug at chandrashekar.info  Mon Jan  3 15:01:18 2005
From: lug at chandrashekar.info (Chandrashekar Babu)
Date: Mon Jan  3 14:59:35 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Nvidia problems in debian
In-Reply-To: <557E17BE74D22143B7BE70EB60E33E9914D3145F@shlmsg01.ad.infosys.com>
References: <557E17BE74D22143B7BE70EB60E33E9914D3145F@shlmsg01.ad.infosys.com>
Message-ID: <20050103150118.4bc45fb2.lug@chandrashekar.info>


> My issues are purely 2D and under heavy load.
> Heavy load for my desktop is 
> *Firefox (5+ tabs)
> *X-Chat (5+ tabs)
> *Thunderbird
> *GNOME 2.8
> *GAIM
> *gnome-terminal (3+ tabs)
> 	-- tab1 runs apt-get
> 	-- tab2 runs kernel/software compilation
> 	-- bash
> *XMMS
> *OOImpress + gedit

I guess the issue is mostly related to gtk2 widget library. I find the
combination awfully slow on both "nv" and "nvidia" driver as well. I'm
on an AMD AthlonXP 1800+, 256MB RAM, GeForce2/MX with 64 MB RAM machine.
Even on my other box (an old Pentium 233 MMX, 64 MB RAM, Riva TNT2 with
32 MB RAM box), I dont see any much difference between the two drivers
(yes, I managed to run Gnome 2.8 for the heck of it!). 

Though Gnome is somewhat slow in starting applications, popping menus
and so on, the interactivity seems normal on both drivers on my
machines. 

Do you find the same performance difference using apps that run on
Qt/fltk/motif/imlib ?

> Try running the following apps, first with "nvidia" and then with "nv"
>
> With "nv" the interactivity is fluent where as with "nvidia" my mouse
> skips a few events.

Perhaps this has something to do with "HWCursor" option (under video
drivers section) in your xorg.conf ? Or maybe I'd blame it on driver
support for your specific hardware. 

X cursor looks beautiful with "nvidia" driver on my box, as I use
HWCursor and CursorShadow enabled. 

> Workspace switching is slow.

On Gnome, yes... I find it slow on both "nv" and "nvidia" drivers. 


> Probably because this is a kernel issue.
> I'm running 2.6.10 /w ckdev patchset + inotify.

On my kernel, I had to do --extract-only and then do a "make install"
from the sources.


> Also the best test would be to cat a huge file to /dev/null or
> /dev/zero And then generate random X Events and check the
> interactivity.

Tried this too (cat /dev/urandom > /dev/null). Highly responsive on my
lean setup, and on KDE, but on Gnome, there were glitches with both "nv"
and "nvidia" drivers. Screen freeze/jerky behaviour when I try moving a
firefox window randomly across the screen. 

However, my system might be too slow/outdated for Gnome to really test
the performance difference between the 2 drivers. 

--
Chandrashekar Babu
http://www.chandrashekar.info/

From lug at chandrashekar.info  Mon Jan  3 15:01:18 2005
From: lug at chandrashekar.info (Chandrashekar Babu)
Date: Mon Jan  3 14:59:36 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Nvidia problems in debian
In-Reply-To: <557E17BE74D22143B7BE70EB60E33E9914D3145F@shlmsg01.ad.infosys.com>
References: <557E17BE74D22143B7BE70EB60E33E9914D3145F@shlmsg01.ad.infosys.com>
Message-ID: <20050103150118.4bc45fb2.lug@chandrashekar.info>


> My issues are purely 2D and under heavy load.
> Heavy load for my desktop is 
> *Firefox (5+ tabs)
> *X-Chat (5+ tabs)
> *Thunderbird
> *GNOME 2.8
> *GAIM
> *gnome-terminal (3+ tabs)
> 	-- tab1 runs apt-get
> 	-- tab2 runs kernel/software compilation
> 	-- bash
> *XMMS
> *OOImpress + gedit

I guess the issue is mostly related to gtk2 widget library. I find the
combination awfully slow on both "nv" and "nvidia" driver as well. I'm
on an AMD AthlonXP 1800+, 256MB RAM, GeForce2/MX with 64 MB RAM machine.
Even on my other box (an old Pentium 233 MMX, 64 MB RAM, Riva TNT2 with
32 MB RAM box), I dont see any much difference between the two drivers
(yes, I managed to run Gnome 2.8 for the heck of it!). 

Though Gnome is somewhat slow in starting applications, popping menus
and so on, the interactivity seems normal on both drivers on my
machines. 

Do you find the same performance difference using apps that run on
Qt/fltk/motif/imlib ?

> Try running the following apps, first with "nvidia" and then with "nv"
>
> With "nv" the interactivity is fluent where as with "nvidia" my mouse
> skips a few events.

Perhaps this has something to do with "HWCursor" option (under video
drivers section) in your xorg.conf ? Or maybe I'd blame it on driver
support for your specific hardware. 

X cursor looks beautiful with "nvidia" driver on my box, as I use
HWCursor and CursorShadow enabled. 

> Workspace switching is slow.

On Gnome, yes... I find it slow on both "nv" and "nvidia" drivers. 


> Probably because this is a kernel issue.
> I'm running 2.6.10 /w ckdev patchset + inotify.

On my kernel, I had to do --extract-only and then do a "make install"
from the sources.


> Also the best test would be to cat a huge file to /dev/null or
> /dev/zero And then generate random X Events and check the
> interactivity.

Tried this too (cat /dev/urandom > /dev/null). Highly responsive on my
lean setup, and on KDE, but on Gnome, there were glitches with both "nv"
and "nvidia" drivers. Screen freeze/jerky behaviour when I try moving a
firefox window randomly across the screen. 

However, my system might be too slow/outdated for Gnome to really test
the performance difference between the 2 drivers. 

--
Chandrashekar Babu
http://www.chandrashekar.info/

From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Tue Jan  4 14:41:25 2005
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi S)
Date: Tue Jan  4 14:42:42 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] One Day One Command
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501041414480.7014-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

One Day One Command :-
---------------------

info - Read documentation in Info format.

Summary: 

Apart from Man pages, some commands comes with a detail manual pages,
called info pages, which is in info format. This info command provides
Menu, Search, Corss-Ref and many other facilities.

Examples:

$ info  -- List all info pages available in the system.

$ pinfo -- Curses based lynx-style info browser.

$ info  emacs -- Show Emacs info page. (See man emacs, to feel the 
                 difference)

Read: info info, info pinfo

Bye :)
-- 
Bharathi S

From vam_rox at gmx.net  Tue Jan  4 15:09:08 2005
From: vam_rox at gmx.net (Vamsee Kanakala)
Date: Tue Jan  4 15:07:54 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Mozilla Thunderbird Backup
In-Reply-To: <e70ef6930501032243306a1489@mail.gmail.com>
References: <e70ef6930501032243306a1489@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <41DA643C.4020904@gmx.net>

Srinivasan R wrote:

>how do I import the
>old mails along with the current mails. Is it possible??
>  
>
Yes. Very much so. But, you have to create the same accounts that you 
created in your previous installation and click on Tools -> Import and 
select the type of back-up and click ok. Even if you can't see all your 
mails right now, once you create the mail accounts, your mails will be 
visible.

Check this out:
http://texturizer.net/thunderbird/faq.html

-VK

On Tue, 4 Jan 2005 11:17:40 +0000 (GMT), arumugam karthik
<arumugamkarti@yahoo.co.in> wrote:
> how can i install windows through linux?

Wow. That's a new one. Windows through Linux. Maybe you mean, Windows on Linux.

> if i do means it won't affect my MBR(master boot record) operations?

It sure will. It will conk off your Linux Boot loader right out of the
MBR and pop in ntldr up there i think. Microsick Windoze. It's really
sick. Does not detect the presence of any other Non-MS OS on your
system and takes up your MBR without letting you know. That's what the
world's most popular proprietary OS does.

Better option would be to install Linux on Windows or put your way.
Linux through Windows.

--
Impossible is not a fact. It's an opinion. Impossible is nothing.

Ankit Malhotra
(The BATFAN)
Blog: http://XFM.BlogSpot.com
Registered Linux User # 349208 (http://Counter.Li.org)
Final Year, B. Tech. CSE, (http://www.VIT.ac.in)

> MBR and pop in ntldr up there i think. Microsick Windoze. It's really

Subject: [Ilugc] Swatantra- Symposium on FOSS- RMS in Vellore!!
Message-ID: <137340-220051241254595@M2W065.mail2web.com>

Played around with gzip, gcc.
Wana meet the person who created these software gizmos?

This is event is for you then. Vellore Institute of Technology is organsing
a symposium on Free 

and Open SOurce software technologies titled Swatantra(6th - 7th Feb, 05). 

Founder of GNu and the man responsible for coining the term Free SOftware,
Richard M Stallman 

will be there to deliver the keynote address of the symposium and to answer
all the questions 

that you have always wanted to ask about these amazingly simply yet
inherently complex programs.

The event will also feature various competitions to kindle your nack for
Linux tweaking and 

tuning such as:- 

LINSTALL-- The Linux installation challenge.
Anaconda !! YaSt !! familiar with all these name?  Have been installing on
your system for a long 

time and you find it fun?? making the X server run?? configuring the boot
loader?? ..YES??..One 

event where apply all your skills which you developed over the years by
trying to install 

GNU/Linux on your system.

WEBMINISTER-- The Apache web server Challenge
Love Apache because of the customizability it offers while deploying your
website? Love fiddling 

with httpd.conf and think you are best at it? This is one event to prove
yourself! Come and 

demonstrate that your are the best at the best webserver that there is and
ever was.....

CORE WARS-- Challenge the memory
This event will feature an old game called core wars which involves
destroying your opponents 

programs by overwriting the memory in which this program is stored. It will
kindle the nerves of 

memory geeks with pointers and direct memory references expertise being the
norm.

Watch out for cool demonstartions on MONO, Linux Cluster, Linux from
scratch and much more....

For further details log on to: http://www.swatantra.info
or mail us at: contact@swatantra.info

From zulfilee at midascomm.com  Wed Jan  5 11:12:51 2005
From: zulfilee at midascomm.com (zulfilee)
Date: Wed Jan  5 10:55:07 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] help: vi editor - to insert new line
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0501042219370.16974@chi.spunge.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0501042219370.16974@chi.spunge.org>
Message-ID: <200501051112.51510.zulfilee@midascomm.com>

Hi,
Just go to command mode
Type
:map k o^[j

The ^[ is ctrl+v ctrl+[ combination

Now keep pressing k and the new lines get added.

Also if you want one keystroke use this
:map k o^[jk
Now press k once 

Cheers
Z

From gopu.bhaskar at wipro.com  Wed Jan  5 11:06:14 2005
From: gopu.bhaskar at wipro.com (gopu.bhaskar@wipro.com)
Date: Wed Jan  5 11:50:35 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: help: vi editor - to insert new line
Message-ID: <9FF1E2261921B84C942BD10365DBFC9C021EB68C@chn-gdy-msg.wipro.com>



> To be more clearer,
> How to insert "tab"(\t as in c programming) and
> "newline"(\n as in c programming) through  the
> substitution command(1,$s/oldtext/newtext/g).

:%s/$/\r To insert new line at the end of each line in the file.
Similarly you can use \t for tabs.


Confidentiality Notice

The information contained in this electronic message and any attachments to this message are intended
for the exclusive use of the addressee(s) and may contain confidential or privileged information. If
you are not the intended recipient, please notify the sender at Wipro or Mailadmin@wipro.com immediately
and destroy all copies of this message and any attachments.
From anandhg02 at yahoo.com  Tue Jan  4 22:36:22 2005
From: anandhg02 at yahoo.com (Anandh G)
Date: Wed Jan  5 12:06:33 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Remote Desktop Connection in Fedora ??? - Solved
In-Reply-To: <557E17BE74D22143B7BE70EB60E33E9914E6DB54@shlmsg01.ad.infosys.com>
Message-ID: <20050105063622.24134.qmail@web41701.mail.yahoo.com>

The VNC server is now working. The only change I made
in the ~/.vnc/xstartup is
# Uncomment the following two lines for normal
desktop:
 unset SESSION_MANAGER
 exec /etc/X11/xinit/xinitrc

I am now able to access my GNOME desktop from my
windows. I am using Real VNC server in Fedora and VNC
4.0 viewer in windows. It is able to connect only if I
specify the IP with port 3.  192.168.100.1:5901. Is
this can be corrected.

One info to share with you, the remote desktop is very
very clear and also fast than the remote desktop
connecton between Win XP to Win XP. (Note: In both
case I had set the resolution the highest available
for remote machine).

Thanks for guidence.


=====
Regards,
AnandhG

From deepak.sarda at gmail.com  Wed Jan  5 16:45:40 2005

Date: Wed Jan  5 14:15:51 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Annotating email messages
Message-ID: <eaac783a050105004567815d8f@mail.gmail.com>

Hello everyone,

Of late, I've often felt the need to annotate some of the emails I
get. Like attaching a quick virtual post-it to the email with some
context info or my thoughts.

Is there any way I can do this? I am okay with storing annotations
meta data on the client side only but if there's some way to make it
work server side - meaning storing meta data with the original email
on the mail server - that would be killer.

If there are no current solutions, any thoughts on how one might
implement such functionality? If we were to implement a server side
solution, are there any unused fields in the email message format that
can be exploited?

Regds,

Deepak.

On Wed, 05 Jan 2005 14:09:12 +0530, Mohammed Riyaz
<p_mdriyaz@fastmail.fm> wrote:
> 
> Has anybody here configured cups to print to a windows printer??
> if yes, could you brief me on how to do this?

Almost all distributions come with tools to configure printers (and
cups). Which distro are you running?

Also, what kind of printer is it? I don't know what a windows printer
is... if it's a network printer, then CUPS works marvelously. If it's
a printer attached to a windows PC and then shared.. then things might
get slightly difficult.

deepak

> a printer attached to a windows PC and then shared.. then things might
> get slightly difficult.

It is a printer connected to the windows machine, it is not a network
printer.
I mainly dont know what i should do with samba to get the printer
visible the the linux machine.

-Riyaz

Subject: [Ilugc] Annotating email messages

References: <eaac783a050105004567815d8f@mail.gmail.com>

Deepak Sarda wrote:
> Of late, I've often felt the need to annotate some of the emails I
> get. Like attaching a quick virtual post-it to the email with some
> context info or my thoughts.

you can add x-headers to the email

x-thoughts: whatever

then have mutt display that header, or have procmail tag based on it 
(you can add the header using procmail as well)

From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Wed Jan  5 19:34:58 2005
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi S)
Date: Wed Jan  5 19:35:33 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] One Day One Command
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501051920350.28923-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

One Day One Command :-
---------------------

ac -  Print statistics about users' connect time

Summary: 

"ac" command will print the users' connect time details in 
different formats (Total, Per day, Per user, etc..)

Example:

$ ac     -- print total useage.
$ ac -p  -- print indv user info
$ ac -dy -- print daily based report.

Read: man ac

Bye :)
-- 
Bharathi S

From madhukar_linux at yahoo.co.in  Thu Jan  6 05:50:41 2005
From: madhukar_linux at yahoo.co.in (Madhukar mythri)
Date: Thu Jan  6 11:20:53 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] What is multi-functional device ??
Message-ID: <20050106055041.7473.qmail@web8409.mail.in.yahoo.com>

Hi all,
       when we type "lspci"...
it shows all pci devices with slot name...
 bus(8-bits): device(5-bits) : function(3-bits)

to identify a PCI device....

here function mean...it will tell..whether the device
is single functional... or multi-functional....

So,
what is multi-functional device??

Rgds
Madhukar

Yahoo! India Matrimony: Find your life partner online
Go to: http://yahoo.shaadi.com/india-matrimony
From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Wed Jan  5 23:58:19 2005
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Thu Jan  6 13:28:27 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] What is multi-functional device ??
In-Reply-To: <20050106055041.7473.qmail@web8409.mail.in.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20050106075819.41688.qmail@web50203.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

--- Madhukar mythri <madhukar_linux@yahoo.co.in>
wrote:
> Hi all,
>        when we type "lspci"...
> it shows all pci devices with slot name...
>  bus(8-bits): device(5-bits) : function(3-bits)
> So,
> what is multi-functional device??

A device that has many end-point resources. 

For example, it can be a PCI card with two serial
ports and a parallel port. 

K Shakthi

K Shakthi

From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Thu Jan  6 20:26:59 2005
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi S)
Date: Thu Jan  6 20:29:56 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] One Day One Command
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501051920350.28923-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501062007480.6619-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

One Day One Command :-
---------------------

alias - Create alias name for a command.

Summary: 

alias is Bash build-in command. This is very useful to create a simple
alias for a complex/long/frequent commands. Once alias created, you
can use alias to call the original command. This alias are deleted
after closing the shell session. For the next session, you have create
it again. So avoid this problem, you add it in your .bashrc file.

Example:

alias  -- Prints all alias commands

alias ls="ls -F --color=always" 
alias cls=clear 

alias ls -- Print the alias' original command

Read: man bash

Bye :)
-- 
Bharathi S

From p_mdriyaz at fastmail.fm  Thu Jan  6 20:55:32 2005
From: p_mdriyaz at fastmail.fm (Mohammed Riyaz)
Date: Thu Jan  6 20:55:42 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] printer config for FC-2
In-Reply-To: <a2de783d050106004222ed1c78@mail.gmail.com>
References: <a2de783d050106004222ed1c78@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <1105025132.28606.212140646@webmail.messagingengine.com>

Hi,

What your printer can and cannot do is defined in .ppd files, if you can
get the .ppd file for your printer and put it in /usr/share/cups/model,
then reconfigure the printer using this .ppd file and you should get all
the options your printer can support.

Your first stop should be the manufacturer's site, next
linuxprinting.org

HTH
Mohammed Riyaz P.

Powerpack from people who sell them 
cheaply(say 40 per cd) legal ??

From suraj at symonds.net  Thu Jan  6 11:09:39 2005
From: suraj at symonds.net (Suraj)
Date: Fri Jan  7 00:39:48 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] One Day One Command
In-Reply-To: <200501062219.51349.trshash84@gmail.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501062007480.6619-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>
	<200501062219.51349.trshash84@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20050106190939.GA300@symonds.net>

T.R.Shashwath wrote: 
,----
| ...Including the ability to use a whole function definition in it...
| 
| alias something="foo() { echo $bar }
`----

you can 'define'  a function, yes.  But whats your  point?  alias is a
literal expansion.  its very much like a pre-processor operation.

alias foo="function bar() { echo hello world; }"

will only  'define' the function 'bar'  when you type  'foo'. Its just
that instead of  having to type of the entire  function, you typed out
'foo'. and the above example is slightly misleading, in a way, in that
if people try to type 'foo test message', they would get syntax errors
because it does literal expansion.

some examples:

$ alias intemp="cd /tmp; "
$ intemp ls
<output of ls>
$ pwd
/tmp

$ alias obfuscated="function myfunc() {"
$ obfuscated echo hello world; }; myfunc
hello world
$

cheers,

  -Suraj

-- 
,-----------------[http://www.symonds.net/~suraj/]---o
| 'Oththu Nadaswaram' is very much similar to a 'sruthi box'. It is a simple open
| ended pipe set to a fixed frequency. It is used to tune Nagaswarams. It is
| one of the oldest 'pitch reference' instruments.
`------------------------------[suraj@symonds.net]---o

Try writing a whole script within an alias... Somewhat useless, but could be 
useful also.

From suraj at symonds.net  Thu Jan  6 18:21:46 2005
From: suraj at symonds.net (Suraj)
Date: Fri Jan  7 07:52:01 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] One Day One Command
In-Reply-To: <200501070103.51686.trshash84@gmail.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501062007480.6619-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>
	<200501062219.51349.trshash84@gmail.com>
	<20050106190939.GA300@symonds.net>
	<200501070103.51686.trshash84@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20050107022146.GA11989@symonds.net>

T.R.Shashwath wrote: 
,----
| Try writing  a whole script  within an alias... Somewhat  useless, but
| could be useful also.
`----

(please dont 'top-post').

Thats not  my point.  alias is a  literal expansion. For  example, you
cannot make your 'function' take arguments. For example if you want to
take a file as an argument to your alias and then cat that file and do
something...

cat <file> | ssh myhost "perl -e 'some code'"

this isn't  possible with a shell  alias. You *will* have  to define a
function.

Of course, you can do this:

alias x='function f { cat $1 |  ssh myhost "perl -e 'some code'"; };f'

But  whas the point?  you could  have pre-defined  'f' anyway  in your
bashrc.

cheers,

  -Suraj

On Thursday 06 Jan 2005 7:09 pm, Suraj wrote:

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Thu Jan  6 18:54:40 2005
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Fri Jan  7 08:25:06 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] RHEL Copyright issues...
In-Reply-To: <001b01c4f420$6925c3f0$0d07a8c0@kums>
Message-ID: <20050107025440.45391.qmail@web50206.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

> > Is buying Linux like RHEL 3,SUSE 9.2 pro, Mandrake
> > Powerpack from people who sell them 
> > cheaply(say 40 per cd) legal ??

As far as SuSE is concerned, you can copy, download
and redistribute the the CDs (pro and personal)
provided you don't charge for the software. One can
always do a SuSE FTP installation. 

When you buy SuSE personal and pro in the market (like
from compusa.com), you are not paying for the distro.
You are paying for the CDs/DVDs, manuals, tech support
etc.

Regards,

K Shakthi

K Shakthi

From ramanraj at iqara.net  Fri Jan  7 08:57:28 2005
From: ramanraj at iqara.net (Ramanraj K)
Date: Fri Jan  7 08:56:37 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] RHEL Copyright issues...
References: <20050106181549.35926.qmail@web54103.mail.yahoo.com>
	<41DD8578.2060805@frodo.hserus.net>
Message-ID: <41DE01A0.7080603@iqara.net>

  Suresh Ramasubramanian wrote:

> Easwaran K.V wrote:
>
>> Is buying Linux like RHEL 3,SUSE 9.2 pro, Mandrake
>> Powerpack from people who sell them cheaply(say 40 per cd) legal ??
>>
>> I know normal versions are free but, these
>> professional and enterprise versions are not to be
>> sold like this . am i correct ??
>
>
> Correct - quite often the distros are either free for download but not 
> for redistribution, or much more expensive (like RHEL) - and with 
> redistribution similarly prohibited.

What RedHat, SuSE and Mandrake essentially sell is support. Please check 
this out from their respective sites. For example at the RedHat 
Enterprise Linux Support Options and Pricing page at 
http://www.redhat.com/software/rhel/purchase/index.html and  
http://www.redhat.com/support/service/sla/rhel3.html , the prices vary 
depending upon the extent and mode of support.Generally, those who 
prohibit redistribution of GPLed or other like free software may be 
prosecuted for copyright violations, and therefore, they would not and 
don't prohibit redistribution.
  
All these companies work hard to put together distros, write patches, 
and even make very substantial contributions. The LinuxForYou issue 
dated Nov, 2004, carried an interview with  founder of RedHat, Michael 
Tiemann, how he single handedly did the GNU C++ compiler, in just six 
months, working hard for 18 hours a day, 7 days a week and finally 
announced it to the mailing list. Purchasing support services directly 
from the company could help to pay developers and also increase the 
reach of free software.  The boxes usually ship with good quality manuals.

> So Ritchie Street software pirates are now diversifying into pirating 
> linux distros as well?

So the Tsunami brought in pirates from the high seas ?  No offence ;)

-Ramanraj.

References:
http://www.redhat.com/legal/legal_statement.html
http://www.redhat.com/licenses/rhel_us_3.html?country=United+States&
http://www.redhat.com/licenses/rhel_rha_eula.html

From Toufeeq_Hussain at infosys.com  Fri Jan  7 09:37:54 2005
From: Toufeeq_Hussain at infosys.com (Toufeeq Hussain)
Date: Fri Jan  7 09:41:21 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Looking back at 2004 - Linux
Message-ID: <557E17BE74D22143B7BE70EB60E33E9914F721A0@shlmsg01.ad.infosys.com>

HI,

> -----Original Message-----
> From: ilugc-bounces@ae.iitm.ac.in 
> [mailto:ilugc-bounces@ae.iitm.ac.in] On Behalf Of Ramkumar R
> Sent: Friday, January 07, 2005 9:24 AM
> To: Chennai Linux User's Group
> Subject: Re: [Ilugc] Looking back at 2004 - Linux
> 
> may be you could enlighten other ilugc'ians abt how Ubuntu is 
> unique ??
> we surely need an user's perspective :)

I tried Ubuntu once.
And I can say that it's good for you if you fall in this category

* You love GNOME, not KDE (Kubuntu is for KDE fans)
* You have a broadband connection at home or the complete
	Sarge CD-set.
* Are Paranoid about keeping your Distro on the bleeding edge.

For the last point you can also try Gentoo :)

Ubuntu is just Debian, re-packaged with some pretty stuff and a good
Installer
With good hardware detection.I think it uses HAL for hardware detection.
It gives you a default-configured distro and then you can customise it
as you want.

The best thing about Ubuntu is the release cycles, the release cycles
are made
to co-incide with GNOME's, so each time a new GNOME revision happens,
you
can expect a Ubuntu release. They make sure that you get the latest
packages
within a 6 month span. This is a very good solution to the release
problems that
Currently plague Debian.

Also the staff on board Cannonical is some of the who's who of the
Linux-Desktop Community.
Jeff Waugh, Micheal Meeks ...

Regards,
Toufeeq Hussain  

From skarra at gmail.com  Fri Jan  7 10:09:32 2005
From: skarra at gmail.com (Sriram Karra)
Date: Fri Jan  7 10:09:51 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Elisp Tutorial
Message-ID: <3f986c69050106203925fd5b9b@mail.gmail.com>

Back in Mid 2002 in one of monthly ilugc meets, I gave a ~2 hour talk
on Emacs Lisp.  Here is a document I have written from the notes I
made for that talk.  I completely forgot about this doc. until
recently when I accidently 'locate'd it on some home directory back up
CD...
It is still incomplete, although I have tried to tie up the biggest
loose ends over the past few weeks.

Pick up the tutorial in postscript/html/LaTeX src from
http://www.cs.utah.edu/~karra/tutorial/

http://www.cs.utah.edu/~karra/elisp-tutorial.tar.gz is a tar bundle
containing just the Makefile and the LaTeX source, if you prefer.

-karra
From sridharinfinity at gmail.com  Fri Jan  7 10:55:01 2005
From: sridharinfinity at gmail.com (Sridhar R)
Date: Fri Jan  7 10:55:12 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Looking back at 2004 - Linux
In-Reply-To: <557E17BE74D22143B7BE70EB60E33E9914F721A0@shlmsg01.ad.infosys.com>
References: <557E17BE74D22143B7BE70EB60E33E9914F721A0@shlmsg01.ad.infosys.com>
Message-ID: <8816fcf805010621252b657ac7@mail.gmail.com>

On Fri, 7 Jan 2005 09:37:54 +0530, Toufeeq Hussain
<Toufeeq_Hussain@infosys.com> wrote:
> 
> I tried Ubuntu once.
> And I can say that it's good for you if you fall in this category
> 
> * You love GNOME, not KDE (Kubuntu is for KDE fans)

Ubuntu does have kde in 'universal', which means unsupported.

> * You have a broadband connection at home or the complete
>         Sarge CD-set.

Due to Ubuntu release cycle, I see a broadband connection is not at
all needed.  The user just get an Ubuntu CD each 6 months and upgrade
is current system with that.  Technicall this is possible with Debian
too, but Ubuntu does that in a clean way (fixed release cycles in sync
with Gnome).   Gnome users would love it.

> * Are Paranoid about keeping your Distro on the bleeding edge.
> 

This is the main reason I switched to Ubuntu from debian.  I need the
*latest* development packages.  For example, gnome-python-extras is
(as of now) missing in debian/sid and unofficial sources.  That
necessitated me to 'make install' pygtk-2.5, gnome-python-2.9.x and so
..on (the slackware way).

btw, 'warty' in ubuntu is like 'sarge' in debian only that it is not
updated throught that 6 months time (except for security updates). 
'hoary' is like 'sid' in debian but much closer to current.  For
example, 'hoary' has gnome2.9 as of now!

> For the last point you can also try Gentoo :)
> 

The only problem I had with Gentoo is the 'compile time'. 
Re-compiling everytime a  support release of package (same version)
happens is not pleasing.  Known solutions (just a compromise) are
using distcc, catching build files or using binary packages (quite
outdated than debian sarge binary packages).   Over all,  IMO,
advantage of user-level compilation is less when compared to binary
packages.

> Also the staff on board Cannonical is some of the who's who of the
> Linux-Desktop Community.
> Jeff Waugh, Micheal Meeks ...
> 

And Ubuntu enjoys enourmous sponsorship from Cannonical.

You can get *free* (gratis) official CDs from http://shipit.ubuntulinux.org/

-- 
Sridhar R - http://cs.annauniv.edu/~rsridhar
Blog: http://www.livejournal.com/~sridharinfinity
: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User:Sridharinfinity
From skperias at yahoo.co.uk  Thu Jan  6 21:25:02 2005
From: skperias at yahoo.co.uk (Periyaswamy Senthilkumar)
Date: Fri Jan  7 10:55:23 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Multiple path search in Script Alias - Apache
Message-ID: <20050107052502.91237.qmail@web25002.mail.ukl.yahoo.com>

Hi,

  I have Application1  on /home/app1/cgi-bin  &
         Application2  on /home/app2/cgi-bin

  I had Application1 being accessed by having the
ScriptAlias in httpd.conf as

ScriptAlias /cgi-bin/ "/home/app1/cgi-bin/"

I access the application from my client as 

 http://<Ip.address.of.Server>/cgi-bin/app1.cgi

Like we have multiple path searchs in the PATH
environment variable 

PATH=/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin

can we have a similar directive for the webserver , so
that I can specify the path of my second app and have
it accessed as 

http://<Ip.address.of.Server>/cgi-bin/app2.cgi

Thanks in advance for your help.

Regards,
Senthil

From anandhg02 at yahoo.com  Thu Jan  6 21:29:21 2005
From: anandhg02 at yahoo.com (Anandh G)
Date: Fri Jan  7 10:59:32 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Cron job execute query
Message-ID: <20050107052921.77930.qmail@web41708.mail.yahoo.com>

I am having a squid proxy server and I am using SARG
to generate access report. I want to get a report of
SARG on daily basis, Since SARG will look for the
Squid access.log file only to generate report, I
planned for rotating the Squid's access.log on daily
basis, so that there will be individual logs for every
day. 

     I added the a script to execute sarg in
/etc/cron.daily/ and also the logrotate was there
already resent in this directory. And I will execute
the cron.daily at system boot time (since we will
shutdown the system daily). what I want is, I want the
sarg script to be run before the logrotate so that the
report for the previous day will be generated and the
log file will be rotated.
     I saw a 0anacron file in this dir which says
adding a 0 infront of the file will make this to
execute first before any other cron files. How can do
the same for sarg.

    

=====
Regards,
AnandhG

> btw, 'warty' in ubuntu is like 'sarge' in debian only that it

> security updates).

A *complete* Ubuntu Distro based on hoary is way too
Bleeding-edge.

Should've improved now :)

Overall, it's a good Distro.
Side Note: the Ubuntu-user mailing list is great for solving
technical issues, but it's a *high traffic* one.

It has more posts than LKML!! :O

For redhat, fedora, see 'rpm'
For debian,ubuntu,.. see 'apt-get', 'sources.list'

From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Fri Jan  7 18:07:53 2005
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi S)
Date: Fri Jan  7 18:09:51 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] One Day One Command
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501071738320.5543-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

One Day One Command :-
---------------------

date -  Print & set the system data & time 

Summary: 

date will print the time information in different formats and we can 
also make a custom formats using the options.

Example:

$ date == print the current date and time
$ date -d '3year ago' == Same date but 3 yr ago
$ date --set='-10 minutes' == Reduce 10 min in the current time
$ date '+%b %_e %a %X %Z %Y' == Current date in custom format.

Read : info date

Bye :)
-- 
Bharathi S

Subject: [Ilugc] RHEL Copyright issues...

	<41DD8578.2060805@frodo.hserus.net> <41DE01A0.7080603@iqara.net>
	<41DE2717.9020807@frodo.hserus.net>
Message-ID: <41DE9BB6.6090304@iqara.net>

  Suresh Ramasubramanian wrote:

> The CDs contain non-free (as in cost, as well as closed source code 
> license) software as well
>
> So your argument does not completely apply here

Thanks for the correction.  If the CDs are known to contain non-free 
software/parts, the person who desires to redistribute and the end user 
as well needs to act according to the terms of its license.  Debian 
makes the task of redistribution easy with its classification of 
packages into free, non-free, contrib etc, but I am not sure how the 
others plan their distros.

-Ramanraj

References:
http://debui.vlsm.org/distrib/packages
http://debui.vlsm.org/social_contract#guidelines


From ramanraj at iqara.net  Fri Jan  7 19:56:13 2005

Subject: [Ilugc] [Fwd: [Fsf-friends] [RMS Events] Swatantra - Info]

-------- Original Message --------
Subject: [Fsf-friends] [RMS Events] Swatantra - Info
Date: Fri, 07 Jan 2005 18:45:12 +0530
From: Arun M <arun@gnu.org.in>


To: FSF Friends <fsf-friends@mm.gnu.org.in>



Swatantra is a conference focusing on Free and open Source 
technologies. Its the first of its kind event being organized 
in south India. The symposium will have food for thought for all 
genre of people may it be from the academic circles or the big 
time Industrial arena. 

    The symposium is being organized by the Department of Information
Technology, Vellore Institute of Technology ,Deemed University.  The
symposium will be held on 6th and 7th of February, 2005 and will be
divided into various sessions. 
                
   The event will also witness the inauguration of the Tamil Nadu
Chapter of the Free Software Foundation of India by Richard M. Stallman,
Founder GNU. RMS will deliver the keynote
on 6th Feb, 9.30 is the timing of his speech. Prof. Nagarjuna will 
be the chief guest and inaugurate the event. 

Please visit the site http://www.swatantra.info for more details. The
whole event is open to all including workng professionals and general
public.

"Sankar.M" <sankar62933@yahoo.co.in> wrote:

> I have been doing project in IPSpoofing.To
> prevent IPSpoofing i want to encrypt sequence number
> and then sent it.So please help me at which module,and
> in that module at which line i should  add the call to
> my encryption module ,so that i could encrypt the
> sequence no. before entered in the packet.If possible
> please specify any books,websites helpful in this
> area.

Sequence number guessing is a more than 4..5 year old fixed vulnerablity.

Please google for terms like "ingress filtering" and uRPF, and also see RFCs
2827 and 3704.

	srs

Date: Sat Jan  8 04:01:36 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Cron job execute query
In-Reply-To: <20050107052921.77930.qmail@web41708.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20050107052921.77930.qmail@web41708.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <41DF0E11.8030901@au-kbc.org>

Anandh G wrote:

>what I want is, I want the
>sarg script to be run before the logrotate so that the
>report for the previous day will be generated and the
>log file will be rotated.
>     I saw a 0anacron file in this dir which says
>adding a 0 infront of the file will make this to
>execute first before any other cron files. How can do
>the same for sarg.
>
>  
>
(1)Set  logfile_rotate  in your  squid.conf  then, create
FILE:  /etc/cron.daily/sarg
-----------------------

#!/bin/bash
 
#Get yesterday date
YESTERDAY=$(date --date "1 day ago" +%d/%m/%Y)
 
/path/to/sarg -o /DOCUMENTROOT/TO/REPORT/daily -d $YESTERDAY > /dev/null 2>&1

/path/to/squid -k rotate  
 
exit 0
-----------------

(2) Move squid logrotate config file from /etc/logrotate.d/squid  to /somewhere/

FILE:  /etc/cron.daily/sarg
-----------------------

#!/bin/bash
 
#Get yesterday date
YESTERDAY=$(date --date "1 day ago" +%d/%m/%Y)
 
/path/to/sarg -o /DOCUMENTROOT/TO/REPORT/daily -d $YESTERDAY > /dev/null 2>&1

/path/to/logrotate  /somewhere/squid 
 
exit 0
-----------------

this link may help you much.
http://sarg.sourceforge.net/sarg.php -->*Sarg users implementations 

*Thanks,
bharathi.


-- 
S.Bharathi Raja,
AU-KBC Research Centre,

From rohitbaisakhiya at gmail.com  Sun Jan  9 12:56:58 2005
From: rohitbaisakhiya at gmail.com (Rohit Baisakhiya)
Date: Sun Jan  9 12:57:08 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Shell scripting help
Message-ID: <1cd7e0305010823261bc9f560@mail.gmail.com>

Hello Luggers
I am new to shell scripting in linux.I need to make a script which can
ping an ip and can write to a file in values of 0 or 1(0 if it
receives ping reply and 1 if it receives no reply).I want to put the
script in crontab such that it tuns every 30 seconds and writes the
value to the file.

Any kind of pointers or help is appriciated.Please help.

-- 
Regards,
Rohit Baisakhiya
From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Sat Jan  8 23:41:54 2005
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Sun Jan  9 13:12:06 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Shell scripting help
In-Reply-To: <1cd7e0305010823261bc9f560@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20050109074154.61848.qmail@web50210.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi Rohit,

--- Rohit Baisakhiya <rohitbaisakhiya@gmail.com>
wrote:
> I need to make
> a script which can
> ping an ip and can write to a file in values of 0 or
> 1(0 if it
> receives ping reply and 1 if it receives no reply).

Try this:

#!/bin/bash
ping -c 1 www.yahoo.com 1>/dev/null
return=`echo $?`
if [ $return -eq 0 ]; then     #Success
  echo "0" >> /tmp/log.file
else                           #Failure   
  echo "1" >> /tmp/log.file
fi

Cheers,

K Shakthi

=====
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
K Shakthi
Specsoft (Hexaware Technologies), ASIC Design Center
http://www.geocities.com/shakthimaan
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

Do you Yahoo!? 
Yahoo! Mail - You care about security. So do we. 
http://promotions.yahoo.com/new_mail
From jujubha at yahoo.com  Sun Jan  9 02:56:29 2005
From: jujubha at yahoo.com (Chandrakumar Muthaiah)
Date: Sun Jan  9 13:27:26 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Shell scripting help
In-Reply-To: <1cd7e0305010823261bc9f560@mail.gmail.com>
References: <1cd7e0305010823261bc9f560@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <41E0E3AD.10802@yahoo.com>

This will do.
create it as ~/scripts/ping-ip.sh

-----------------------8<--------------------
#!/bin/sh

ip=$1
if [ "x$ip" == "x" ]; then
        echo "Need an IP address"
        exit 1
fi

ping -c 1 $ip < /dev/null > /dev/null 2>&1

if [ $? -eq 0 ]; then
        echo 1 > ~/ip.log
else
        echo 0 > ~/ip.log
fi
-----------------------8<--------------------

run it as

~/scripts/ping-ip.sh 192.168.1.1 </dev/null > /dev/null 2>&1

From suraj at symonds.net  Sun Jan  9 01:08:24 2005
From: suraj at symonds.net (Suraj)
Date: Sun Jan  9 14:38:36 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Shell scripting help
In-Reply-To: <20050109074154.61848.qmail@web50210.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <1cd7e0305010823261bc9f560@mail.gmail.com>
	<20050109074154.61848.qmail@web50210.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20050109090823.GA24797@symonds.net>

Shakthi Kannan wrote: 
,----
| #!/bin/bash
| ping -c 1 www.yahoo.com 1>/dev/null
| return=`echo $?`
| if [ $return -eq 0 ]; then     #Success
|   echo "0" >> /tmp/log.file
| else                           #Failure   
|   echo "1" >> /tmp/log.file
| fi
`----

Or simply:

ping -c 1  $host 2>&>/dev/null && echo 1 || echo 0 >>/tmp/log.file

cheers,

  -Suraj

Hi Rohit,

--- Rohit Baisakhiya <rohitbaisakhiya@gmail.com>
wrote:
> Thanks man.That's what i wanted but i want to ask
> one more thing if i
> want to ping any service or port like ftp port 21 or
> mysql 3306. How
> do i check if this services are running after every
> 30 seconds from
> another host.

Use nmap.

nmap:
http://www.insecure.org/nmap/

Introduction to nmap:
http://members.dodo.net.au/~ps2man/Nmap/nmap.html

Remote OS detection using via TCP/IP Stack
Fingerprinting:
http://www.insecure.org/nmap/nmap-fingerprinting-article.html

Cheers,

K Shakthi

From: Sridharan Anand <sanand@au-kbc.org>

Dear Free/Libre Open Source Software Enthusiast,

    There is a committee of the Ministry of Information
Technology, Government of India, that is visiting the AU-KBC
Research Centre (http://www.au-kbc.org), MIT Campus of Anna
University, Chromepet, Chennai, on Thursday, January 13, 2005, in
connection with launching a programme on `HRD for FOSS Capable IT
Professionals.'  The committee would like to have a
brain-storming session with all persons interested in FOSS from
10:30 AM -- 1:00 PM on the following issues:

- -- Status of current usage of FOSS in Industry, Government,
Education and Research, worldwide and in India.

- -- Human resources needs in the FOSS sector in India and abroad.

- -- Available FOSS human resources development programmes in the
 formal and informal sectors (in the world and in India).

- -- Government's possible role in promoting FOSS in India.

- -- Any other steps needed to promote FOSS in India.

    Kindly make it convenient to attend this meeting and give
your valuable inputs so that the Ministry of Information
Technology can formulate the necessary plans and schemes to
further the cause of FOSS which you have been serving
individually and collectively in a voluntary manner.  Enclosed
please find a note on the theme of `HRD for FOSS Capable IT
Professionals' from the Free Software Foundation (India) for
your information and comments.  In case you would also like to
circulate any note to the participants in this connection,
please send the same to us.  The meeting will end at 1.00PM with
lunch.  Please e-mail confirmation of your participlation to
me (Mob.: 98410 26505) or Anand Sridharan (Ph. 2223
4885/2711/1034).  Additional information on how to reach here etc.
will be supplied to you on geting your confirmation of
participation.  Look forward to seeing you here on the 13th.

					Regards,

					Prof. C. N. Krishnan.
                                        Director.


AU-KBC Research Centre
MIT Campus of Anna University
Chromepet, Chennai-44.
(http://www.au-kbc.org)
- --------
Comments sent by Professor Nagarjuna, Chairman, FSF (Free Software Foundation), India on 
the subject  `HRD for FOSS Capable IT Professionals.'

1. What are the focus areas that need to be addressed  by Govt. at  national & 
international levels?

Localization: 
Most urgent focus area should be to identify,  encourage and support the already ongoing 
groups that are  striving to localize (private IT solutions in Indian  languages) the 
GNU/Linux operating system.  How urgent this is becomes clear if we take into account the 
fact that  currently only 4% people (based on the approximate english  literacy) are 
capable of using computers, while our country  has about 65% literacy.  So far IT is 
enabling only the upper  strata of the country.  If we want our people to participate  in 
this information age, making content available to Indian  languages should be a top 
priority.  In this regard, another  serious matter: most of the already localized and 
digitized  content in Indian languages is done in an unethical and  inappropriate way, 
because the documents are encoded in  proprietary standards (both at the level of font and 
data  encoding).  This is serious becomes clear if we know that  this is not allowed in 
any other country except in India.  Govt. must enforce all the industries who are 
presently in  this market (including Govt's CDAC) to develop filters to covert all such 
documents in ISCII, TISCI and Unicode  formats. (please see below our proposals on 
Encoding policy)  

Conversion of schools to FOSS:  
We should work towards the  target of 100% FOSS use in schools 5 years from now, and  
before 2020.  Starting now, we shouldn't install any new  machines in schools/colleges and 
public institutions with  non-free software.  This will eventually solve not only HRD  
related issues for FOSS but also to nurture a good ethos  within the learning institutes 
that shape future societies.  

Content Development: 
While this might seem not a related  issue of FOSS, but FOSS practiced and demonstrated a 
unique  model where people can generate and maintain content that  they require on their 
own if they follow the wikipedia model  (http://www.wikipedia.org) and other such 
community portals.  We should not only create a mirror of sites like wikipedia in  our 
country, but also should make efforts to create and  translate the existing public content 
in Indian languages.  This will also encourage a large number of Indians to  contribute in 
such portals worldwide.  

Mirrors of Free Software:  
Indian mirrors (repositories that  keep upto date versions of the software developed)  must 
be  created and located within the country for faster and  sustained access. 

Internet: 
Internet is the nurturing media of swatantra  software.  It is difficult to visualize the 
success of free  software without Internet.  Providing faster and economical  access to 
this facility particularly for public institutions  will help support and sustain the 
movement further.  Though  not related to FOSS directly, we must have the network work  
within the country independent of the international backbone.  Seriousness of this becomes 
clearer if we look at the fact  that when our up front ISP's are disconnected to the 
international backbone, two people within a city in India may  not be able to communicate 
with each other despite the fact  that they are completely wired.  This could be due to 
the  non-availability of root DNS servers, and not a very clean routing of packets within 
the country.]  Not having such an  independent network may cause serious problems in case 
of  international pressures.  Having such a facility is crucial  for a good bargaining 
power of a developing nation.  China, I  was told, has such a network which works 
independent of the  international backbone.

At the international level we should protect our freedom in  matters related to imposing 
software patents. The current  stand by India on this very important issue should be held  
strongly and no modification is required.  We should  withstand and stand on our feet and 
defend our independence  in this matter without yeilding to the pressures of the so  
called developed countries and bigger financial powers to  enforce software patents in our 
country too. 
  

2. What policies / guidelines should be evolved to create a strong HRD  in FOSS in India?

Digital Encoding: 
A very important issue is to drive industry  and all govt and other      public bodies to 
encode all their  documents in open standards (non-proprietary).  E.g.,
exchanging and storing documents in MS Word should not be  allowed, since these documents 
being binary not only  propogate viruses with them making them vulnerable, but since  the 
encoding method is not a standard and the companies  change them in every next version 
merely (without any  technical reason) to keep their users locked and continue to  use 
their upgraded software.  If we encourage such usage,  then govt. is actually supporting a 
monopoly practice to  flourish within the country. Alternatively, the document  encodings 
be done in text, html, xml, pdf, rtf, in that order  of preference.  A similar policy for 
encoding spreadsheets,  databases, audio, video etc.  All digital encodings of public  
documents as a policy cannot be done in propreitary  standards.  FSF India wishes that we 
work towards enforcing  this by bringing in other stakeholders and confederations  like 
NASSCOM, FICCI, CII, MAIT etc should be alerted to take  up this issue in the national 
interest.  This will encourage  good business ethos within the industry.  We wish that 
Govt.  take this initiative and lead.  FSF India will provide any  help to Govt. in this 
regard in arriving at a policy document.

Curriculum: 
Second major issue for human resource development  within the country is to plan in a major 
way to restructure  the technical curriculum of schools and colleges within the  country.  
What is happening now is no less than a crime:  e.g., existence of brand names within the 
curriculum/syllabi  at all levels (schools, colleges and  universities).  This is  a 
direct endorsement of a particular company and a specific  application.  This is a serious 
issue and should be  considered very urgent.  We need to alert and bring together  the 
policy makers of technical education immediately and ask  them to remove all mentions of 
brand names in the  syllabi. For example, eliminate Oracle and replace it by  RDBMS, 
eliminate Exell and replace it by spreadsheet etc.  This kind of secular syllabi will 
provide enough freedom also  to the instructors to use what is available.  When we went to  
schools and organizations to promote free software we were astonished to find such glaring 
omissions.  We request that  Govt. must look in to this matter.  Keeping in mind that  
schools and colleges are the places where the trained  technical persons are getting 
generated, it is here that we  need to concentrate to create a secular technical 
curriculum.  Please keep in mind that a large number or private IT  training colleges are 
directly funded by major software  companies to provide education only in a specific 
technology.  If technical training is entirely left to private interests  bigger companies 
will dictate what is good for the country and  not the Govt.  We should also monitor this 
area also, since  many people opt for getting trained in such institutes.
  
Swatantra Software Consortium: 
By inviting all the stake  holders and confederations a consortium (similar to the W3C)  
should be formed to make informed decisions on technical and  policy issues related to 
software and technical matters.  

Standards to be followed by Websites:  
Access to content  available on the Internet depends on the delivery method  followed by 
the content publishers.  Most content publishers  unknowingly  support some specific 
encodings again  proprietary, which will enforce the users to use a particular  
technology, again promoting certain business interests. 
  
A much bigger and broader issue is to drive towards a policy  where no technology is 
allowed to be distributed (marketed)  in a proprietary mode of delivery.  Just as we seek 
our  automobiles come with nuts and bolts we should demand that  every software that is 
marketed must carry the source code  along with the right to modify and distribute the 
software.  This is going to encourage a lot of innovation, as is already  evident within 
the FOSS world, within the country.  This is  the best way to achieve the self-reliance 
enshrined in our  Constitution, and is the main focus of the 2020 vision of our  Honarable 
President Kalam.  Let people participate in shaping  the technology of our society.

Law mandating use of Free and Open Software and Standards in public  affairs is necessary  
to enable wider and stronger  use and adoption  of FOSS. Just as the GNU Manifesto, and 
the GPL together laid a firm  foundation for growth of free software, a clear statement of 
objects  and reasons for using  FOSS for Computerisation, with enunciation of  it as 
legislation  alone will enable use, adoption  and evolution of  workable  solutions.   A   
'Computerisation  [FOSS]  Act'  may  help  establishing public  networks to handle  
routine transactions, using  FOSS, with transparency at every level, for productivity and 
growth.  Without this, there would be  wastage of resources resulting in poor  
implementations not usable or workable.

 It is also necessary to  have laws that compel hardware and software  manufacturers to 
disclose technical specifications and details about  their   products   to  buyers,   to   
enable  interoperability   and  portability.  For example, new AGP  cards like NVIDIA are 
getting far  more complex than the CPU,  and it may become increasingly difficult  to  
reverse engineer  such  complex hardware  to  make such  devices  accessible  to  free 
software.   Selective  disclosures to  non-free  software entities  alone promote 
monopolies,  and therefore harmful.  Manufacturers should disclose full information about 
their products,  which   will   also  enable   independent   checking,  testing   and  
verification of product integrity and security.

All research  projects funded by the  state should be  made free and  open to the public.  
FSF  India has already elaborated the necessity  for this in its recent memorandum 
addressed to CSIR.

Software Patents Policy to be arrived at as mentioned in  response to the first point.

Keep reverse engineering legal. This is required till all the  technology is not free.

India should reject US pressure to prohibit free software to  play a DVD, etc.

Any attempt by other bodies that try to create policies that  would limit what can the FOSS 
community can do should be  resisted.  One way is to play an active role in WIPO to block  
any proposed treaties that would limit what people are  allowed to do with FOSS.  For 
instance, the proposed WIPO  Broadcast Treaty would do this.


3. Any other suggestions on the subject  `HRD for FOSS capable IT  Professionals'.

If the above mentioned basic issues are addressed most of the ground work for creating FOSS 
professionals get created.

Contests, Events, Festivals and awareness camps may be organized to enthuse the community 
to develop Swatantra software solutions.  FSF India will help organizations that come 
forward to organize such events.  Special projects for developing Swatantra software may 
be given to qualified professionals to develop the required software.  

Nagarjuna G.
Chairman
Free Software Foundation of India.
http://www.gnu.org.in

point to different servers depending on load)

From suraj at symonds.net  Sun Jan  9 19:57:43 2005
From: suraj at symonds.net (Suraj)
Date: Mon Jan 10 09:27:55 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Compiling php page from a script with out a browser.
In-Reply-To: <874qhqzgic.fsf@gmx.net>
References: <1cd7e0305010900055f5373fe@mail.gmail.com>
	<41e0ef5b.QlNP2ohfQE3x16ju%linux@frodo.hserus.net>
	<1cd7e03050109022735c9d9c9@mail.gmail.com>
	<20050109111247.GA1528@symonds.net> <874qhqzgic.fsf@gmx.net>
Message-ID: <20050110035743.GA14491@symonds.net>

Joe Steeve wrote: 
,----
| After an address  resolution, the client is going  to be connecting to
| only one IP., hence there wont  be a problem. (when using DNS to point
| to different servers depending on load)
`----

Thats not my  point.  The application is where  it matters.  The first
run, The user  might get a session cookie from  one machine but during
the next 'click' it might go  to a different front-end. In large scale
solutions  data replication and  clustering is  a solution.   In small
scale, I  can only think  of having custom session  handling functions
that  write to,  say,  NFS mounted  directories  or write  to a  MySQL
DB). So wondering how these guys might have set this up.

cheers,

  -Suraj

| Sarabha Sastrigal was a blind flautist who died in his 30s.
`------------------------------[suraj@symonds.net]---o

You can use a package manager like yum for rpm or apt for
debian/fedora (apt4rpm works for rpm's as well).....these programs
work with repositories - you can make a directory as a
repository....even for rpm's I would suggest apt, though it is not
shipped by default - it is quite powerful and extensible - and has
nice gui frontends like synaptic (unlike yum).

it moves on...

From madhukar_linux at yahoo.co.in  Mon Jan 10 08:22:02 2005

Hi all,
       ioremep() is a function, which maps physical

my doubt is:
   why we should map physical address to
virtual-address?

   we can read and write to physical address only know

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Mon Jan 10 00:30:32 2005
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Mon Jan 10 14:00:41 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] doubt: on ioremap()
In-Reply-To: <20050110082202.60924.qmail@web8403.mail.in.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20050110083032.66414.qmail@web50201.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi Madhukar,

--- Madhukar mythri <madhukar_linux@yahoo.co.in>
wrote:
>    why we should map physical address to
> virtual-address?

Because kernel is running in virtual address space.
All physical addresses are to be mapped to its address
space.
 
> we can read and write to physical address only
> know
> directly....

Also remember to use readl/b/w, writel/b/w functions
with ioremapped addresses.

Regards,

K Shakthi

K Shakthi

From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Mon Jan 10 14:32:12 2005
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi S)
Date: Mon Jan 10 14:33:35 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] One Day One Command
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501101417120.4083-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

One Day One Command :-
---------------------

echo - Display a line of text on the screen

Summary: 

Echo is used to show a line of text on the screen with limited Esc
sequence (BELL, Backspace, H-Tab, V-Tab,...) handling capabilities.

Example:

$ echo  -- print a empty line
$ echo "Bharathi\nMidas" -- Just print the Line
$ echo -e "Bharathi\n\tMidas" -- Interpret and print the Line
$ cat nums
  1
  2
  3

$ echo -n `cat nums` -- Print the file content with-out new line char.
  1 2 3 

Read: man echo

Bye :)
--
Bharathi S

From: "Suresh Ramasubramanian" <linux@frodo.hserus.net>
To: <schander@mindspring.com>
Cc: "Sivasankar Chander" <siva@whitebox.dias.ath.cx>;
<ilugc@ae.iitm.ac.in>
Sent: Sunday, December 26, 2004 9:02 PM
Subject: Re: [Ilugc] OT: Automated Tsunami warning script/program ?


> Sivasankar Chander wrote:
> >   Just thinking out aloud - it should be fairly trivial to develop
a
> > PHP/Perl script that parses the USGS Earthquake Hazards site at
> > http://earthquakes.usgs.gov, retrieves information for all
earthquake
> > events, and automatically sends out an e-mail alarm when an event
>
> One of my friends already has this up and running - he's in Taiwan,
> which has lots more earthquakes and tsunamis on a regular basis.
>

-----------------------------

From: "Sivasankar Chander" <siva@dias.ath.cx>
To: <ilugc@ae.iitm.ac.in>
Cc: "Sivasankar Chander" <siva@whitebox.dias.ath.cx>
Sent: Sunday, December 26, 2004 8:08 PM
Subject: [Ilugc] OT: Automated Tsunami warning script/program ?


>
>   Just thinking out aloud - it should be fairly trivial to develop a
> PHP/Perl script that parses the USGS Earthquake Hazards site at
> http://earthquakes.usgs.gov, retrieves information for all
earthquake
> events, and automatically sends out an e-mail alarm when an event
> exceeding a certain magnitude (say 7.0) occurs within a well-defined
> Oceanic region (say the Indian Ocean / Bay of Bangal). This would
> be similar to the systems already in operation at the Pacific
> Tsunami Watch Centre (PTWC) at Honolulu, Hawaii and the Alaska
> Tsunami Watch Centre (ATWC), both of which parse a network of
> seismometers and issue automated warnings.
>
>   The reason this works very well for the US and Japan is that
> the Pacific Ocean is fairly large, so there's a sufficient
> delay between an Earthquake event (which can be detected in
> less than 15 minutes around the globe from the fast-propagating
> P-Wave) and the following Tsunami, which could take about 12 hours
> to get from one side of the Pacific Ocean to the other. This allows
> ample time for a warning to be circulated.
>
>   In the case of the Great Sumatran/Andamans Earthquake of 2004
> (which took place this morning), the P-wave would have reached
Madras
> in about 4 minutes, while the Tsunami took about 2.5-3 hours to
reach
> Madras.
>
> The time difference would have been barely sufficient to get a
> message out on the Radio/TV and evacuate the low-lying coastal
areas.
> Difficult, but definitely well within reach of present technology.
> However, it's another issue whether we have the civic discipline
> to actually perform an orderly and timely evacuation in India :-(.
>
> -Siva

From suraj at symonds.net  Mon Jan 10 01:54:08 2005
From: suraj at symonds.net (Suraj)
Date: Mon Jan 10 15:24:17 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] One Day One Command
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501101417120.4083-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

Bharathi S wrote: 
,----
| $ echo -n `cat nums` -- Print the file content with-out new line char.
|   1 2 3
`----

Technically, its  the shell that  interprets the `cat nums`  first and
then  supplies them to  echo as  arguments.  It  doesn't matter  if we
supplied the -n argument here or not.

cheers,

  -Suraj

From sanand at au-kbc.org  Mon Jan 10 10:49:51 2005
From: sanand at au-kbc.org (Sridharan Anand)
Date: Mon Jan 10 16:33:07 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: [Fwd] Invitation: FOSS brain-storming session with Min.
	of IT
References: <20050109114648.GA4723@symonds.net>
	<ed2d3c00050109224864c225a7@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <loom.20050110T114754-20@post.gmane.org>

Thyagu rajan <citizenofgnu@...> writes:

> we would like to meet the convention on FOSS on 13th at chennai.

Everyone is welcome to participate in this session.  However, please note
that

0) there is only limited seating available (we should be able to easily
accommodate 30-40 people)
1) on the other hand, 13th. is a working day, so we're not sure how many
people will actually turn up

To help us plan the logistics appropriately, I would appreciate it if
interested persons confirmed their participation ASAP.  I believe
there is going to be a formal ILUG-C `delegation' at the meeting.  In
addition, we would especially welcome participation of people from
industry, academia and research who are actively using, developing or
promoting Free Software in their work.  This meeting is meant to be a 
kind of forum for Govt. to learn about their experiences, to learn about
their needs, and what Govt. can do to fulfil those needs in the long
term.  Specifically, the focus will be on the initiatives Govt. can take
to promote Free Software in the education and human resources sectors.
Those who will not be able to attend but who have something to say on
this issue may send me thier notes, so that they can be circulated among the
representatives from the GoI.

More details will be posted on this thread, as and when they become
available. HAND.

Later,

Anand.

Hello all,

I would like to design a Document Management System in LAMP which
would convert all uploaded Documents to PDF. For this I would like to
use the filters used in OpenOffice.org for conversion. I would like to
know whether there would be any isues in using the OpenOffice.org
source code like this. This would be a strictly academic oriented non
commercial Open Source project which I would like to put up although,
I have no big expecations. It is going to be designed for purely
academic purposes.

Thanks to all.
