This event is for you then. Vellore Institute of Technology is 
organizing
a symposium on Free and Open Source software technologies titled
Swatantra(6th - 7th Feb, 05). 

Founder of GNU and the man responsible for coining the term Free 
Software,
Richard M Stallman will be there to deliver the keynote address of the
symposium and to answer all the questions that you have always wanted 
to
ask about these amazingly simply yet inherently complex programs. 

The event will also feature various competitions to kindle your nack 
for
Linux tweaking and tuning such as:- 

LINSTALL-- The Linux installation challenge.
Anaconda !! YaSt !! familiar with all these name? Have been installing 
on
your system for a long time and you find it fun?? making the X server 
run??
configuring the boot loader?? ..YES??..One event where apply all your
skills which you developed over the years by trying to install 
GNU/Linux on
your system. 

WEBMINISTER-- The Apache web server Challenge
Love Apache because of the customizability it offers while deploying 
your
website? Love fiddling with httpd.conf and think you are best at it? 
This
is one event to prove yourself! Come and demonstrate that your are the 
best
at the best web server that there is and ever was..... 

CORE WARS-- Challenge the memory
This event will feature an old game called core wars which involves
destroying your opponents programs by overwriting the memory in which 
this
program is stored. It will kindle the nerves of memory geeks with 
pointers
and direct memory references expertise being the norm. 

Watch out for cool demonstrations on MONO, Linux Cluster, Linux from
scratch and much more.... 

For further details log on to: http://swatantra.info
or mail us at: contact@swatantra.info

Anurag
http://www.geocities.com/anuragvit/fest.htm




---------------------------------
  Yahoo! Messenger - Communicate instantly..."Ping" your friends today! Download Messenger Now
From andyetitmoves at gmail.com  Mon Jan 10 17:52:31 2005
From: andyetitmoves at gmail.com (Ramkumar R)
Date: Mon Jan 10 17:52:39 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Window manager that is enemy of Mouse
In-Reply-To: <20050110120658.GA35149@frodo.hserus.net>
References: <8816fcf805011001593e656cbd@mail.gmail.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0501101553090.11328-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>
	<8816fcf805011002414629fdbd@mail.gmail.com>
	<20050110120658.GA35149@frodo.hserus.net>
Message-ID: <9a9bfc1705011004227b27826@mail.gmail.com>

I would go in for enlightenment - well, even with a working mouse, I use it...
Has an excellent keybinding system - all wm actions and any arbitrary
shell command can be executed - there's a functional gui called
e16keyedit for this too - add `essh', the enlightenment wm shell to
this - you can go to desktop 1, launch emacs, kill any window matching
the title regexp '.*g?vim.*' ( ;) ), goto area (2,3), restore any
minimized windows, asynchronously wait for emacs to finish loading and
notify you with music of your choice - all when you press
Ctrl+Alt+G...Especially if you are a confiuguration maniac (like
making windows of one particular class focus on clicking...well, if u
have a working mouse...) and love  eye candy (like a translucent image
of the window when moving it) - the E is the way to go.

One more suggestion - if your left button isn't working - may be you
could use the X config to swap your buttons - we use the left button
more than the right, right ?

it moves on...

On Sun, 9 Jan 2005 03:12:47 -0800, Suraj <suraj@symonds.net> wrote:
> Rohit Baisakhiya wrote:
> ,----
> | No my  dear its not any  exam, it the need  of the day for  me. We are
> | setting up  a replication/loadbalancer  setup for our  php/mysql based
> | web portal. I  am not a developer or programer, so  need help from all
> | you guys.
> `----
> 
> By 'load  balancer' are you talking  about a setup  where multiple web
> servers are serving  traffic? How do you handle  sessions?  Would like
> to hear  how your setup is  (hoping its a one-man  setup/solution :) )
> and how its performance is.
> 

Yes we have 6 webservers, 2 mysql db servers, 1 mail server running
qmail & 1 file server. we are using unison for site syncronisation and
real time db replication with mysql 4.1.8. Also the script which i
took for changing the values 0 & 1 is read by a php code in which we
have a condition for connection mysql db server "mysql_connect" , if
it reads value 0 it will connect the master db server and if it gets
value 1 it will connect slave server.

cheers !!! 

Rohit Baisakhiya.

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Mon Jan 10 06:51:10 2005
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Mon Jan 10 20:21:22 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] doubt: on ioremap()
In-Reply-To: <20050110093716.65271.qmail@web8408.mail.in.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20050110145111.63125.qmail@web50207.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

--- Madhukar mythri <madhukar_linux@yahoo.co.in>
wrote:
>    So ioremap() is done for Memory mapped IO only..
>  and not for IO mapped IO ( am i correct)

Why not? 

Use ioremap() for IO-mapped and use inb(), outb()
functions.
 
>   is it must, to access memory mapped address we
> should do ioremap()???

Did you try it without remapping? Oops ... you will
get that. Good way to learn oops debugging!

Highly recommended:
http://www.xml.com/ldd/chapter/book/ch08.html

Regards,

K Shakthi

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Mon Jan 10 07:29:35 2005
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Mon Jan 10 20:59:45 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] (no subject)
In-Reply-To: <20050110150232.28416.qmail@webmail9.rediffmail.com>
Message-ID: <20050110152935.10725.qmail@web50208.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

My thoughts below:

You also want school/college students to attend
workshops/lectures. Schedule your events in such a way
that you can avoid timing conflicts.

I will be happy to render lectures, attend to
question-answer sessions (Feb 19, 20 - weekends).
 
> &#61623; Public 
> o Demo

I would encourage MIT students to take this as an
opportunity to learn something _new_ and demo the
same. 
http://www.tldp.org/HOWTO/HOWTO-INDEX/categories.html

> o Application Project Demonstration

Conduct a three-four member programming contest. Can
be multiple problems to be solved in a stipulated time
or give it as a single project. 

> o Web page Design using Free Software Technology

Should be interesting. Some useful tools here for web
designers:
http://www.linuxforum.com/forums/index.php?showtopic=53452

> o Paper Presentation  /* Please suggest topics */
> o Quiz
> o Ad. Design Contest
> o Hacking /* Please Suggest */

You can setup servers and invite students to _hack_
into the system. No script kiddies! 
But, participants will have to be strong in
assembly/perl/C. 

> o Game Zone

UT!
 
> Workshops & Lecture Topics
> &#61623; Kernel Programming

You are targeting a larger audience. Not sure how many
will be interested in it. Requires strong
fundamentals.

> &#61623; GNU Programming tools

Should be useful.

> &#61623; Advanced  Linux Programming

Same as kernel programming.

> &#61623; Networking in Linux

Show as many demos as possible.

Your strength is the number of students and computers.
I suggest you keep as many displays/demos/stalls as
possible, apart from the events. WYSIWYG - you can
convey a lot of info with eye-catching displays.

Regards,

K Shakthi

=====

K Shakthi
Specsoft (Hexaware Technologies), ASIC Design Center
http://www.geocities.com/shakthimaan

Suraj wrote:
> Rohit Baisakhiya wrote: 
> ,----
> | if it  reads value 0 it  will connect the  master db server and  if it
> | gets value 1 it will connect slave server.
> `----
> 
> What you  should rather do  is to run  a local nameserver that  does a
> round-robin rotation for your mysql server.

That wont help failover which is what he wants to implement I guess.
It is basically overkill if all he has are two or three mysql servers - 
better use them as a single cluster and cache mysql connections, using 
sqlrelay or other mysql clustering app.

	srs

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Mon Jan 10 22:29:29 2005
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Mon Jan 10 22:27:35 2005
Subject: laptops.. (was ..Re: [Ilugc] Window manager that is enemy of
	Mouse)
In-Reply-To: <20050110162947.46703.qmail@web12707.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20050110162947.46703.qmail@web12707.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <41e2b471.MII74wLjYoALvSjV%linux@frodo.hserus.net>

Toufeeq Hussain <topa_007@yahoo.com> wrote:

> Speaking of laptops, any suggestions regarding the
> same.
>
> I heard Thinkpads are the best for Linux and Vaio's
> the worst.
> This is in terms of H/W support.
>
> What does the ILUGC community prefer.. ?

I have an acer travelmate 290 series (292 FxCi) that I rather like.

Centrino laptop (ipw2200.sourceforge.net for the centrino drivers), intel
motherboard + video card, ac97 sound card with rather cheesy speakers, an
internal modem that linmodems.org seems to detect just fine, and rtl8139 /
realtek ethernet card.

Slackware 10 worked just fine almost out of the box - had to download and
compile the ipw2200 driver for 2.6.x though (this box now runs 2.6.10 just
great).

Two other things you need - especially with 2.6 and intel's centrino speedstep
- are:

1. cpufreqd - http://cpufreqd.sourceforge.net
2. laptop-mode-tools to take advantage of the 2.6 laptop mode -
   http://www.xs4all.nl/~bsamwel/laptop_mode/tools/

FC3, Sarge etc should also install just fine on this guy .. and best of all, it
is lightweight, sleek aluminium colored, and ships with RH7.3 preinstalled that
you can format without worrying that your laptop's cost includes the cost of a
licensed windows XP that you're going to format and install linux on top of it.

	srs

> I heard Thinkpads are the best for Linux and Vaio's
> the worst.

I'd recommend Thinkpad anyday, and would suggest to best avoid notebooks
from the Asian market if you are looking for sturdy-build coupled with
excellent Linux support (esp. the cheap ones from Fujitsu, Jaguar,
Sharp, Toshiba and Sony). But then again, that's just my personal
opinion. Even Dell laptops are way better. Owning a Powerbook is like
owning a Mercedes (and not many would want Linux on that box).

I find a lot of people complain about the trackpoint device... But
strangely, I'm used to it so well that I couldn't easily adjust myself
to touchpads when I get my hands on a different notebook ;-). But then,
yes... vast majority of people are more comfortable with touchpads
(newer models of thinkpads have them too).

> i've been using this acer for a while now and it is pretty good.

I've heard good reviews about acer too (though never got my hands on one
as yet). There's a rumour that a couple of IBM thinkpad models are being
manufactured (outsourced) at Acer itself... know not how far thats true,
yet someone told me that one of his "outsourced" IBM thinkpad had issues
with Linux (XFree86 rather) detecting the video chipset an year back.

There are these new notebooks that I've come across in this month's
PCQuest magazine - Ingram Micro, Edge, Connoi and Benq.
Anyone tried their luck getting Linux to work on these models ? Any
comments about their hardware support on Linux ?

--
Chandrashekar Babu                       
http://www.chandrashekar.info/

unknown unknown GNU/Linux

hotter. How do i determine temp.

coming back to the  real question
">i need to make a script which can call a php file with out
> being opened in a browser should be compiled and the function in the
> php file should be executed."

dir>/bin/php) with the file name as an argument. But i am yet to find
out how to pass values (GET or POST) to generate dynamic pages.....

waiting to know more about load balancing and clustering...

text. The formatting would be lost.

From Toufeeq_Hussain at infosys.com  Tue Jan 11 08:54:27 2005
From: Toufeeq_Hussain at infosys.com (Toufeeq Hussain)
Date: Tue Jan 11 08:57:08 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] convert to doc
Message-ID: <557E17BE74D22143B7BE70EB60E33E99150A3129@shlmsg01.ad.infosys.com>

Hi,
 
> how to convert pdf to doc in linux
> iam using fc 1

You'll need the pdf-utils package.
It contains utilities to convert between pdf to other formats.
One of the formats is rtf, from which you can build a Word Doc in OO
Writer.

Google around..

Regards,
Toufeeq Hussain

From suraj at symonds.net  Mon Jan 10 19:41:21 2005
From: suraj at symonds.net (Suraj)
Date: Tue Jan 11 09:11:32 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] How do i determine MotherBoard/CPU parameters
In-Reply-To: <32b5ee76050110101135885bd3@mail.gmail.com>
References: <32b5ee76050110101135885bd3@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20050111034121.GA5436@symonds.net>

Varun Soundararajan wrote: 
,----
| On touching  the cabinet when in  linux it appears that  the System is
| hotter. How do i determine temp.
`----

cat    /proc/acpi/thermal_zone/THRM/temperature   |   perl    -pi   -e
's/.*:\s+(\d+).*/$1/'

Have this  in your prompt  or write a  gdesklets applet that  does the
above and stick it in your desktop.

Also  try 'athcool'[1],  but  be warned  that  it might  not work  for
you. It works for me (Athlon XP  2600+ / VIA KM800A). I *used* to hear
an  annoying  noise  from  my  on-board sound  card  when  using  this
software, but thats reduced a lot after I put a PCI SBLive 5.1 in.

cheers,

  -Suraj

References:

[1] http://members.jcom.home.ne.jp/jacobi/linux/softwares.html#athcool

-- 
,-----------------[http://www.symonds.net/~suraj/]---o
| Maaya maalava gowLa is the raga first taught to students of Carnatic music
| .
`------------------------------[suraj@symonds.net]---o
From suraj at symonds.net  Mon Jan 10 19:52:39 2005
From: suraj at symonds.net (Suraj)
Date: Tue Jan 11 09:22:49 2005
Subject: laptops.. (was ..Re: [Ilugc] Window manager that is enemy

In-Reply-To: <557E17BE74D22143B7BE70EB60E33E99150A3144@shlmsg01.ad.infosys.com>

Toufeeq Hussain wrote: 
,----
| Yeah.  There's something magical about the Thinkpad + Linux combo.  It
| seems to go so well.
`----

The very first  (or second or third) ILUGC meet  I attended had Asokan
demoing Debian "potato" (it was 'frozen' back then) on his Dell laptop
that he lovingly called "DellBian".  Everything worked out of the box.
Sound, Graphics  (on a  large 1280x1024 display  running windowmaker),
Network.

Of  course, "out  of  the box"  is a  term  that continues  to take  a
different meaning  during each  era.  :) One  had to type  'lspci' and
'modprobe' the  appropriate modules and almost always  it was preceded
by  a kernel  compile.   and  often there  were  these huge  "cultural
divides" between various distros.  People would complain that there is
no pppconfig in redhat or a sndconfig in debian and such.

cheers,

  -Suraj

-- 
,-----------------[http://www.symonds.net/~suraj/]---o
| KJ Yesudas is the student of Chembai Vaidyanatha Bagawathar
`------------------------------[suraj@symonds.net]---o

--- Shakthi Kannan <cyborg4k@yahoo.com> wrote:

> Hi,
> 
> --- Madhukar mythri <madhukar_linux@yahoo.co.in>

> >    So ioremap() is done for Memory mapped IO
> only..
> >  and not for IO mapped IO ( am i correct)
> 
> Why not? 
> 
> Use ioremap() for IO-mapped and use inb(), outb()
> functions.
>

> > should do ioremap()???
>

> get that. Good way to learn oops debugging!

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Tue Jan 11 09:43:56 2005
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Tue Jan 11 09:41:28 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] How do i determine MotherBoard/CPU parameters
In-Reply-To: <32b5ee7605011011434a10e4e0@mail.gmail.com>
References: <32b5ee76050110101135885bd3@mail.gmail.com>	<20050110190249.5031.qmail@web50201.mail.yahoo.com>
	<32b5ee7605011011434a10e4e0@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <41E35284.3070006@frodo.hserus.net>

Varun Soundararajan wrote:
> [varun@varun bin]$ sensors
> Can't access procfs/sysfs file
> Unable to find i2c bus information;
> For 2.6 kernels, make sure you have mounted sysfs!
> For older kernels, make sure you have done 'modprobe i2c-proc'!
> [varun@varun bin]$ mount
> <snip>
> none on /sys type sysfs (rw)
> <snip>

suresh@etherkiller 09:41:37 <~> $ lsmod|grep thermal
thermal                10888  0
processor              15660  1 thermal

and from my rc.modules on slackware 10 -

### ACPI
/sbin/modprobe ac
/sbin/modprobe battery
/sbin/modprobe processor
/sbin/modprobe button
/sbin/modprobe fan
/sbin/modprobe thermal

And from my kernel .config for 2.6.10 (along with the adjoining cpufreq 
settings that you can use along with http://cpufreqd.sourceforge.net)

#
# ACPI (Advanced Configuration and Power Interface) Support
#
CONFIG_ACPI=y
CONFIG_ACPI_BOOT=y
CONFIG_ACPI_INTERPRETER=y
CONFIG_ACPI_SLEEP=y
CONFIG_ACPI_SLEEP_PROC_FS=y
CONFIG_ACPI_AC=m
CONFIG_ACPI_BATTERY=m
CONFIG_ACPI_BUTTON=m
CONFIG_ACPI_VIDEO=m
CONFIG_ACPI_FAN=m
CONFIG_ACPI_PROCESSOR=m
CONFIG_ACPI_THERMAL=m
CONFIG_ACPI_ASUS=m
CONFIG_ACPI_IBM=m
CONFIG_ACPI_TOSHIBA=m
CONFIG_ACPI_BLACKLIST_YEAR=0
# CONFIG_ACPI_DEBUG is not set
CONFIG_ACPI_BUS=y
CONFIG_ACPI_EC=y
CONFIG_ACPI_POWER=y
CONFIG_ACPI_PCI=y
CONFIG_ACPI_SYSTEM=y
CONFIG_X86_PM_TIMER=y

#
# APM (Advanced Power Management) BIOS Support
#
# CONFIG_APM is not set

#
# CPU Frequency scaling
#
CONFIG_CPU_FREQ=y
# CONFIG_CPU_FREQ_DEBUG is not set
CONFIG_CPU_FREQ_PROC_INTF=y
CONFIG_CPU_FREQ_DEFAULT_GOV_PERFORMANCE=y
# CONFIG_CPU_FREQ_DEFAULT_GOV_USERSPACE is not set
CONFIG_CPU_FREQ_GOV_PERFORMANCE=y
CONFIG_CPU_FREQ_GOV_POWERSAVE=y
CONFIG_CPU_FREQ_GOV_USERSPACE=y
CONFIG_CPU_FREQ_24_API=y
CONFIG_CPU_FREQ_GOV_ONDEMAND=m
CONFIG_CPU_FREQ_TABLE=y

From andyetitmoves at gmail.com  Tue Jan 11 09:48:52 2005
From: andyetitmoves at gmail.com (Ramkumar R)
Date: Tue Jan 11 09:49:02 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] How do i determine MotherBoard/CPU parameters
In-Reply-To: <41E35284.3070006@frodo.hserus.net>
References: <32b5ee76050110101135885bd3@mail.gmail.com>
	<20050110190249.5031.qmail@web50201.mail.yahoo.com>
	<32b5ee7605011011434a10e4e0@mail.gmail.com>
	<41E35284.3070006@frodo.hserus.net>
Message-ID: <9a9bfc1705011020181b6cfae9@mail.gmail.com>

gkrellm rocks....perhaps one app I can go on talking abt like I did
for enlightenment...occupies one full column of my desktop with
everything from an alsa frequency spectrum to monitoring cpu
usage...sensors support is excellent - works with ACPI, lm_sensors,
hddtemp (may be others too..)...make sure you run sensors_detect
(comes with lm_sensors) as root - quite comprehensive and interactive
- if you have fedora, it will generate the config file as well...you
will just have to ensure that the lm_sensors service is running (check
with system-config-services or peek into /etc/rc?.d/)

it moves on...

PS: Sorry if this mail comes up in double...I got a mail delivery
failure notification in the first attempt...

From Toufeeq_Hussain at infosys.com  Tue Jan 11 09:45:55 2005
From: Toufeeq_Hussain at infosys.com (Toufeeq Hussain)
Date: Tue Jan 11 09:52:09 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Kernel Compilation: Modules vs Built-In
Message-ID: <557E17BE74D22143B7BE70EB60E33E99150A3294@shlmsg01.ad.infosys.com>

Hello all,

I've been having this doubt for a long time and I wanted to know what
the community feels about this.

During Kernel Compilation , we can either build modules or have the
feature compiled into the kernel.

I personally prefer having a monolithic kernel with all the features
compiled in.

I use *no modules*, I have a minimal configuration with just the bare
necesseties.
Ex: I don't have support for parallel port etc

I feel this speeds up the boot time by a few seconds.

Is this the right way to go about it, or would I be better off 
Having a modular kernel ?

Regards,
Toufeeq Hussain

From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Tue Jan 11 10:05:54 2005
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi S)
Date: Tue Jan 11 10:04:01 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] One Day One Command
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501101547400.11328-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501110955030.7486-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

On Mon, 10 Jan 2005, Bharathi S wrote:
> On Mon, 10 Jan 2005, Suraj wrote:
> > Bharathi S wrote: 
> > | $ echo -n `cat nums` -- Print the file content with-out new line char.
> > |   1 2 3

> > Technically, its the shell that interprets the `cat nums` first
> > and then supplies them to echo as arguments.  It doesn't matter if
> > we supplied the -n argument here or not.
> 
> Thanks for the correction. The '-n' option don't add the new line
> char at the end of the output string.

Yday, I gone thru bash manual to get more info abt the command
substitution.

<snip>
Command substitution allows the output of a command to replace the
command itself.  Command substitution occurs when a command is
enclosed as follows:

     $(COMMAND) or `COMMAND`

Bash performs the expansion by executing COMMAND and replacing the
command substitution with the standard output of the command, with any
trailing newlines deleted.  Embedded newlines are not deleted, but
they may be removed during word splitting.  The command substitution
`$(cat FILE)' can be replaced by the equivalent but faster `$(<
FILE)'.

</snip>

Bye :)
-- 
Bharathi S

From suraj at symonds.net  Mon Jan 10 20:57:08 2005
From: suraj at symonds.net (Suraj)
Date: Tue Jan 11 10:27:14 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Kernel Compilation: Modules vs Built-In
In-Reply-To: <557E17BE74D22143B7BE70EB60E33E99150A3294@shlmsg01.ad.infosys.com>
References: <557E17BE74D22143B7BE70EB60E33E99150A3294@shlmsg01.ad.infosys.com>
Message-ID: <20050111045708.GA21090@symonds.net>

Toufeeq Hussain wrote: 
,----
| I use *no modules*, I have  a minimal configuration with just the bare
| necesseties.
`----

Did you  say 'No' to  'Modules Support'? AFAIK debian  wasn't friendly
that way because without module support, anyway it would run depmod. I
went up and manually removed those lines from the rc script.

,----
| I feel this speeds up the boot time by a few seconds.
`----

I think it doesn't matter all  that much. But speeding up things a lot
more is  to tune up your  startup services.  Things like  "Do I really
need a dictd starting up?". "Do  I really need xdm trying to see which
is the dm and then giving it up to gdm?"

,----
| or would I be better off Having a modular kernel ?
`----

I guess. YMMV.

cheers,

  -Suraj

,-----------------[http://www.symonds.net/~suraj/]---o
| The first "American" to become popular as a carnatic vocalist was the Late
| John Higgins also called as Higgins Bhaagavathar!
`------------------------------[suraj@symonds.net]---o
From suraj at symonds.net  Mon Jan 10 21:04:07 2005
From: suraj at symonds.net (Suraj)
Date: Tue Jan 11 10:34:12 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] One Day One Command
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501110955030.7486-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501101547400.11328-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0501110955030.7486-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>
Message-ID: <20050111050407.GB21090@symonds.net>

Bharathi S wrote: 
,----
| Bash  performs the expansion  by executing  COMMAND and  replacing the
| command substitution with the standard output of the command, with any
| trailing  newlines deleted.   Embedded newlines  are not  deleted, but
| they may  be removed during word splitting.   The command substitution
| `$(cat  FILE)' can  be  replaced  by the  equivalent  but faster  `$(<
| FILE)'.
`----

exactly. The following helps demonstrate:

~ $ cat txt/foo.txt 
the quick brown
 fox jumped
 over the
 lazy dog
~ $ echo $(<txt/foo.txt)
the quick brown fox jumped over the lazy dog
~ $ echo `cat txt/foo.txt`
the quick brown fox jumped over the lazy dog
~ $ echo -n `cat txt/foo.txt `
the quick brown fox jumped over the lazy dog~ $ 

Note, in  the last  command with  'echo -n', how  the prompt  ended up
sticking close to the output. because  echo -n didn't add a newline in
the end.

cheers,

  -Suraj

-- 
,-----------------[http://www.symonds.net/~suraj/]---o
| The first "American" to become popular as a carnatic vocalist was the Late
| John Higgins also called as Higgins Bhaagavathar!
`------------------------------[suraj@symonds.net]---o
From Toufeeq_Hussain at infosys.com  Tue Jan 11 10:41:37 2005
From: Toufeeq_Hussain at infosys.com (Toufeeq Hussain)
Date: Tue Jan 11 10:44:29 2005

> ,----
> | I use *no modules*, I have  a minimal configuration with 
> just the bare 
> | necessities.
> `----
> 
> Did you  say 'No' to  'Modules Support'? AFAIK debian  wasn't 
> friendly that way because without module support, anyway it 
> would run depmod. I went up and manually removed those lines 
> from the rc script.
No, Module support is there.
Currently I'm using the CPU Freq stuff as modules.


> ,----
> | I feel this speeds up the boot time by a few seconds.
> `----
> 
> I think it doesn't matter all  that much. But speeding up 
> things a lot more is  to tune up your  startup services.  
> Things like  "Do I really need a dictd starting up?". "Do  I 
> really need xdm trying to see which is the dm and then giving 
> it up to gdm?"

Yes I've removed gdm and the other unnecessary stuff .

Toufeeq

On Tue, 11 Jan 2005 10:06:32 +0530, Asokan Pichai <pasokan@mafoi.com> wrote:

> These days me and my powerbook have come to terms. I just wish the damn
> console fonts were better

To change the font in the Terminal :

In the Terminal application, from the Font menu, select Show Fonts (OS
X 10.2.x and later) or Font Panel... .
 
In the Font window, select the family, typeface, and size you want to
use. For some families, you may also change the character width and
height.
 
To make your changes the default setting, click the Save This Setting
As My Default Font button.

Linux on the Desktop & OS X on the move :)

Quick language recommendation : since you're allergic to $var format
in Perl/PHP I heartily recommned Ruby. Complete OO... and get the
second edition of the pickaxe book from pragmatic programmers :
http://www.pragmaticprogrammer.com/

cheers
BGa
-- 
We will find a way, or we will make one - Hannibal
From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Mon Jan 10 23:41:08 2005
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Tue Jan 11 13:11:40 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Kernel Compilation: Modules vs Built-In
In-Reply-To: <557E17BE74D22143B7BE70EB60E33E99150A3294@shlmsg01.ad.infosys.com>
Message-ID: <20050111074108.26812.qmail@web50204.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

--- Toufeeq Hussain <Toufeeq_Hussain@infosys.com>
wrote:
> I personally prefer having a monolithic kernel with
> all the features
> compiled in.

I guess it would depend on the system and what you
intend to use the system for. 

If you are working on cutting-edge and
development/testing, then you will require modular
support.

If you are an end-user who simply want to use the
system, with quick boots, performance, then you might
as well have all the  modules compiled in, after
installing/configuring your hardware.

Regards,

K Shakthi

=====

K Shakthi

http://www.geocities.com/shakthimaan

From raja.mallik at moschip.com  Tue Jan 11 07:56:45 2005
From: raja.mallik at moschip.com (Raja Mallik)
Date: Tue Jan 11 13:26:47 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Kernel struct info
In-Reply-To: <1105428686.12083.93.camel@mazda>
References: <1ab801c4f798$134587b0$28c8a8c0@benson>
	<1105428686.12083.93.camel@mazda>
Message-ID: <1105430328.12083.104.camel@mazda>

Hi all, 

Kernel maintains a structure that can be operate by READ/WRITE
operations by user application.

For eg : SET1[5] = {10, 11,12,13,14,}
         SET2[5] = { 0, 1,  2, 3, 4}

         GET1[5] = {21, 22, 23, 24, 25};
         GET2[5] = {0,  1, 2, 3, 4};

1)User will pass any of the GET2 array to get the values on the
structure.(device_read)
2)user will pass any of the SET2 array to set the values on the
structure.( device_write)

I am looking for a mechanism as to how to store these GET1 and SET1 values in kernel modules.
Is there any standard structure that can used? kindly shoot your
reference!

Thanks
Raja Mallik

On Mon, 10 Jan 2005 21:18:00 +0530, Suresh Ramasubramanian
<linux@frodo.hserus.net> wrote:
> Suraj wrote:
> > Rohit Baisakhiya wrote:
> > ,----
> > | if it  reads value 0 it  will connect the  master db server and  if it
> > | gets value 1 it will connect slave server.
> > `----
> >
> > What you  should rather do  is to run  a local nameserver that  does a
> > round-robin rotation for your mysql server.
> 
> That wont help failover which is what he wants to implement I guess.
> It is basically overkill if all he has are two or three mysql servers -
> better use them as a single cluster and cache mysql connections, using
> sqlrelay or other mysql clustering app.
> 
For fail support only we are having conditions in the php code itself.
The webserver will ping the master mysql database every 10 or 15
seconds and will connect to the database whose value the ping results
it gets from the script.

This has solved our fail-over problem !! also we are not using any
kind of failover supporting app !!
  

Cheers !!

> 


-- 
Regards,
Rohit Baisakhiya
KiranInfotech

From sbharathi at midascomm.com  Tue Jan 11 17:35:48 2005
From: sbharathi at midascomm.com (Bharathi S)
Date: Tue Jan 11 17:33:54 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] One Day One Command
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501071738320.5543-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501111648240.29262-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

One Day One Command :-
---------------------

grep -- (Global Regular Expression Print) 
         Print lines matching a pattern

Summary: 
`grep' searches the input files for lines containing a match to a
given pattern list. Grep has a no .of useful options and support 
regular expressions.

Examples:

$ grep -i bharathi Midas.txt -- Print the lines which contains string 
                                "bharathi" in the Midas.txt file

$ grep -v bharathi ILUGC.txt -- Print the line which is not the 
                                string "bharathi"

$ grep "^A" file -- Prints the line starting with A.

$ grep "Z$" file -- Prints the line with ending letter Z.

$ grep -c "Linux"  file -- Prints count of match. 

$ grep '^[012]' file -- Prints the line starting with 0/1/2

Read : info grep / egrep / fgrep

Bye :)
-- 
Bharathi S

On Tue, 2005-01-11 at 06:50 +0530, Joe Steeve wrote:
> Suresh Ramasubramanian <linux@frodo.hserus.net> writes:
> > i've been using this acer for a while now and it is pretty good.
> 
> How much did you buy it for?


I have a Wipro LittleGenius CP 15, which has got almost the same
features. Cost me 66k in India. This was in Aug 2004.
--------------------------------------------
Features that worked "out of the box" (not even lspci/modprobe stuff)
with ubuntu warty.

ipw2100, cpufreq, AC'97 sound, 855GM graphics, synaptic touchpad
--------------------------------------------
Things I had to fiddle with to get it to work:

National Semiconductor based irda controller (nsc-ircc)

--------------------------------------------
Things I have not tested: firewire port
--------------------------------------------

Took me less than an hour to get the whole setup working. When I had
gentoo, I had to emerge packages and play with the ipw2100
firmware/driver a bit and I had to configure irda manually then too.

I'm satisfied with this laptop.

Regards,
arv

> READ/WRITE
> operations by user application.

elements? Will the size of the array grow? Are the
values a constant? What is the scope of the structure?

From andyetitmoves at gmail.com  Wed Jan 12 10:45:21 2005
From: andyetitmoves at gmail.com (Ramkumar R)
Date: Wed Jan 12 10:45:28 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Kernel Compilation: Modules vs Built-In
In-Reply-To: <20050111074108.26812.qmail@web50204.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <557E17BE74D22143B7BE70EB60E33E99150A3294@shlmsg01.ad.infosys.com>
	<20050111074108.26812.qmail@web50204.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <9a9bfc17050111211557b58005@mail.gmail.com>

distros use modules as they need to cater a wide range of hardware -
it just isn't possible to compile in everything...for a custom
installation though, I guess compiling in things is better - faster,
saves some space required for the module as well (that's a microscopic
amt though...) - come on, there is no point in having a reiserfs
module with reiserfs on your hard disk. it is anyway needed right from
bootup to shutdown - I generally have modules for those which I may
not use that frequently, or for those which I may not need now, but
may require it some time in the future - in fact, even for the second
case, it isn't that difficult to do a recompile anyway...

it moves on...

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Tue Jan 11 23:36:58 2005

Date: Wed Jan 12 13:07:06 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Kernel struct info
In-Reply-To: <1105506673.1106.4.camel@mazda>
Message-ID: <20050112073658.67225.qmail@web50206.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

--- Raja Mallik <raja.mallik@moschip.com> wrote:
> Yes, for the time being..it has on 5 elements. They
> are int type at this
> moment.
 
You can use ioctl command to communicate with your
driver. 

User-space (application):
int ioctl(int fd, int cmd, ...);

Kernel-space (driver):
int (*ioctl) (struct inode *inode, struct file *filp,
         unsigned int cmd, unsigned long arg);

Since you want to get only one value, you can use:

__put_user(datum, ptr)

Check this link:
http://www.xml.com/ldd/chapter/book/ch05.html#t1

You might also want to check the scull example from
here:

http://examples.oreilly.com/linuxdrive2/

Regards,

K Shakthi

=====
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
K Shakthi
Specsoft (Hexaware Technologies), ASIC Design Center
http://www.geocities.com/shakthimaan
--------------------------------------------------------------------------


	
		
__________________________________ 
Do you Yahoo!? 
Yahoo! Mail - You care about security. So do we. 
http://promotions.yahoo.com/new_mail
From carti at chi.spunge.org  Wed Jan 12 03:25:11 2005
From: carti at chi.spunge.org (carti)
Date: Wed Jan 12 14:54:23 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] crontab like feature
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0501120312090.12706@chi.spunge.org>

Hi,

I have an user account in a remote linux
server. I want to run a script once in 45 mins.
For this, I dont want to put in the login script
or write a program which runs continuously(or sleeps)
and executes the script once in 45 mins.

I dont have access(rights) to put in "crontab".
Also, I dont want to use "at" command because I dont want
to login and execute the script. But the server will be
running continuously.

Is there any way to do the above?.

OR

Is there any way to automatically telnet to a linux
server(with username and passwd) and executes the script
(put in login script) and logouts automatically.

I have heard of automated ftping, but not automated
telnetting.. any idea(s)?

Thaks and regards,
carti
From raja.mallik at moschip.com  Wed Jan 12 10:11:24 2005
From: raja.mallik at moschip.com (Raja Mallik)
Date: Wed Jan 12 15:41:26 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Kernel struct info
In-Reply-To: <20050112073658.67225.qmail@web50206.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20050112073658.67225.qmail@web50206.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1105524782.1106.173.camel@mazda>



Kernel module maintains a structure that can be operate by READ/WRITE
operations by user application.

For eg : SETTINGS[5] = {10, 11,12,13,14,}
         

User will defined IOCTLs for this map is defined as:

For write to device: ( Pass an index number and value to write)

1) IOCTL_SET1_MSG
2) IOCTL_SET2_MSG
3) IOCTL_SET3_MSG
4) IOCTL_SET4_MSG
5) IOCTL_SET5_MSG

And for reading from device: ( Pass an index number and get the value
set for the device)

1) IOCTL_GET1_MSG
2) IOCTL_GET2_MSG
3) IOCTL_GET3_MSG
4) IOCTL_GET4_MSG
5) IOCTL_GET5_MSG

I have defined 

static int Settings[5]={10, 12, 13, 14, 15}

When I call this in device_ioctl() in kernel module , I define all IOCTL
defined above in a switch(cmd_num) 

what I want to do is for 

case IOCTL_SET1_MSG:
     
        { 

          Here I want to set the global settings as defined above:
Settings[5] array.

}

I have IOCTL defined as:

#defined IOCTL_SET1_MSG --IOR( _IOR(DEVICE_MAJOR_NUM, 0, char *) 


When the user application calls with IOCTL_SET1_MSG, its passes a number
0 to the node, kernel should set 1st value of Settings[5]={10. 11, 12,
13, 14} i.e 10, and 11 for 1 and so on..

I am little stuck here.. 

Thanks
Raja

carti wrote: 
,----
| Is  there any  way  to  automatically telnet  to  a linux  server(with
| username and passwd) and executes the script (put in login script) and
| logouts automatically.
`----

*ugh*  telnet? anyway,  be it  telnet or  ssh, you  can use  an expect
script to do it. search for  'expect script ssh' and you will find out
how to do it. Put the script in a cron job on your local box.

  -suraj

From suraj at symonds.net  Wed Jan 12 02:27:34 2005
From: suraj at symonds.net (Suraj)
Date: Wed Jan 12 15:57:41 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] crontab like feature
In-Reply-To: <20050112101857.GA2273@symonds.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0501120312090.12706@chi.spunge.org>
	<20050112101857.GA2273@symonds.net>
Message-ID: <20050112102734.GA3126@symonds.net>

Suraj wrote: 
,----
| *ugh*  telnet? anyway,  be it  telnet or  ssh, you  can use  an expect
| script to do it. search for  'expect script ssh' and you will find out
| how to do it. Put the script in a cron job on your local box.
`----

Or even plain ssh like this in your local crontab:

10 * * * * ssh remote.host 'command here'

With the  above you could have  a 'passphraseless' ssh  key. But thats
not a good  thing to do. If you  dont care, you can. Or if  you give a
damn about doing it securely you could as well use 'rsh'. man rsh.

cheers,

  -Suraj

,-----------------[http://www.symonds.net/~suraj/]---o
| MS Subbulakshmi was the first Carnatic musician to perform at the UN
| .
`------------------------------[suraj@symonds.net]---o

Put a crontab in your desktop linux box which ssh's to the remote 
machine once every 45 minutes and executes the script there .. you can 
run apps / scripts remotely using ssh
From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Wed Jan 12 18:51:25 2005
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi S)
Date: Wed Jan 12 18:49:19 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] One Day One Command
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501111648240.29262-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501121825020.9506-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

One Day One Command :-
---------------------

cat -- CATenate files & print on the STDOUT

Summary: 

>From Jargon File: Catenate is an obscure word meaning "to connect 
in a series", which is what the "cat" command does to one or more 
files.

Cat will conCATenate the FILE(s) / STDIN to STDOUT. 

Examples:

$ cat MyFile  -- Dump the file to STDOUT

$ cat File1 File2 File3 -- Dump File1, File2  & File3

$ cat -b File -- Print the File with Number for Non blank lines

$ cat -s File -- Squeeze multiple blank lines to single.

$ cat -A File -- Show the Non-Printable Chars also

$ cat > File -- Concat the STDIN to STDOUT & FILE.

Read: info cat

Bye :)
-- 
Bharathi S

From kums at gmx.net  Wed Jan 12 19:12:57 2005
From: kums at gmx.net (Kumaraguru)
Date: Wed Jan 12 19:13:24 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] crontab like feature
References: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0501120312090.12706@chi.spunge.org>
Message-ID: <001501c4f8ac$a01ec150$0d07a8c0@kums>

Hi,

If your own machine runs 24x7 to run the remote script
every hour then that's fine. In case you don't have
such a setup there's another idea (no guarantees though).

Does the remote machine run a web server?
If so, you can host a cgi script that does all your stuff.
Then signup for some *free* site status probing service like
http://www.siteprobe.com/ to pull your cgi script every hour.

[It looks like siteprobe.com will only check your url every
1 hour and you will have to pay if you want to check more
often. You can find similar services if you search.]

Regards
Kumaraguru

From kums at gmx.net  Wed Jan 12 20:44:30 2005
From: kums at gmx.net (Kumaraguru)
Date: Wed Jan 12 20:44:57 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] crontab like feature
References: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0501120312090.12706@chi.spunge.org><001501c4f8ac$a01ec150$0d07a8c0@kums>
	<20050112140022.GB21492@symonds.net>
Message-ID: <000a01c4f8b9$6a236800$0d07a8c0@kums>

Hi,

> cgi!? Like you want to make it easier to the expl0iter?

Follow the precautions you would normally have to for
such scripts. Make sure your script is fairly hard
to crack. Beyond that, all I could say.. if somebody
is *determined* to break into yours it's just a matter
of time before they actually do it.

Hosting a cgi script doesn't mean you are going to
announce that to the entire world anyway. Make it
accessible only to the probing server. IMHO, The
weakest point may not necessarily be a cgi script
but your own local machine. Somebody gaining access
to your machine can get the login details of your
remote accounts and could expl0it them as easily.

Anyway, I am asking out of curiosity..
Is their such thing as a non-exploitable solution?


Regards
Kumaraguru


> Kumaraguru wrote:
> ,----
> | Does the remote machine  run a web server?  If so, you  can host a
cgi
> | script that  does all  your stuff.
> `----
>
> cgi!? Like you want to make it easier to the expl0iter?
>
> cheers,
>
>   -Suraj
>

by all. It gave me lot of insight in achieving the
crontab like feature by different means.

On digging around the system and man pages for some
more time, I found that crontab allows user(non root) also
to add entries in user specific crontab.

The crontab version and the Linux version I provide
herewith.

Linux 2.2.25
and
(Cron version -- $Id: crontab.c,v 2.13 1994/01/17 03:20:37 vixie Exp $)

In-Reply-To: <dc538c3f05011300016016f680@mail.gmail.com>

Message-ID: <41E65479.60006@gmail.com>

Read a brief review @

http://sudhir-lp.blogspot.com/2005/01/bsnl-announces-broadband-tarrif.html

on how the present pricing policy is skewed in favor the business user
rather than home user. 10GB of transfer for a home user is more
expensive than 10GB of transfer for a corporate user.

Of course, till June, it appears to be a free-for-all :)

Cheers,
Sudhir.P

From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Thu Jan 13 17:21:47 2005
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi S)
Date: Thu Jan 13 17:19:17 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] One Day One Command
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501121825020.9506-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501131655440.22475-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

One Day One Command :-
---------------------

watch - Periodically run and show the output of a program

Summary:

Watch runs command repeatedly, displaying its output This allows 
you to monitor the program output change over time.

Examples :-

$ watch ls -- Every 2sec(default time) 'ls' is executed and output 
              is showed on the screen.

$ watch -n 6 who -- Every 6Sec 'who' run and list the current users

$ watch -d date -- Highlight the difference b/w successive updates

Press Ctrl+C to stop the Watch Command.

Read: man watch

Wish you happy Pongal & Bye :)
-- 
Bharathi S

From suraj at symonds.net  Thu Jan 13 10:37:11 2005
From: suraj at symonds.net (Suraj)
Date: Fri Jan 14 00:07:21 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Bharathi's "One Day One Command" on LiveJournal
Message-ID: <20050113183711.GA4185@symonds.net>

hello,

Here is  my part in helping  to make Bharathi's "One  Day One Command"
mails into something accessible:

I went  to the archives  and downloaded the  gzip" and parsed  out the
"One Day One Command" Mails. Thanks  to bharathi for keeping them in a
consistent format.  It turned out that he has sent only about 5 so far
:) I  could have as  well opened the  archive by hand and  copy pasted
them into files. :)

Then it occured  to me that having an LJ community  for ILUGC would be
useful in more  than one ways. Not just in getting  these "One Day One
Command" onto LJ and being able to  get them in RSS but also that many
people have livejournal accounts and  they post something or the other
technical. They might as well post in the ilugc lj community as well.

Here is the thing so far:

http://www.livejournal.com/community/ilugc/

My stupidity, I should have somehow "intelligently" appended something
to  the  subject. The  RSS  feed  titles will  not  make  sense as  of
now. Whoever wants to be moderator can probably edit it by hand.

for the future:

either Bharathi can post to this LJ community as and when he sends out
a mail (not preferable - extra work for bharathi. probably lesser work
than updating a twiki, but its still requires effort!)

or

one of  us who knows  for sure that  we never miss out  fetching ilugc
emails can  setup a  procmail filter to  extract bharathi's  mails and
post them  to LJ. I  used http://sourceforge.net/projects/ljclive/ for
posting the entries so far but  its *sloooow* even on a machine with a
decent pipe (symonds.net). Solutions? Volunteers?

cheers,

  -Suraj

-- 
,-----------------[http://www.symonds.net/~suraj/]---o
| Thyagaraja is the youngest of the trinity
`------------------------------[suraj@symonds.net]---o

From getmailsp at gmail.com  Fri Jan 14 11:27:31 2005
From: getmailsp at gmail.com (Sudhir Parasuram)
Date: Fri Jan 14 11:27:43 2005
Subject: [Way OT] Livejournal Vs Blogger [was Re: [Ilugc] Bharathi's "One
	Day One Command" on LiveJournal]
In-Reply-To: <20050113183711.GA4185@symonds.net>
References: <20050113183711.GA4185@symonds.net>
Message-ID: <41E75F4B.70402@gmail.com>

Suraj wrote:
> hello,
> [...]
> Here is the thing so far:
> 
> http://www.livejournal.com/community/ilugc/

My apologies for pulling this offtopic. However, in the interest of an
increasing number of people who are blogging and are potential
candidates, I was wondering if the question might make some sense here
and there could be some interesting answers.

Does anyone know what are the major advantages/disadvantages of 
Livejournal.com over Blogger.com ?

I presently have a blog (http://sudhir-lp.blogspot.com) at Blogger.com
account and am able to post to it via tools like w.bloggar. It also
allows post via email option (which I can use for automated script
posts), though it's not necessarily the most secure option. And it also
allows comments to be emailed to the owner of the blog, not to mention
having an option to email those comments also to a mailing-list. And it
provides ATOM feeds. There may be other things which I haven't covered,
but there are most of the things that I find useful.

Things that it lacks (IMO) is the ability to categorize, the ability to
comment backtrack.

Anyone have anything useful to add the Blogger.com side or point me to 
things that are beautiful in Livejournal.com ?

Cheers,
Sudhir.P

> [...]

-- 
http://sudhir-lp.blogspot.com

Sudhir Parasuram wrote:

> Anyone have anything useful to add the Blogger.com side or point me to 
> things that are beautiful in Livejournal.com ?
>
I wouldn't call it 'beautiful', but you can have 'user pics' in LJ. So 
if you comment/blog, a stamp-size pic shows up on the left. And I can 
set current 'moods'. And I use LogJam(which is pretty feature-rich) to 
blog directly from my debian box.

-VK.

Hi friends,
things didnt work with Mandrake 10.0  official since the acpi
directory is empty,
I installed FC3 x86-64 and the problem persists. However, system
appears less hot when i touch the case (may be thats my perception).
[root@localhost varun]# ls -lR /proc/acpi/
/proc/acpi/:
total 0
dr-xr-xr-x  2 root root 0 Jan 14 22:47 ac_adapter
<snip>
/proc/acpi/ac_adapter:
total 0

/proc/acpi/battery:
total 0

/proc/acpi/button:
total 0
dr-xr-xr-x  3 root root 0 Jan 14 22:47 power
dr-xr-xr-x  3 root root 0 Jan 14 22:47 sleep

/proc/acpi/button/power:
total 0
dr-xr-xr-x  2 root root 0 Jan 14 22:47 PWRF

/proc/acpi/button/power/PWRF:
total 0
-r--r--r--  1 root root 0 Jan 14 22:47 info

/proc/acpi/button/sleep:
total 0
dr-xr-xr-x  2 root root 0 Jan 14 22:47 SLPB

/proc/acpi/button/sleep/SLPB:
total 0
-r--r--r--  1 root root 0 Jan 14 22:47 info

/proc/acpi/embedded_controller:
total 0

/proc/acpi/fan: <- see nothing here
total 0

/proc/acpi/power_resource:
total 0

/proc/acpi/processor:
total 0
dr-xr-xr-x  2 root root 0 Jan 14 22:47 CPU1

/proc/acpi/processor/CPU1: <- these 4 files are not helping either
total 0
-r--r--r--  1 root root 0 Jan 14 22:47 info
-rw-r--r--  1 root root 0 Jan 14 22:47 limit
-r--r--r--  1 root root 0 Jan 14 22:47 power
-rw-r--r--  1 root root 0 Jan 14 22:47 throttling
[root@localhost varun]# cat /proc/acpi/processor/CPU1/limit
<not supported>
[root@localhost varun]# cat /proc/acpi/processor/CPU1/info
processor id:            0
acpi id:                 1
bus mastering control:   no
power management:        no
throttling control:      no
limit interface:         no
[root@localhost varun]# cat /proc/acpi/processor/CPU1/power
active state:            C1
default state:           C1
bus master activity:     00000000
states:
   *C1:                  promotion[--] demotion[--] latency[000] usage[00000000]
    C2:                  <not supported>
    C3:                  <not supported>
[root@localhost varun]# cat /proc/acpi/processor/CPU1/throttling
<not supported>
[root@localhost varun]#

Why is this acpi dir empty?

BTW i have an ASUS MB (my first mail has all those details ).
lm_sensors says it dint find any sensors
gkrellm cannot configure temp,fan and voltage (i guess bcoz of empty acpi dir)
any idea
-Varun

Varun Soundararajan wrote:
> /proc/acpi/:
> total 0
> dr-xr-xr-x  2 root root 0 Jan 14 22:47 ac_adapter
> <snip>

Did you modprobe all these -

/sbin/modprobe ac
/sbin/modprobe battery
/sbin/modprobe processor
/sbin/modprobe button
/sbin/modprobe fan
/sbin/modprobe thermal

>
>I have a Wipro LittleGenius CP 15, which has got almost the same
>features. Cost me 66k in India. This was in Aug 2004.
>--------------------------------------------
>Features that worked "out of the box" (not even lspci/modprobe stuff)
>with ubuntu warty.
>
>ipw2100, cpufreq, AC'97 sound, 855GM graphics, synaptic touchpad
>--------------------------------------------
>Things I had to fiddle with to get it to work:
>
>National Semiconductor based irda controller (nsc-ircc)
>
>--------------------------------------------
>Things I have not tested: firewire port
>--------------------------------------------
>
>Took me less than an hour to get the whole setup working. When I had
>gentoo, I had to emerge packages and play with the ipw2100
>firmware/driver a bit and I had to configure irda manually then too.
>
>I'm satisfied with this laptop.
>
>Regards,
>arv

>--- Raja Mallik <raja.mallik@moschip.com> wrote:
>  
>
>>Kernel maintains a structure that can be operate by
>>READ/WRITE
>>operations by user application.
>>For eg : SET1[5] = {10, 11,12,13,14,}
>>         SET2[5] = { 0, 1,  2, 3, 4}
>>
>>         GET1[5] = {21, 22, 23, 24, 25};
>>         GET2[5] = {0,  1, 2, 3, 4};
>>    
>>
>
>Will it be only 5 elements? What type are these
>elements? Will the size of the array grow? Are the
>values a constant? What is the scope of the structure?

>Message: 7
>Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 10:45:21 +0530
>From: Ramkumar R <andyetitmoves@gmail.com>
>Subject: Re: [Ilugc] Kernel Compilation: Modules vs Built-In
>To: Chennai Linux User's Group <ilugc@ae.iitm.ac.in>
>Message-ID: <9a9bfc17050111211557b58005@mail.gmail.com>
>Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
>
>distros use modules as they need to cater a wide range of hardware -
>it just isn't possible to compile in everything...for a custom
>installation though, I guess compiling in things is better - faster,
>saves some space required for the module as well (that's a microscopic
>amt though...) - come on, there is no point in having a reiserfs
>module with reiserfs on your hard disk. it is anyway needed right from
>bootup to shutdown - I generally have modules for those which I may
>not use that frequently, or for those which I may not need now, but
>may require it some time in the future - in fact, even for the second
>case, it isn't that difficult to do a recompile anyway...
>
>it moves on...
>
>On Mon, 10 Jan 2005 23:41:08 -0800 (PST), Shakthi Kannan
><cyborg4k@yahoo.com> wrote:
>  
>
>>Hi,
>>
>>--- Toufeeq Hussain <Toufeeq_Hussain@infosys.com>
>>wrote:
>>    
>>
>>>I personally prefer having a monolithic kernel with
>>>all the features
>>>compiled in.
>>>      
>>>
>>I guess it would depend on the system and what you
>>intend to use the system for.
>>
>>If you are working on cutting-edge and
>>development/testing, then you will require modular
>>support.
>>
>>If you are an end-user who simply want to use the
>>system, with quick boots, performance, then you might
>>as well have all the  modules compiled in, after
>>installing/configuring your hardware.
>>
>>Regards,
>>
>>K Shakthi
>>

From topa_007 at yahoo.com  Sun Jan 16 04:31:30 2005

From kums at gmx.net  Sun Jan 16 18:14:40 2005
From: kums at gmx.net (Kumaraguru)
Date: Sun Jan 16 18:15:01 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] 100 % FOSS -- an illusion?
References: <20050116123130.84899.qmail@web30202.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <000901c4fbc9$25afe820$0d07a8c0@kums>

Hi,

Afaik, WMV ASF and MP3 codecs certainly cannot be
deemed free. VirtualDub project was asked to drop
support for ASF by microsoft
http://www.advogato.org/article/101.html
And I believe the same applies for WMV.

MP3 codecs need a licence from Thomson and Fraunhofer
and it never was a free format.
http://www.mediachance.com/mp3/


Regards
Kumaraguru

> HI,
> 
> http://www.gnu.org/philosophy/java-trap.html
> This article on gnu.org, makes me raise some
> questions..
> 
> I use .MOV , .WMV, .ASF and .MP3 codecs to play
> multimedia files on xine or mplayer.
> 
> Do these codecs qualify as F/OS Software ?
> Can these codecs be used in Industry for Professional
> use without any Licensing Issues ?
> 
> Regards,
> Toufeeq Hussain

From fred at bytesforall.org  Mon Jan 17 00:20:57 2005
From: fred at bytesforall.org (Frederick Noronha (FN))
Date: Mon Jan 17 00:15:40 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] FreeSoftwaremagazine.com
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0501170020460.866@news.goa.bytesforall.org>

Issue 1 Volume 1 of this new magazine has just hit the (cyber)stands. And, 
don't be too surprised, you're free to download a copy too of this 78-page 
publication. Some of the articles in the first issue:

 	o File formats; format wars (Marco Fioretti)
 	  File formats: the past, the present, a possible future

 	o XML: The answer to everything? (Kay Ethier, Scott Abel)
 	  This article weighs the pros and cons of XML for some
 	  applciations (publishing) and explores why it is the
  	  best possible solution for many programming and
 	  publishing needs.

 	o Free file formats and the future of intellectual
   	  freedom (Terry Hancock)
 	  Information as property may be served by closed
 	  file formats, but the freedom of information
 	  requires free formats.

 	o Creating the Free Software Magazine (Tony Mobily)
 	  A long path that takes us to the very beginning
 	  of this project.

 	o Mac OS X: Welcome to the jungle -- a look inside the
 	  Mac OS X software ecology (Chris J Karr)

 	o The magic of live CDs (Harish Pillay)
 	  What are live CDs, and how do they work?

 	o Every engineer's checklist for justifying
 	  Free Software. It's not just about 'no licence fees'
 	  (Malcolm D Spence)

 	o Smarter password management (John Locke)
 	  How to handle your passwords without getting lost

 	o The content tail wags the IT dog (Daniel James)
  	  Without hardware and software, there would be
 	  nothing for digital media to be created on, or used
 	  with. And yet the content industry attempts to tell
 	  the far larger IT industry what it can and cannot do.

 	o Motivation and value of free resources. Wikipedia
 	  and Planetmath show the way (Aaron E Klemm)

 	o It's all about freedom (Christian Einfeldt)
 	  Freedom is free software's competitive advantage.

 	o The Commons (Dave M Berry)
 	  The Commons as an Idea -- Ideas as a Commons

 	o Let's not forget our roots (Free Software is not
 	  just about cost or stability; it's a movement that
 	  mustn't forget the principles which made it possible)
 	  Tom Chance.

A PLANT NEEDS WATER TO GROW! Free Software Magazine -- by subscribing you 
will be supporting a magazine which believes in Free Software. All our 
articles are released under the GNU free documentation license, enhancing 
existing information on Free Software.

From andyetitmoves at gmail.com  Mon Jan 17 10:45:02 2005
From: andyetitmoves at gmail.com (Ramkumar R)
Date: Mon Jan 17 10:45:12 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Kernel Compilation: Modules vs Built-In
In-Reply-To: <e8fef13b050113132959ff99a1@mail.gmail.com>
References: <557E17BE74D22143B7BE70EB60E33E99150A3294@shlmsg01.ad.infosys.com>
	<20050111074108.26812.qmail@web50204.mail.yahoo.com>
	<9a9bfc17050111211557b58005@mail.gmail.com>
	<e8fef13b050113132959ff99a1@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <9a9bfc17050116211538abd539@mail.gmail.com>

> This is very wrong perception for modular kernel. Though Linux kernel
> is monolithic kernel, but it has few features of microkernel and so as
> modularity.

I never denied that (I guess you meant linux has _a_ few features of a
microkernel, the meaning isn't quite the same otherwise :)....My point
is that this run-time modularity is needed much for distros - as a
single user, you know most of your requirements beforehand, and hence
can use the performance compile time selection offers.

> Seems you are note very clear with ( whether all the modules can
> compile or not with kernel ), but defenitely, compiling all the module
> in kernel will make the kernel faster, and also, it will effect the
> size of the kernel and also it requires more amount of resources.
> 

NO...your argument is valid only when you don't use all the modules -
as is the case with a distro...if that's not the case, it is the other
way round, though only by a small measure.
Also, I prefer compiling modules you know will be used always, not
*all* modules...

> Let me point out very significat point here. Linux does not require
> reiserfs/ext3/ext2 to bootup. It explodes the kernel into ram and then
> depending on whether fs is modular or inbuilt in kernel, get loaded
> and root file system get mounted on that and the reason you can see
> that fs loaded as module and / mounted on same fs. Actually this is
> break through for Linux Kernel, which was implemented for almost all
> the devices.
> 

Well, again I never said that you can't do it...I know about initrd
and its benefits...
I quote myself -

> amt though...) - come on, there is no point in having a reiserfs
> module with reiserfs on your hard disk. it is anyway needed right from
> bootup to shutdown

Are you going to umount the root partition? No. So that module is
going to be referenced throughout. Now, in such a case a module
doesn't offer any advantage...On the other hand, take the floppy
driver - it makes sense to use it as a module if you don't use the
floppy too often. Gets loaded only when you actually use the floppy
and then can be removed after you finish using it.

Do remember that initrd does have its overhead - so, why use it when
not required?

it moves on...

> Regards,
> Animesh.
> 
> > not use that frequently, or for those which I may not need now, but
> > may require it some time in the future - in fact, even for the second
> > case, it isn't that difficult to do a recompile anyway...
> 


-- 
If you want to travel around the world and be invited to speak at a lot
of different places, _just_ write a Unix operating system.
                                                       - Linus Torvalds

otherwise....

my prev. mail) - this is independent of ACPI...

Message-ID: <41EB97EC.506@vibromech.com>

Dear All,

I am Padmanaban, working in Vibromech Engineers & Services Ltd. Perungudi,
We had already installed RH9 in servers & FC2 in Desktops. We are now 
reviewing
the various distros of linux. Can any one suggest the best distributions 
for Mail server,
File server & Desktops seperately.

I can brief you what runs on Desktops and Servers:

*Desktops*
1. Word processing
2. Spreadsheets
3. Email
4. Web browsing
5. Accounting

The average user has
a> A very limited familiarity with the operating system,
b> Experience with windows and MS applications and expects the same look 
and feel.
c> expects no degradation in speed and apparent performance

*Engineering desktop *
1. Word processing
2. Spreadsheets
2. Email
3. Web browsing
4. Pro/Engineer
5. Simulation and analysis

The average user has
a> Some familiarity with the operating system,
b> Experience with windows and MS applications, but no issues with 
learning a new OS

*Mail Server*
1. Qmail (POP) (Planning to go for IMAP)
2. Squid
3. Sendmail
4. Sophos antivirus

*File Server*
1. Samba (Planned to Run NFS)
2. Apache (Planned to Run PHP)


Thks / Rgds
R.Padmanaban.
Vibromech Engineers & Services Ltd.
Perungudi, Ch - 96.

From apsivam at gmail.com  Mon Jan 17 11:44:26 2005
From: apsivam at gmail.com (=?utf-8?b?U2l2YW5hbmRoYW4s?= P.)

Subject: [Ilugc] Re: Modem Configuration in Fedora core3

Nowadays Fedora comes with lot of bugs. FC3 uses 'udev' a new feture that
dynamically manage /dev/ directory. I suspect this could cause trouble for you.
I myself a long time Fedora user and a RHCE, but I personally suggest you to
choose some other distro if you are not a hacker by yourself.

Cheers,

--Sivam

From vijairaj_sr at rediffmail.com  Mon Jan 17 18:01:38 2005

Sivanandhan wrote:
> Nowadays Fedora comes with lot of bugs. 

Is it? If you have found any, please make it a 
point to send a report to the developers.

> FC3 uses 'udev' a new feture that dynamically manage /dev/ directory.
 > I suspect this could cause trouble for you.

There had been enough debates on adopting udev 
or not. according to Gregs paper 
"http://www.kroah.com/linux/talks/ols_2003_udev_paper/Reprint-Kroah-Hartman-OLS2003.pdf" 
  udev seems to be the need of tomorrow. So, 
instead of shying away from it, i'd rather 
recommend you to find out the real problem and 
fix them.

--
Regards,
R. Vijairaj

On Mon, 17 Jan 2005 16:17:05 +0530, Animesh Singh <animeshs@gmail.com> wrote:
> Afternoon Ramkumar,
> 
> > I never denied that (I guess you meant linux has _a_ few features of a
> > microkernel, the meaning isn't quite the same otherwise :)....My point
> > is that this run-time modularity is needed much for distros - as a
> <snip>
> We talked about linux kernel ( not distro), which is from one palce.
> Though in few case like RH backported.
> > single user, you know most of your requirements beforehand, and hence
> > can use the performance compile time selection offers.
> <snip>
> Does not make any sense. ( single user ? )
> >
> > > Seems you are note very clear with ( whether all the modules can
> > > compile or not with kernel ), but defenitely, compiling all the module
> > > in kernel will make the kernel faster, and also, it will effect the
> > > size of the kernel and also it requires more amount of resources.
> > >
> >
> > NO...your argument is valid only when you don't use all the modules -
> > as is the case with a distro...if that's not the case, it is the other
> > way round, though only by a small measure.
> <snip>
> Well, a bit of performance in kernel, counts a lot.
> > Also, I prefer compiling modules you know will be used always, not
> > *all* modules...
> <snip>
> That's your idea. I haev put the points in general and applicable to all.
> >
> > > Let me point out very significat point here. Linux does not require
> > > reiserfs/ext3/ext2 to bootup. It explodes the kernel into ram and then
> > > depending on whether fs is modular or inbuilt in kernel, get loaded
> > > and root file system get mounted on that and the reason you can see
> > > that fs loaded as module and / mounted on same fs. Actually this is
> > > break through for Linux Kernel, which was implemented for almost all
> > > the devices.
> > >
> >
> > Well, again I never said that you can't do it...I know about initrd
> > and its benefits...
> > I quote myself -
> >
> > > amt though...) - come on, there is no point in having a reiserfs
> > > module with reiserfs on your hard disk. it is anyway needed right from
> > > bootup to shutdown
> <snip>
> This is what is totally wrong.
> What is reiserfs module ? and what is reiserfs on disk ? Does this
> mean two things.
> I would stongly recommened you to read the internals of Linux Booting.
> 
> What I have to say is that. Linux when boots up, it does not require
> reiserfs. and to support my point technically I gave you an
> explanation that, "lsmod might list your filesystem as loadable
> module. ( reiserfs can be one of the module. ) But the question is how
> can reiserfs can be loaded as module when root fs is using same.
> 
> My dear friend, answer to this is what I gave you. Linux does nto
> require reiserfs to bootup,  'cause while booting it uses ram to
> explode the kernel and later on ( once the reiserfs filesystem gets
> loaded ( it can be modular/ built in module ) ), root fs gets
> remounted on same.
> 
> Regards,
> Animesh.
>

From vijairaj_sr at rediffmail.com  Mon Jan 17 20:34:35 2005
From: vijairaj_sr at rediffmail.com (Vijairaj  R)
Date: Tue Jan 18 02:04:35 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Take a Break - Try BSD!
Message-ID: <20050117203551.21295.qmail@webmail25.rediffmail.com>

Dear peers!
	If it doesn't trouble you let me share my *first* experience with one of the best unix Flavours - FreeBSD. A few months before, I received a copy of FreeBSD-5.2.1 along with a magazine. I was really happy to see the cute little Beastie - FreeBSD mascot. There were two iso-images (1 installation + 1 rescue) in a DVD. I loop mounted the image on my linux box and went through the installation guide. This was my first surprise - There were around 10 types of installation listed. There was an option to install from a primary DOS partition, which was the only option applicable for my box (I didn't wanna burn the images on a CD). But to my dismay the 1GB partition was not enough size. Then suddenly had a flash, yes my favourite toy qemu should be of some use, I thought. Took a quick backup of mbrs & dbrs and launched qemu (qemu -hda /dev/sda -cdrom <disk1.iso> -boot d). The installer was very nice and fast. It seems that FreeBSD can be installed only on a primary partition; luckily I had room for two primary partitions. FreeBSD is really nice here - It slices a single partition in to many peaces and each of the slice acts like a separate partition. It also suggested the aprox space required for each partition. I happily formatted /dev/ad4s4[a-g] with ufs(native filesystem) and flagged off to start installation. Installation was over in 15 mins, further answering the installer took around 5 mins. Chose to have the loader on the dbr and rebooted to load the FreeBSD kernel for the first time. I was really really happy - it happily detected all my hardware (80GB SATA hdd, floppy driver, ide-dvd, ps/2 mouse/keyboard...). After all the bootup messages finally popped up the 80x25 term. Everything went fine until now but now started the trouble. the keybindings were weirdy and my favourite vim didn't obey my orders, adding to all this X (XFree86) would never start. I, for the first time, took the monitor manual and found out the Horiz and vertical freq. X seemed to be uncontrollable. also except for msdos I could not mount my other partitions ext3 & reiser. and I finally decided to give up for now and sadly I laid BSD to rest ;-(.
	
	Sometime later, I thought of trying the latest version of XFree86 and downloaded the ~30M files on my dialup (Took an entire night) only to forget about it. 

	Three days leave for PONGAL... I was reading an article on NetBSD at os.sourceforge.net and it inspired me to tame this daemon. Booted in to FreeBSD and straightaway started the XFree86-4.4.0 installation. Voila! X started - Luckily I had the 'via' driver in this version. 
The desktops included in FreeBSD were.
* Gnome 2.4.1
* KDE 3.1.4
* FVWM
* TWM

along with -
* KOffice
* KDevelop
* Quanta plus
* Opera, mozilla, ...

I really wondered, if a single CD can contain these many tools. They were so sweet and I especially love the gnome splash screen. I could even configure ACME to use all of my multimedia keys. played with all those tools for some time....

Accidently i came across a tool called 'vidcontrol'. This is used to setup the video mode for the console. I liked the 80x30 mode with swiss font. Cool!!!
(Know any similar tool for linux???  possibly setfont)

longed for more... wanted to mount my reiser and ext3 partitions. reiserfs was easy, googled reiserfs+FreeBSD and straight to the reiserfs port... compiled reiserfs as a module and loaded (readonly-happy with it). google had nothing to offer for ext3. Queued the task for some time later and had a look at the FreeBSD manual. To my surprise it had a word on ext2 and said that it is present in the source and by default not built in to the kernel. So wanted to compile the kernel, little hope if it would ever compile, for I have not even compiled a hello, world on BSD. OK, but let me try, I thought and followed the instruction (Options  EXT2FS) and started building the kernel. All the required tools were installed by default. Compilation was going fine until it threw a kernel exception. So what could be the reason? I restarted and found that the disk was only 150MB free. thought it could be the reason and removed the ports directory to free up some 250MB and restarted the build. Finally got a neat build. installed the new kernel and to my delight ext3 partitions could be mounted (readonly).

Loading and unloading the kernel modules are really very easy. Also automatic loading at boot time is also easier than in linux. Downloaded a nice splash image for the bootup screen. also, the console screen savers are cool!!!

Altogether it was a nice experience having had a chance to tame the great daddy of OS'. What a way to celebrate ~//~PONGAL~\\~

So whats up this weekend??? Take a copy of FreeBSD and click install! Wanna copy? mail me or call me to burn one (http://www.chennailug.org/wiki/CDs_for_Grab).


--
Regards,
R. Vijairaj

Jai Jawan! Jai Kissan! Jai FSFn!

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Mon Jan 17 17:14:02 2005
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)

Message-ID: <20050118011402.80149.qmail@web50210.mail.yahoo.com>

Greetings!

I would like to thank the Computer Science Department
- the students, professors, HOD and Dean, Kongu
Engineering College, Erode for giving me an
opportunity to conduct a one-day workshop/seminar on
"GNU/Linux/OSS" on January 17, 2005 (Monday). 

Special thanks to Arvind Kalyan (final year, CS) who
has been working with me for the past three weeks in
meticulously planning the seminar, and answering my
questions. Special thanks goes to the Management for
the good hospitality and stay provided at the guest
house. The infrastructure at your college is
_state-of-the-art_. Thanks for providing all the
required facilities for the seminar.

The following is a quick summary of the workshop
events:

Session I: "Careers with GNU/Linux/OSS" (morning)
Presentation slides can be downloaded from (2 MB):
http://www.geocities.com/cyborg4k/kongu.gnu.linux.oss.jan17.2005.pdf

Session II: Introduction to device driver programming
(morning)
Simple device driver code examples (demo) can be
downloaded from:
http://www.geocities.com/cyborg4k/kongu.jan17.2005.device.drivers.tar.gz

Session III: Knoppix demo and GNU/Linux installation
(afternoon)

Session IV: Watched the movie, The.Code.Linux.avi
(evening)

We shall organize more events in future as a
collaboration between ilugc and Kongu Linux User's
Group. 

Thanking you once again,

K Shakthi

P.S.: Arvind Kalyan, joined Kongu Linux User's mailing
list.

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Tue Jan 18 08:30:36 2005
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Tue Jan 18 08:28:00 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: linux + cdrecord = crash ?
In-Reply-To: <8816fcf80501171849876363d@mail.gmail.com>
References: <8816fcf80501171846286d3339@mail.gmail.com>
	<8816fcf80501171849876363d@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <41EC7BD4.3060804@frodo.hserus.net>

Sridhar Ratna wrote:
> On Tue, 18 Jan 2005 08:16:15 +0530, Sridhar Ratna
> <sridharinfinity@gmail.com> wrote:
> Jan 18 06:56:28 infinity exiting on signal 15
> Jan 18 06:56:29 infinity syslogd 1.4.1#16ubuntu4: restart.
> Jan 18 07:16:29 infinity -- MARK --
> Jan 18 07:36:30 infinity -- MARK --
> Jan 18 07:56:30 infinity -- MARK --
> Jan 18 08:08:04 infinity syslogd 1.4.1#16ubuntu4: restart.
> 
> ps: i face this problem since I was using Linux
> 

mark is not a problem - it is a placeholder entry is all

see man syslogd for details -

>        -m interval
>               The syslogd logs a mark timestamp  regularly.   The
>               default interval between two -- MARK -- lines is 20
>               minutes.  This can be  changed  with  this  option.
>               Setting the interval to zero turns it off entirely.

Subject: [Ilugc] Re: linux + cdrecord = crash ?
In-Reply-To: <8816fcf80501171914688dc847@mail.gmail.com>

Message-ID: <41EC8139.1000207@frodo.hserus.net>

Sridhar Ratna wrote:
> Seems like I will no longer use cdrecord .. possibly will help push
> the libcoaster, libburn projects further .....

cdrecord is setuid in recent versions to fix a security bug - so you 
either use sudo, or work as root to burn cds

try ide-scsi instead of just ide - and see if specifying dev=/dev/hdc 
(say) works for you
From joe_steeve at gmx.net  Mon Jan 17 20:41:31 2005
From: joe_steeve at gmx.net (Joe Steeve)
Date: Tue Jan 18 09:42:20 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] 100 % FOSS -- an illusion?
In-Reply-To: <20050116123130.84899.qmail@web30202.mail.mud.yahoo.com> (Toufeeq
	Hussain's message of "Sun, 16 Jan 2005 04:31:30 -0800 (PST)")
References: <20050116123130.84899.qmail@web30202.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <87651w850c.fsf@deck8.enterprise>

Toufeeq Hussain <topa_007@yahoo.com> writes:
> I use .MOV , .WMV, .ASF and .MP3 codecs to play multimedia files
> on xine or mplayer.
>
> Do these codecs qualify as F/OS Software ?  Can these codecs be
> used in Industry for Professional use without any Licensing
> Issues ?

There are some Open formats (Ogg Vorbis) which are not covered by
exclusive patents. Its your choice to either switch to Open
formats or to stick to whatever proprietary formats you've been
using. However, there is Free Software for both. 

Its advisable to use Open formats as a protest against the
irrelevance of the software patent system.

-- 
.O. A proud GNU user
..O http://www.joesteeve.tk/
OOO http://gnukid.5gigs.com/

> as

> physical address????
 
The address you see in /proc/pci is physical address.
The address returned from ioremap is virtual address.

From fred at bytesforall.org  Tue Jan 18 12:44:55 2005

Subject: [Ilugc] FreeSoftwaremagazine.com
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0501181244490.1608@news.goa.bytesforall.org>

Issue 1 Volume 1 of this new magazine has just hit the (cyber)stands. And, 
don't be too surprised, you're free to download a copy too of this 78-page 
publication. Some of the articles in the first issue:

 	o File formats; format wars (Marco Fioretti)
 	  File formats: the past, the present, a possible future

 	o XML: The answer to everything? (Kay Ethier, Scott Abel)
 	  This article weighs the pros and cons of XML for some
 	  applciations (publishing) and explores why it is the
  	  best possible solution for many programming and
 	  publishing needs.

 	o Free file formats and the future of intellectual
   	  freedom (Terry Hancock)
 	  Information as property may be served by closed
 	  file formats, but the freedom of information
 	  requires free formats.

 	o Creating the Free Software Magazine (Tony Mobily)
 	  A long path that takes us to the very beginning
 	  of this project.

 	o Mac OS X: Welcome to the jungle -- a look inside the
 	  Mac OS X software ecology (Chris J Karr)

 	o The magic of live CDs (Harish Pillay)
 	  What are live CDs, and how do they work?

 	o Every engineer's checklist for justifying
 	  Free Software. It's not just about 'no licence fees'
 	  (Malcolm D Spence)

 	o Smarter password management (John Locke)
 	  How to handle your passwords without getting lost

 	o The content tail wags the IT dog (Daniel James)
  	  Without hardware and software, there would be
 	  nothing for digital media to be created on, or used
 	  with. And yet the content industry attempts to tell
 	  the far larger IT industry what it can and cannot do.

 	o Motivation and value of free resources. Wikipedia
 	  and Planetmath show the way (Aaron E Klemm)

 	o It's all about freedom (Christian Einfeldt)
 	  Freedom is free software's competitive advantage.

 	o The Commons (Dave M Berry)
 	  The Commons as an Idea -- Ideas as a Commons

 	o Let's not forget our roots (Free Software is not
 	  just about cost or stability; it's a movement that
 	  mustn't forget the principles which made it possible)
 	  Tom Chance.

A PLANT NEEDS WATER TO GROW! Free Software Magazine -- by subscribing you will 
be supporting a magazine which believes in Free Software. All our articles are 
released under the GNU free documentation license, enhancing existing 
information on Free Software.

Download your copy today from http://www.freesoftwaremagazine.com
Subscriptions open!

From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Tue Jan 18 14:00:35 2005
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi S)
Date: Tue Jan 18 13:57:02 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] One Day One Command
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501131825530.23601-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501181342410.6505-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

One Day One Command :-
--------------------

free -- Display Information about Memory utilization

Summary:-

Displays the total amount of free and used physical memory 
& swap space in the system, as well as the buffers & cache 
consumed by the kernel.

Examples :-

$ free -- Display the mem info in KB.

$ free -m -- Display the mem info in MB.

$ free -m -t -- Display the total mem info.

$ free -s 2 -- Display the mem info for every 2Sec.

$ free -s 2 -c 5 -- Display the mem info for every 2Sec 
                    But only 5 times

$ cat /proc/meminfo -- This is the original info which 
                       is used by free command for the 
                       report.

Read: man free

Bye :)
-- 
Bharathi S

I have been using Thunderbird from version 0.3 and I faced this problem in all the versions.

This problem is not with the mail client.

classic fonts that when I installed Fedora Core 2 and found only 3
sets of fonts in the KDE Contol Centre which were the connectiva
crystal, bluecurve and one more (I think SVG...), I was a bit
dejected.

set of GNOME icons which were already installed. I even tried on th
RedHat 9 cds but to no avail. Then I realized that the icons maybe a
part of another package like kde-artworks. What I want to know is
whether on installing the package from RH9 CDs I will have any issues
in my existing Fedora installation as the artworks package will update
more things than just the icons.

Awaiting all levels of solutions for this apparently small peculiar
problem. Why are most distros cutting out on KDE icons now a days
anyway.
