From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Tue Jan 18 17:26:07 2005
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Tue Jan 18 17:23:38 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] FreeBSD installation
In-Reply-To: <557E17BE74D22143B7BE70EB60E33E9915357EEF@shlmsg01.ad.infosys.com>
References: <557E17BE74D22143B7BE70EB60E33E9915357EEF@shlmsg01.ad.infosys.com>
Message-ID: <41ECF957.5080004@frodo.hserus.net>

Toufeeq Hussain wrote:
> On a Windows Xp PC , I need to install Linux and FreeBSD.
> 
> What is the right order so that the bootloaders don't get screwed up ?
> Windows Xp is already installed.
> 
> Should I install Linux first and then BSd or the other way ?

Depends - if you want to use lilo/grub install linux first.  If not 
install freebsd.

And make sure you have enough primary partitions available.

	suresh
From vijairaj_sr at rediffmail.com  Tue Jan 18 17:28:35 2005
From: vijairaj_sr at rediffmail.com (Vijairaj R)
Date: Tue Jan 18 17:28:46 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: FreeBSD installation
In-Reply-To: <557E17BE74D22143B7BE70EB60E33E9915357EEF@shlmsg01.ad.infosys.com>
References: <557E17BE74D22143B7BE70EB60E33E9915357EEF@shlmsg01.ad.infosys.com>
Message-ID: <41ECF9EB.1040203@rediffmail.com>

Toufeeq Hussain wrote:
> Hi,
> 
> On a Windows Xp PC , I need to install Linux and FreeBSD.
> 
> What is the right order so that the bootloaders don't get screwed up ?
> Windows Xp is already installed.
> 
> Should I install Linux first and then BSd or the other way ?

Doesn't matter really, but make sure that you dont install the 
BSDs boot loader on the MBR unless you are familiar with it.

Actually there are some more limitations,
1. Freebsd can only be installed on a primary partition 
(http://www.tldp.org/HOWTO/Linux+FreeBSD-2.html) so you should 
have one to spare.
2. If XP is in a logical partition, then according to the 
windows naming conventions the partition number would have 
incremented and you might need to update the boot.ini file.

-- 
Regards,
R. Vijairaj

Jai Jawan! Jai Kissan! Jai FSFn!

Toufeeq Hussain wrote:
>>>Should I install Linux first and then BSd or the other way ?
>>
>>Depends - if you want to use lilo/grub install linux first.  
>>If not install freebsd.

depends - if you're more comfortable with grub than with the freebsd 
bootloader, feel free to use that.

grub (or lilo) will boot anything for you - solaris/i386, *bsd, windows 
- all it has to do is to point to the appropriate boot partition and 
pass any other boot parameters that are necessary for bootup.

	srs

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Tue Jan 18 18:04:18 2005

From trshash84 at gmail.com  Tue Jan 18 18:00:39 2005
From: trshash84 at gmail.com (T.R.Shashwath)
Date: Tue Jan 18 18:04:35 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] I pressed CTRL+ Z on a terminal
In-Reply-To: <2989532e0501180427319e10b0@mail.gmail.com>
References: <2989532e0501180427319e10b0@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <200501181800.39633.trshash84@gmail.com>

On Tuesday 18 Jan 2005 12:27 pm, Antony Paul wrote:
> Hi all,
>     I pressed CTRL + Z when a program was running. I want to bring it
> to front. How to do it ?
>
> rgds
> Antony Paul

Use "fg" to bring it to the front, or %programname (eg: %emacs).

You can also use something like "fg emacs", or "fg pid". Similarly, to make a 
task go to the background, C-z it and run "bg" or "bg programname"

HTH! :)

-- 
Shash

To know a thing well, know its limits. 
Only when pushed beyond its tolerances will true nature be seen.
--The Amtal Rule - Dune

I get another doubt because of your answers.

An ISO image (files present in compact disk) can be
dumped into a hard disk.  Without any CDROM drive and
with the help of some tools(like cd emulator or virtual
cd drive for MS windows) it can be accessed later if
I want.

If the organizing and structuring of data in any media
is already known, then why not dumping the content of dvd
into hard disk OR reading thru cd drive not possible through
some tool like virtual cd drive OR loopback devices?

kindly pour your thoughts on the same.

regards,
carti

carti wrote:
> An ISO image (files present in compact disk) can be
> dumped into a hard disk.  Without any CDROM drive and
> with the help of some tools(like cd emulator or virtual
> cd drive for MS windows) it can be accessed later if
> I want.

this can be done.

but how do you dump the dvd drive's contents onto the hdd without access 
to a dvd drive either on that machine or some other machine on the same 
network?

even if it is a machine on the same network, dumping the contents of a 
dvd drive to another machine reliably is rather time consuming .. i 
still remember karra sriram coming over to my place at 9 PM one night, 
rsyncing a copy of the PCQ sarge dvd onto his hard disk connected to my 
PC, while the dvd drive was mounted on my laptop, the PC's dvd combo 
drive having a technical snag of some kind ... and leaving a bit past 
midnight. :)

	srs

im using  freebsd 5.2.1, linux fedcore3 and windows (nt) i have no problems
the best order would be to install windows , then freebsd and linux , 
bcoz its nize to have grub on ur mbr.
if u have a problem with the booting , grub will be there for the rescue.

ananth.g


Suresh Ramasubramanian wrote:

> Toufeeq Hussain wrote:
>
>>>> Should I install Linux first and then BSd or the other way ?
>>>
>>>
>>> Depends - if you want to use lilo/grub install linux first.  If not 
>>> install freebsd.
>>
>
> depends - if you're more comfortable with grub than with the freebsd 
> bootloader, feel free to use that.
>
> grub (or lilo) will boot anything for you - solaris/i386, *bsd, 
> windows - all it has to do is to point to the appropriate boot 
> partition and pass any other boot parameters that are necessary for 
> bootup.
>

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Tue Jan 18 06:19:11 2005
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Tue Jan 18 19:49:45 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] doubts in kernel porting & device drivers
In-Reply-To: <20050118084748.74334.qmail@web8407.mail.in.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20050118141912.53161.qmail@web50203.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

--- Madhukar mythri <madhukar_linux@yahoo.co.in>
wrote:
>          So in /proc/pci IO-mapped address and
> Memory
> mapped address both are  physical addres only...
> as u  said.....   is it???

Yes.

>         iom_start = pci_resource_start(dev2,2);
>         iom_end = pci_resource_end(dev2,2);
>         iom_len = pci_resource_len(dev2,2);

What is the value of iom_len? You basically write
0xffffffff to base-address and read the value back.
Mask out the lower nibble and increment the resulting
value by 1 to get the size/len of the IO-mapped
region. Do read the PCI specification. 

> /* ioremap MMIO region */
>         ioaddr = ioremap(iom_start, iom_len);  //

What type is ioaddr? iom_len?

Check the short.c example in linux device drivers code
examples.

Regards,

K Shakthi

K Shakthi

http://www.geocities.com/shakthimaan

It is not advisable to convert from one lossy compression format to
another...the sound quality will be poorer, and audible glitches may
surface...Agreed that we need to protest against non-free formats, but
given the number if mp3's that are around, a more practical solution
would be live it, and ensure that anything that you encode from now on
is done with free formats :)

it moves on...

The first version I used FreeBSD 5.1.

It ran well on both my P4 and my old P1 166 Mhz.
Even X ran without any problems on my old SiS 6202 VGA card.

I also loved the ports package system and its simplicity.

Recently, I'm reading good reviews of NetBSD 2.0 with claims that 
It performs better/is faster than FreeBSD 5.3 on micro-management of
tasks.

Toufeeq Hussain

no, you don't need microphone ears - it's enough if you are a serious
listener of music...and especially when you use earphones, this
occasional sound resembling the initial handshake noise of dialup
connections is one 'signature' of these re-encoded files - and if you
have good bass in your speakers, and especially when the bitrate is
above 160 kbps, do try to listen to the two files in a interspersed
manner - there will be a certain lack of richness.

it moves on...

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Wed Jan 19 10:02:31 2005
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Wed Jan 19 10:02:53 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] mail access from linux thru M$ exchange
In-Reply-To: <20050119042831.43777.qmail@web51802.mail.yahoo.com>

simi mathur wrote:
> hi all
> how do v access mails from a linux desktop from  a M$
> exchange server 2003.

Evolution with the Ximian connector, for native exchange access

Or if your exchange server has IMAP/POP3 and SMTP connectors enabled you 
can use anything you want (kmail, thunderbird etc)

	srs

> >         iom_start = pci_resource_start(dev2,2);

> What is the value of iom_len? You basically write
> 0xffffffff to base-address and read the value back.
> Mask out the lower nibble and increment the
> resulting
> value by 1 to get the size/len of the IO-mapped
> region. Do read the PCI specification.

> >         ioaddr = ioremap(iom_start, iom_len);  //

> Check the short.c example in linux device drivers
> code examples.

From andyetitmoves at gmail.com  Wed Jan 19 10:46:46 2005
From: andyetitmoves at gmail.com (Ramkumar R)
Date: Wed Jan 19 10:47:06 2005
Subject: [OT][Ilugc] mail access from linux thru M$ exchange
In-Reply-To: <41EDE6B9.8050205@frodo.hserus.net>
References: <557E17BE74D22143B7BE70EB60E33E99153584F6@shlmsg01.ad.infosys.com>
	<41EDE6B9.8050205@frodo.hserus.net>
Message-ID: <9a9bfc17050118211628ccc105@mail.gmail.com>

> Speaking of that - is it necessary to have hal and dbus on a gnome 2.8
> install?

Better...components like the gnome-volume-manager (mounts your devices
automatically) use them - morever, nice as a concept - a central
broadcasting server through which event sources could communicate with
listeners, with good configurability for the sysad...I would visualize
many of the present day 'information' daemons (say hddtemp, for
example) using this in the future.

> 
> I upgraded to dropline gnome 2.8 from gnome 2.6 recently - and the
> fstab-sync (part of hald) keeps updating my fstab so that an entry for
> /sys is created - though it is already in mtab.  So my initscripts try
> to remount /sys and fail - though as /sys is already mounted because of
> mtab things work after throwing that error.

You can prevent this by modifying the hal policy - write up a config
file in /usr/share/hal/fdi/[priority]some-name/storage-policy.fdi -
it's an xml file, the dtd is in /usr/share/hal/fdi.dtd - keep the
priority higher than the default policy (usually 90), so that your
policy gets overriden finally - see man fstab-sync for details....

afaik, beagle needs the inotify kernel patch as well...apart from some
other packages...
if you are using reiserfs, extended attributes (REISERFS_FS_XATTR)
must be enabled...
I am currently waiting for inotify to get to the mainstream - hopeful
that it won't be too long, considering it's advantages over dnotify.

it moves on...

> 
>         suresh
> _______________________________________________
> To unsubscribe, email ilugc-request@ae.iitm.ac.in with
> "unsubscribe <password> <address>"
> in the subject or body of the message.
> http://www.ae.iitm.ac.in/mailman/listinfo/ilugc

you folks. I plan to use it in my business card rather than my
e-mail id.

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Tue Jan 18 23:41:52 2005
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Wed Jan 19 13:12:00 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] doubts in kernel porting & device drivers
In-Reply-To: <20050119045942.66141.qmail@web8408.mail.in.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20050119074152.83153.qmail@web50210.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi Madhukar,

--- Madhukar mythri <madhukar_linux@yahoo.co.in>
wrote:
>   Memory mapped mean.. the IO-address lines is
> mapped
> to physical memory location some range....

Address lines (from CPU) are mapped to I/O, eventually
using the addressable memory region. Have to use
readl(), writel() functions.

>  and IO-mapped mean CPU bus lines are dedicated to
> some 
> IO's which have smaller address range...

Few address lines from CPU are used just for I/O chip
select. As a result you have to use specific inb(),
outb() functions.

> > > /* ioremap MMIO region */
> > >         ioaddr = ioremap(iom_start, iom_len); 
> //
> > 
> > What type is ioaddr? iom_len?
>       
>       ioaddr------> void *  
>       iom_len----->unsigned long

ioaddr should be of type - unsigned long.

K Shakthi

=====

K Shakthi
Specsoft (Hexaware Technologies), ASIC Design Center
http://www.geocities.com/shakthimaan

From suraj at symonds.net  Wed Jan 19 00:49:58 2005
From: suraj at symonds.net (Suraj)

Subject: [Ilugc] A spam reduction solution for me

V.K.Vallinayagam wrote: 
,----
|  I had this  need. I run my own  business. I want a way  in which many
| people can  message me. I thought  of putting my e-mail  id in company
| web-page and my business card but I feared misuse and spam.
`----

Like what Schneier says, "Security"  is only a function of the comfort
level you  want to  provide the  people who will  have to  observe the
security measures.  In  your case, you will end  up missing some folks
who think  its too  much of a  pain to  send you a  mail via  that web
interface.

cheers,

From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Wed Jan 19 16:45:59 2005
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi S)
Date: Wed Jan 19 16:43:57 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] One Day One Command
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501191645200.18100-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

One Day One Command :-
--------------------
df -- Disk Free and Usage report

Summary:-

df command display the amount of disk space available on 
the filesystem (FS) containing each file name argument. 
If no file name is given, the space available on all 
currently mounted FSs is shown.

Examples :-

$ df -- Usage report of all mounted FS.

$ df myfile -- Display usage report of FS which contain
               the myfile.

$ df /home -- Usage report of Home partition

$ df /dev/hda1 -- Usage report of /dev/hda1

$ df -Th -- Display the partition type and size is in human 
            readable format

$ df -x tmpfs -- Don't list the 'tmpfs' partitions.

$ df -P -- Output in POSIX format. (Remove -P and see the 
           difference)

Read: man df

Bye :)
-- 
Bharathi S

From: suraj at symonds.net (Suraj)
Date: Wed Jan 19 19:36:57 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] reiser 4 vs xfs

Ramkumar R wrote: 
,----
| well...reiser4 is not stable as yet  - reiserfs is quite good in fact,
| many distros  have it  as the default...i  have reiserfs on  my system
| with no problems at all...ppl say that for reiser4 as well, but if you
| are of the paranoid type, you better wait...
`----

remember, there are  no tools (yet) to recover  a crashed reiserfs. If
you  care for  your  data, you  probably  would use  ext3 or  whatever
instead of "trying" out xfs. I put  all *my* data in an ext3 and my /,
/usr, etc.,. in an xfs.

cheers,

  -Suraj

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Wed Jan 19 09:52:27 2005
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Wed Jan 19 23:22:40 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] doubts in kernel porting & device drivers
In-Reply-To: <20050119130225.28370.qmail@web8405.mail.in.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20050119175227.14729.qmail@web50206.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

--- Madhukar mythri <madhukar_linux@yahoo.co.in>
wrote:
> (in O.S books i had studied like, physical address
> mean RAM address)

Not necessarily. It depends on the architecture.
Having 32 address lines gives the ability to address a
4G address space. Where it is mapped to depends on the
hardware.
 
>       ioaddr = ioremap(physical_addr, Len);
> > ioaddr should be of type - unsigned long.
> 
>  oky...but, ioremap() returns type "void *"  know...
> So, should we type cast ...

void * is a generic type. It cannot be used directly.
It is useful to pass addresses (that can represent
anything). You will need to typecast it to use it.

"Suriya Narayanan M S" <mssnlayam@vsnl.net> wrote:
> PS: Not to offend you, but this attitude is really 
> irritating. ILUGC is
> not a technical support center.

No offence, but, if you do not wish to reply, please
ignore the e-mail. But, don't discourage a person from
asking questions. I don't see why ILUGC cannot be a
technical support center. It is a great place to learn
and provide technical help :)

Regards,

K Shakthi

Antony Paul <antonypaul24@gmail.com> writes:

> It is the first list I am seeing which behaves like this. 

No, this is a standard feature in mailing lists.  Mail reader are usually
powerfull enough to provide two functionalities: use the `Reply-To' or the
mailing-list.

Ofcouse, we can manually edit these too.

For emacs+gnus lovers, you can type f/F to reply to the mailing list and
r/R to reply to the author (much the same feel as when readin news from
nntp servers).

From vijairaj_sr at rediffmail.com  Wed Jan 19 19:01:09 2005
From: vijairaj_sr at rediffmail.com (Vijairaj  R)
Date: Thu Jan 20 00:31:10 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Installing linux
Message-ID: <20050119190243.30843.qmail@webmail45.rediffmail.com>

Comrades,
Atlast, found some time to complete this (http://www.chennailug.org/wiki/Linux/Installation) article on Linux Installation.

I never used Linux to check mail nor used Emacs. I use web mail
clients or Outlook Express(Hotmail account) to check mail. I do
subscribe to lot of mailing lists at Apache, CVS, PostgreSQL. This is
the only list I came across which behaves like this. Now I will hit
Reply to All in Gmail web UI.

    I searched in the archive at
yahoo(http://groups.yahoo.com/group/ilugc-archive/) to find out why
ilugc behaves like this. The search results showed no relevant
information. So can any one please tell me why people dont like to
reply to the list but to individuals.

   I have some more suggestions. 
1. Put a link to a searchable list archive in the mail subscription page.
2. There is no link to Wiki in the home page.

--- Shakthi Kannan <cyborg4k@yahoo.com> wrote:
> Hi,
> 
> --- Madhukar mythri <madhukar_linux@yahoo.co.in>
> wrote:
> > (in O.S books i had studied like, physical address
> > mean RAM address)
> 
> Not necessarily. It depends on the architecture.
> Having 32 address lines gives the ability to address
> a
> 4G address space. Where it is mapped to depends on
> the
> hardware.
>  
> >       ioaddr = ioremap(physical_addr, Len);
> > > ioaddr should be of type - unsigned long.
> > 
> >  oky...but, ioremap() returns type "void *" 
> know...
> > So, should we type cast ...
> 
> void * is a generic type. It cannot be used
> directly.
> It is useful to pass addresses (that can represent
> anything). You will need to typecast it to use it.
>

From siva at dias.ath.cx  Thu Jan 20 10:08:40 2005
From: siva at dias.ath.cx (Sivasankar Chander)
Date: Thu Jan 20 10:39:53 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] FC3 (was: reiser 4 vs xfs)
Message-ID: <20050120043840.CC3DE33508@whitebox.dias.ath.cx>


> can anybody tell me which of these two is better(reiser 4 vs xfs)...?

  No idea, I'm quite happy with ext3 on cryptoloop.

> also... i am still undecided betw fedcore3 and drake 10.....
> 
  IMHO, FC3 is the best desktop distro that has come out of the RedHat
stable since RH 7.3. I still dislike the default Bluecurve desktop,
so I got rid of it and switched to xfce4 instead.

  I was able to perform a manual, selective upgrade of my primary
system (a heavily-upgraded RedHat 7.3 install) using just the binary
rpms from FC3, and a few SRPMs from previous RedHat distros. The
salient features are:

Linux-2.6.8.1 (tarball from kernel.org)
Static /dev tree (no udev)
glibc-2.3.3-74 (from FC3)
gcc-3.4.2-6.fc3
rpm-4.3.2-21 (from FC3)
XFree86-4.3.0-55 (recompiled with gcc34 - upgrading to X.org is hairy) 
xfce-4.1.99.2 (still buggy, but a lovely lightweight WM that's very
     easy on the eyes - I recommend the GTK style with the Xfce-kolors
     user-interface theme, but of course it's a matter of personal
     choice. This rivals fvwm2 in all-round usability)
rxvt-2.7.8 (replacement for xterm, which is a resource hog. Just say no)
mozilla-1.6.0.dag (an old and reliable release - I'll move to firefox after
     sorting out the dependencies)
postfix-1.1.13 (another legacy remnant)
cdrecord-2.0.1.1-5 (from FC3, supports native ATA CD-R/RW without IDE-SCSI.
  One minor observation is that it burns CD-Rs at an average speed of 32x
  on a 52x writer, with speed varying from about 20x at the start to 48x
  near the end. Pretty good, but I'm not sure if it's HW-constrained)
ogle-0.9.2 (for DVD playback)
qryptix (my own stuff, to encrypt home directories)
and a bunch of other stuff to satisfy dependencies - not too difficult.

The entire setup is rock-stable, and astonishly responsive as a desktop.
All of this is on a PIII-1Ghz/256 MB RAM/i815e with on-board VGA/sound.
I'd recommend recompiling some critical pieces (kernel, glibc, xfree86,
some other libraries) using gcc-3.4.2 to take advantage of the 2.6 
vsyscall, as well as other optimizations in gcc33 and gcc34 - the
-mregparm=3 for the kernel (transplanted from AIX/POWER/PowerPC,
which has had it since 1990(?)) is one of them. 

I'm investigating replicating the install on a legacy PII notebook
with 96 MB RAM - more later. Anybody who thinks that Gentoo is the
best-performing desktop distro, especially on resource-constrained
systems, should seriously consider FC3 instead. It rocks!

(Get the FC3 ISO images from this month's Digit DVD instead of the
installable DVD from last month's LFY, if you can. CDROM drives
are more prevalent on legacy systems.)

-Siva

From mbchandar at gmail.com  Thu Jan 20 11:03:37 2005
From: mbchandar at gmail.com (bala chandar)
Date: Thu Jan 20 11:03:45 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Difference between bashrc and bash_profile
In-Reply-To: <20050120053041.44110.qmail@web53402.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20050120053041.44110.qmail@web53402.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <dc538c3f050119213375992310@mail.gmail.com>

bashrc is the profile configuration per user.
bash_profile is for the all the user.

when u do changes in bashrc, it is reflected to that particular user
when u do changes in bash_profil, it is reflected to all user


On Wed, 19 Jan 2005 21:30:41 -0800 (PST), ram

From sridharinfinity at gmail.com  Thu Jan 20 11:10:47 2005
From: sridharinfinity at gmail.com (Sridhar Ratna)
Date: Thu Jan 20 11:10:51 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Difference between bashrc and bash_profile
In-Reply-To: <20050120053041.44110.qmail@web53402.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20050120053041.44110.qmail@web53402.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <8816fcf805011921404ed48c02@mail.gmail.com>

On Wed, 19 Jan 2005 21:30:41 -0800 (PST), ram
<ramprasad_rajendran@yahoo.com> wrote:
> Hai everyone,
> What is the difference between bashrc and bash_profile
> and what do i put in each.?
> 

.bash_profile is executed for login shells (eg. virutal  terminals)
.bashrc is executed for interactive shells (eg. gnome-terminal)

read bash manual page

-- 
Sridhar Ratna - http://srid.bsdnerds.org

From siva at dias.ath.cx  Thu Jan 20 12:03:10 2005
From: siva at dias.ath.cx (Sivasankar Chander)
Date: Thu Jan 20 12:34:23 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] FC3 (was: reiser 4 vs xfs)
In-Reply-To: <20050120052636.71579.qmail@web53403.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20050120063310.9959633508@whitebox.dias.ath.cx>

> I've got one doubt here.
> Then does it mean that u cannot recover files on a
> resierfs  when the system has been improperly shutdown
> 
> > > can anybody tell me which of these two is
> > better(reiser 4 vs xfs)...?
> > 
> >   No idea, I'm quite happy with ext3 on cryptoloop.
> > 
  
  I don't know, but Reiser4 doesn't have the reputation
of being industrial-strength. OTOH, I haven't lost a
single byte of data over the last 4 years with ext3 -
so I'm staying with ext3 until significant performance
advantages, combined with industrial-strength reliability,
are seen in xfs, reiser4, etc.

  The other main advantage of ext3 is that in a pinch, I
can repair an ext3 filesystem mounted as an ext2
filesystem, which is supported on a whole lot of install
CDs and liveCDs (RH 6.2, 7.x, 8.x, Knoppix, ...). I did
this recently on a system in which I'd accidentally
hosed glibc during an attempted upgrade, leaving the system
unbootable. I rebooted in rescue mode with a RH 7.3
install CD and repaired it without much effort. With
Reiser or anything more elaborate, I'd have been sunk -
it would have required a kernel with the appropriate
filesystem support compiled in.

-Siva
From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Wed Jan 19 23:31:00 2005
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Thu Jan 20 13:21:14 2005

From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Thu Jan 20 13:52:49 2005
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi S)
Date: Thu Jan 20 13:50:36 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] One Day One Command
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501201304030.7889-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

One Day One Command :-
--------------------
uname - Display system informations

Summary:-

Display system infos like OS Type, Kernel version, Arch,
Host name etc... Main this uname will collect the info
from the /proc/sys/kernel/{ostype, hostname, osrelease, 
version, domainname}.

Examples :-

$ uname  -- Kernel Name

$ uname -n -- Show the machine name

$ uname -rv -- Show kernel's release & Ver info

$ uname -om -- Show Arch and OS Type

$ uname -a  -- Show all info

Read: man uname

Bye :)
-- 
Bharathi S



From deepak.sarda at gmail.com  Thu Jan 20 17:28:09 2005
From: deepak.sarda at gmail.com (Deepak Sarda)
Date: Thu Jan 20 14:58:33 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] FC3 (was: reiser 4 vs xfs)
In-Reply-To: <20050120063310.9959633508@whitebox.dias.ath.cx>
References: <20050120052636.71579.qmail@web53403.mail.yahoo.com>
	<20050120063310.9959633508@whitebox.dias.ath.cx>
Message-ID: <eaac783a0501200128f6cde68@mail.gmail.com>

On Thu, 20 Jan 2005 12:03:10 +0530 (IST), Sivasankar Chander
<siva@dias.ath.cx> wrote:
>   
>   I don't know, but Reiser4 doesn't have the reputation
> of being industrial-strength. OTOH, I haven't lost a
> single byte of data over the last 4 years with ext3 -
> so I'm staying with ext3 until significant performance
> advantages, combined with industrial-strength reliability,
> are seen in xfs, reiser4, etc.
> 

I do not understand why you are comparing ext3 with reiser4. Reiser4
is new and of course needs more real world testing before 'mission
critical' data can be entrusted to it.
A fair comparison would be to compare ext3 with reiserfs (ver3).

I've always used Reiserfs since mandrake started using is as default.
I've never lost data to it due to corruption. The one time I did lose
data, it was my own 'rm -rf' mistake :)
This brings me to another question asked here:

On Wed, 19 Jan 2005 21:26:36 -0800 (PST), ram
<ramprasad_rajendran@yahoo.com> wrote:
> I've got one doubt here.
> Then does it mean that u cannot recover files on a
> resierfs  when the system has been improperly shutdown

You can certainly expect to recover files from an improper shutdown -
that's what a journalized file system is all about. Without getting
into technicalities, IMO Ext3 is no better than Reiserfs at handling
improper shutdowns. Does that sound too negative? What I mean is that
both are good at handling improper shutdowns.. but it's not like ext3
does it better than reiserfs.

The one thing that ReiserFS doesn't support is 'undelete' as I found
out after an inadvertant 'rm -rf'  I wrote a mini-howto to recover
data for reiserfs:

http://www.antrix.net/journal/techtalk/reiserfs_data_recovery_howto.comments

Deepak.

PS: Wasn't the thread about reiser4 vs xfs? :)

-- 

http://eminor.antrix.net/

From andyetitmoves at gmail.com  Thu Jan 20 16:57:08 2005
From: andyetitmoves at gmail.com (Ramkumar R)
Date: Thu Jan 20 16:57:20 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Difference between bashrc and bash_profile
In-Reply-To: <8816fcf805011921404ed48c02@mail.gmail.com>
References: <20050120053041.44110.qmail@web53402.mail.yahoo.com>
	<8816fcf805011921404ed48c02@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <9a9bfc170501200327598c95ca@mail.gmail.com>

> .bash_profile is executed for login shells (eg. virutal  terminals)
> .bashrc is executed for interactive shells (eg. gnome-terminal)

well..usually yes...but do remember that whether we start a login
shell or not doesn't really depend on the terminal. depends on how
bash is started - it behaves like a login shell when started with a
--login, -l or as -bash.

A modular setup could have the following components - a .login file
(or call it whatever you want) with all the environment settings, a
.bashrc with all interactive stuff like aliases, functions,
interactive bash options and startup commands, a .bash_profile with
the .login and the .bashrc sourced in, and you could preferably source
.login to your .xinitrc and .Xclients as well...this is out of
experience, so do tell me if there is a technically more correct
method....

it moves on...

> 
> read bash manual page
> 
> --
> Sridhar Ratna - http://srid.bsdnerds.org

From andyetitmoves at gmail.com  Thu Jan 20 17:11:40 2005
From: andyetitmoves at gmail.com (Ramkumar R)
Date: Thu Jan 20 17:12:01 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] FC3 (was: reiser 4 vs xfs)
In-Reply-To: <20050120052636.71579.qmail@web53403.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20050120043840.CC3DE33508@whitebox.dias.ath.cx>
	<20050120052636.71579.qmail@web53403.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <9a9bfc17050120034116e95cb@mail.gmail.com>

> I've got one doubt here.
> Then does it mean that u cannot recover files on a
> resierfs  when the system has been improperly shutdown

reiserfs is one true journalled fs - that means that you can pull the
plug while bunzip2'ing a kernel archive and still come up with a
consistent fs with as little data loss as possible - this has been
tested - or may be do something more drastic as rajsekar did with
swsusp...don't recommend it though :)...

I may be wrong, but I still can't help feeling that ext3 is ext2
'patched' with journalling features...

In addition, reiserfs is found to save as much as 15% on hard disk
space and has been benchmarked to have better performance - besides
some other theoretical advantages like ability to store unlimited
number of files (within you hard disk space, obviously), as compared
to ext* where you need to specify a cap on the number of files you
will be able to store.

Hey, how's the performance on cryptoloop? I imagined that it would be
a nightmare!!

it moves on...

> --- Sivasankar Chander <siva@dias.ath.cx> wrote:
> 
> >
> > > can anybody tell me which of these two is
> > better(reiser 4 vs xfs)...?
> >
> >   No idea, I'm quite happy with ext3 on cryptoloop.
> >
> > > also... i am still undecided betw fedcore3 and
> > drake 10.....
> > >
> >   IMHO, FC3 is the best desktop distro that has come
> > out of the RedHat
> > stable since RH 7.3. I still dislike the default
> > Bluecurve desktop,
> > so I got rid of it and switched to xfce4 instead.
> >
> >   I was able to perform a manual, selective upgrade
> > of my primary
> > system (a heavily-upgraded RedHat 7.3 install) using
> > just the binary
> > rpms from FC3, and a few SRPMs from previous RedHat
> > distros. The
> > salient features are:
> >
> > Linux-2.6.8.1 (tarball from kernel.org)
> > Static /dev tree (no udev)
> > glibc-2.3.3-74 (from FC3)
> > gcc-3.4.2-6.fc3
> > rpm-4.3.2-21 (from FC3)
> > XFree86-4.3.0-55 (recompiled with gcc34 - upgrading
> > to X.org is hairy)
> > xfce-4.1.99.2 (still buggy, but a lovely lightweight
> > WM that's very
> >      easy on the eyes - I recommend the GTK style
> > with the Xfce-kolors
> >      user-interface theme, but of course it's a
> > matter of personal
> >      choice. This rivals fvwm2 in all-round
> > usability)
> > rxvt-2.7.8 (replacement for xterm, which is a
> > resource hog. Just say no)
> > mozilla-1.6.0.dag (an old and reliable release -
> > I'll move to firefox after
> >      sorting out the dependencies)
> > postfix-1.1.13 (another legacy remnant)
> > cdrecord-2.0.1.1-5 (from FC3, supports native ATA
> > CD-R/RW without IDE-SCSI.
> >   One minor observation is that it burns CD-Rs at an
> > average speed of 32x
> >   on a 52x writer, with speed varying from about 20x
> > at the start to 48x
> >   near the end. Pretty good, but I'm not sure if
> > it's HW-constrained)
> > ogle-0.9.2 (for DVD playback)
> > qryptix (my own stuff, to encrypt home directories)
> > and a bunch of other stuff to satisfy dependencies -
> > not too difficult.
> >
> > The entire setup is rock-stable, and astonishly
> > responsive as a desktop.
> > All of this is on a PIII-1Ghz/256 MB RAM/i815e with
> > on-board VGA/sound.
> > I'd recommend recompiling some critical pieces
> > (kernel, glibc, xfree86,
> > some other libraries) using gcc-3.4.2 to take
> > advantage of the 2.6
> > vsyscall, as well as other optimizations in gcc33
> > and gcc34 - the
> > -mregparm=3 for the kernel (transplanted from
> > AIX/POWER/PowerPC,
> > which has had it since 1990(?)) is one of them.
> >
> > I'm investigating replicating the install on a
> > legacy PII notebook
> > with 96 MB RAM - more later. Anybody who thinks that
> > Gentoo is the
> > best-performing desktop distro, especially on
> > resource-constrained
> > systems, should seriously consider FC3 instead. It
> > rocks!
> >
> > (Get the FC3 ISO images from this month's Digit DVD
> > instead of the
> > installable DVD from last month's LFY, if you can.
> > CDROM drives
> > are more prevalent on legacy systems.)
> >
> > -Siva

From suraj at symonds.net  Thu Jan 20 03:57:16 2005
From: suraj at symonds.net (Suraj)
Date: Thu Jan 20 17:27:33 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Difference between bashrc and bash_profile
In-Reply-To: <9a9bfc170501200327598c95ca@mail.gmail.com>
References: <20050120053041.44110.qmail@web53402.mail.yahoo.com>
	<8816fcf805011921404ed48c02@mail.gmail.com>
	<9a9bfc170501200327598c95ca@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20050120115716.GA30422@symonds.net>

Ramkumar R wrote: 
,----
| A modular  setup could have the  following components -  a .login file
| (or call  it whatever you want)  with all the  environment settings, a
| .bashrc   with  all   interactive  stuff   like   aliases,  functions,
| interactive bash  options and  startup commands, a  .bash_profile with
| the .login and the .bashrc sourced in, and you could preferably source
| .login  to  your .xinitrc  and  .Xclients  as  well...this is  out  of
| experience,  so do  tell me  if there  is a  technically  more correct
| method....
`----

I maintain the following:

.bashrc -- all variables, aliases.
.bash_profile -- nothing  but a  shell script that  determines what it
should start for the "session". (ie.,. screen)
functions.sh --  shell functions that are  invoked regularly ('emacs',
'dirrc', etc.,.)

At work,  since I will have  to login to several  hundred machines and
since some machines dont  have some capabilities (depending on whether
they are 'production' or  'development' boxes) the "session" part gets
modified accordingly  (ie.,.  whether it should  run ssh-agent, screen
or simply give a shell, etc.,.)

cheers,

  -Suraj

-- 
,-----------------[http://www.symonds.net/~suraj/]---o
| The kanjira is an instrument without shruti.
`------------------------------[suraj@symonds.net]---o

codename. There is, indeed, such a codename. The announcement behind

Microsoft patent saber-rattling.

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Thu Jan 20 11:10:59 2005

Dear GNU/Linux enthusiasts:

This is just a confirmation/reminder that we will be
having the shell scripting session I by Hariram
Aatreya on January 22, 2005 (Saturday) at CSD#320,

From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Fri Jan 21 16:20:46 2005
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi S)
Date: Fri Jan 21 16:18:03 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] One Day One Command
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501211602290.24266-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

One Day One Command :-
-------------------

ls -- List directory contents

Summary : 

List the current directory contents and informations.

Examples :

$ ls  -- Alphabetically list all files and dir 

$ ls -r -- Reverse order

$ ls --color=always -- Output in color

$ ls -F -- Files are classified with /@|= symbols

$ ls -1 -- Output in single column

$ ls -a -- Display hidden entries starting with .

$ ls -R -- Recursive output

$ ls -Q -- Enclose entry names in double quotes

Read : man ls

Wish you happy Bakrid & Bye :)
-- 
Bharathi S

From vallinayagam at ureach.com  Sat Jan 22 05:58:02 2005
From: vallinayagam at ureach.com (V.K.Vallinayagam)
Date: Sat Jan 22 16:28:12 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] which linux brand teaches me linux better?
Message-ID: <200501221058.FAA06313@www21.ureach.com>

Hi,
 "linux" - means different things to different people. For most
part, they assume the command line and GUI applications running
on linux and the facilities given by the platform for the
applications to run co-operatively. 
  This is my advice. It is better that whatever you learn can be
applied in windows platform too. I would suggest take a TCL
shell, in linux or windows and start doing command line stuffs.
In TCL, the difference between command line and programming
language is not there. 
  I would suggest this investment of time and efforts pays-off
more than learning basic linux-specific commands like "ls" .
Whatever you have learnt can be applied in windows and linux
except for platform specific issues.Infact , it is an
un-advertised fact that TCL has many cross-platform attributes
and satisfies many things that java claims too.
 In TCL shell, you would feel you are in command line mode and
not programming language . Then get to know the boot sequence
and then kernel compilation. I started with SuSE and moved to
Debian. I would suggest start with knoppix live-cd , no install
required.

Regards
V.K.Vallinayagam
MsgBox: http://valli.home.dyndns.org

In-Reply-To: <41F10FA3.9080307@eth.net>

Boovarahan <boose@eth.net> wrote:

> I had windows in /dev/hda1 and mdk in /dev/hda5.
>
> Recently I altered the configuration by using fdisk.
>
> At present I have windows in /dev/hda3.
>
> I could not find linux. I tried the rescue mode but could not succeed.

Boot with a linux bootable disk / rescue cd / any bootable cd that lets you
specify commandline boot options, then do a fdisk -l and see if you can list
the partitions out.

	srs

From gnunify at symbiosiscomputers.com  Fri Jan 21 13:59:11 2005
From: gnunify at symbiosiscomputers.com (GNUnify 2005)
Date: Sat Jan 22 17:26:58 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Invitation for GNUnify '05
Message-ID: <200501210829.j0L8TBbm005774@localhost.localdomain>

 Dear  Sir / Madam,

   We, the students of MSC (CA),SICSR, take a pleasure to invite you to
   a**GNUnify a**05a**- the FREE SOFTWARE event organized by Symbiosis
   Institute of Computer Studies and Research (SICSR).

   As a part of our efforts to spread IT every year we organize-"GNUnify",
   which aims at contributing and encouraging the use of Free/Open Source
   Software. "GNUnify" was initiated in the year of 2003, as a forum to unite
   open minds. The event aims at spreading the philosophy of GNU Linux,
   unifying and strengthening the open source movement, sharing and spreading
   knowledge.

   GNUnify 2003 and GNUnify 2004 witnessed the success of various events like
   Techie Talks, Install Fest, Tutorials, and Workshops. Eminent speakers
   like Dr. Richard M.Stallman, President and Founder of FSF, USA, Mr. Naba
   Kumar, GNOME Organizations Mr. Robert Adkins, Technetra, California, Ms.
   Alolita Sharma, Technetra, California, and their likes, graced the event
   in the previous two years. Some of the topics of the talks include
   Wireless Technology Deployment using GNU/Linux, Collaborative Open Source
   Project Revenue Models, Guerialla-Warfare in Gyan and its kinds.

   Upholding the success of past two years the students of M Sc(CA) are
   organizing GNUnify 05' the 3 day activity during Feb 13-15,2005. On the
   first day, there is a Linux Awareness Program for school Children. On the
   second day we have Install Fest, Techie Talks, Workshops and Tutorials. On
   the third day we have Seminars that will focus on a combination of
   managerial, social and technical topics in the areas of Free software/
   Open Source.

   We would like to cordially invite you for the event where you can deliver
   talks on topics either of your choice pertaining to FOSS or the ones
   mentioned on our website.You are also welcome to take part in TechieTalks,
   Workshops and Tutorials where you would be delivering technical knowledge
   to the audience. We will be delighted if you can make it to GNUnify 2005.

   Please visit our website http://gnunify.sicsr.ac.in for further details.

   Please feel free to forward this mail to anyone who believes in the cause
   of Free/Open Source software.

   Anticipating a positive reply,

   Thank you.
   With Regards,

 Apeksha Chate

My suggestion is to try all the distros you could "think" of. :)  But
do not forget the command line.  You must be able to use/setup almost
anything from command line.  Thus fedora/redhat/mdk may not be
important distro at all.

You may start off with slackware and may eventually move on to debian.

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Sat Jan 22 06:57:14 2005
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Sat Jan 22 20:27:27 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] which linux brand teaches me linux better?
In-Reply-To: <8816fcf805012205073b322e06@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20050122145714.9244.qmail@web50204.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

> On Sat, 22 Jan 2005 16:06:43 +0530, Srinivasan Gopal
> <srinivasan.iitm@gmail.com> wrote:
> > sir,
> > which linux teaches me better ?
> > 1.fedora core 3
> > 2.mandrake
> > 3.slackwire
> > 4.debian

Any of the off-the-shelf distros are good. 

As far as what teaches you better it depends on what
you want to learn. It really doesn't matter what
distro you use, only the relevant software packages
are important.

Regards,

K Shakthi

Shakthi Kannan wrote: 
,----
| > > sir,
| > > which linux teaches me better ?
| > > 1.fedora core 3
| > > 2.mandrake
| > > 3.slackwire
| > > 4.debian
| 
| Any of the off-the-shelf distros are good. 
`----

Building a Linux-From-Scratch would be a good way of learning a lot of
things that  you will  generally not learn  otherwise. But  thats only
after you know  some of the basics. So any of  the above distros would
be a good place to start.

cheers,

  -Suraj

Hi,

So finally we have confused the new man very throughly !

Well here enters the Red Hat fan, I would suggest Fedora Core 3, hoping 
you have a good new machine. New machine in the sense it has a decent 
processor (PIII equivalent or above) and decent amount of HDD. If you want 
to be stingy for space then try minimal installation and miss some thing 
and then wonder why something doesnt work !

Nice to be back on the list after a gap of more than 2 years. In case 
people forgot who I am, I am the guy in aero department, well may name on 
google shows a lot of archives with my responses in it.

Hi suraj and Prabhu. Feels pretty nostalgic to be back on the list. I miss 
our man Mr.M.K.Saravanan.

Well now that I am on the list, will add more activity to the list :D

Midhun Kumar Allu

the Live CD, he can do a hard disk install and have a Debian based
system.

From igni_linux at yahoo.com  Sat Jan 22 19:31:56 2005
From: igni_linux at yahoo.com (ignacius nallu)
Date: Sun Jan 23 09:02:13 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] dual booting -XP and Fedora
Message-ID: <20050123033156.80205.qmail@web30201.mail.mud.yahoo.com>

Dear all,
This is the way I have setup dual booting and I am
using this for the past 2 years without any problems.
1. Install Windows XP
2. Install Fedora.In the bootloader configuration
install the grub bootloader on the dedicated /boot
partition or the single / partition as per your setup
preference in disk setup[dont install it in
/dev/hda[mbr]]
3. Extract XOSL [free] in c:
4. Read the XOSL manual that comes along witrh it to
get more idea.
5.boot using windows boot floppy
6.Install XOSL
Adv: 
1.You may uninstall XOSL any time restoring to
previous setup and also if you change your mindset to
install grub on /dev/hda you may install grub later.


Moreover there is no fear in dualbooting any linux
with WinXp/2000 because, if any problem occurs you may
use fixmbr and bootcfg to rectify windows booting
corruption.
And in in a similar way you may restore your grub by
booting with fedora rescue CD. and do chroot and
grub-install.

Trust me because I have triple booted winXP,slackware
and Fedora core 1 without any problems in my 20 GB
hdd. 

You may also use some utilities to backup your boot
records and restore them when they get corrupted.



If this input is useless please neglect...

bye,
ignacius






		
__________________________________ 
Do you Yahoo!? 
Take Yahoo! Mail with you! Get it on your mobile phone. 
http://mobile.yahoo.com/maildemo

> and finally settle on the one, he feels comfortable.
> Then you can start
> talking, how your choice of distro is better than
> others ;)

This would be the best way to go about learning Linux.
You get to taste all the dishes on the table and you
can make out the common ingredients in them ;)

It really doesnt matter as in the end you will end up
with either a RedHat based or a Debian based one.

If you are an elitist, you might even end up using
FreeBSD or Slackware.

By way of analysis we may proceed from compounds to
         ingredients.            --Sir I.Newton.

Learning the ingredients(UNIX) is more important that
the compounds(Linux Distro's).

Regards,
Toufeeq Hussain


=====

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Sun Jan 23 16:44:30 2005
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Sun Jan 23 16:44:39 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: USB driver for airtel tera gate modem
In-Reply-To: <341c07aa05012302017c78a94a@mail.gmail.com>
References: <20050121181423.68754.qmail@web30201.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
	<341c07aa05012302017c78a94a@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <41f38716.whNyrTekFxUKyoEu%linux@frodo.hserus.net>

sathish subramanian <sathish.subramanian@gmail.com> wrote:

> how much of an effort is to move from kernel 2.6.5 (default in fedora
> core 2) to 2.6.6 ? will the current\ application get affected?

If you move from one fedora kernel to another nothing should break.

If you use a vanilla kernel you download off kernel.org all bets are off -
fedora kernels are heavily patched and customized.

Lots of stuff will still work but random failures here and there are a likely
result if you run an app that expected a kernel patch to be there when it isnt
- or when you had supermount enabled in the fedora kernel so that any CD you
insert shows up on your gnome desktop, but not when you compile your vanilla
kernel ..

	srs

On Saturday 22 Jan 2005 6:27 pm, Archana.S.R wrote:
> > > > | > > sir,
> > > > | > > which linux teaches me better ?
> > > > | > > 1.fedora core 3
> > > > | > > 2.mandrake
> > > > | > > 3.slackwire
> > > > | > > 4.debian
> > > > |
> > > > | Any of the off-the-shelf distros are good.
>
> i think fedora core / mandrake will be better to learn the commands &
> know about various linux issues before getting much into the internals

Actually, I think you can't separate learning the commands and learning the 
issues. Especially Mandrake, Xandros and others - they move you away from the 
actual OS, to the extent that you don't know it exists.

I started with an old redhat, moved to slackware and freebsd.

Briefly flirted with redhat again. Moved right back to slackware desktop and
freebsd server [for personal use that is - all our work boxes are RH]

The only time I ever tried debian was when someone convinced me to try
installing slink.  Took one horrified look at the nonintutive install (dselect
among other things) and went straight back to happy un-debianned life.

Toufeeq Hussain wrote:
> srs, If I patch the vanilla kernel with the latest -ac
> patchset will I get teh fedora kernel ?
> 
> just wondering cause I always see Alan's posts on LKML
> beginning with "RPMS are being prepared for..."

Alan Cox works for Redhat but so do several other kernel and gcc hackers

So what you see on fedora and rhel is not just stock RH - there's lots 
and lots of other patches (poke around the contents of a kernel src.rpm 
sometime)

See http://www.linuxsecurity.com/content/view/106183/102/ for changelogs

	srs

From kumar.appaiah at gmail.com  Sun Jan 23 19:37:02 2005
From: kumar.appaiah at gmail.com (Kumar Appaiah)
Date: Sun Jan 23 19:37:15 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] [GVL] bash and sh difference?
Message-ID: <a0c4f62705012306073613d955@mail.gmail.com>

Hello!

In the Shell scripting class held last Saturday, I asked whether sh
isn't just a symbolic link to bash on Linux systems, and that wasn't
agreed upon.

But I am now on an FC3 system, and here's the info:

$ cd /bin
$ ls -l sh
lrwxrwxrwx  1 root root 4 Jan  2 17:01 sh -> bash

The same is true for Debian. Is it so on *all* GNU/Linux systems?

Thanks.
Kumar
From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Sun Jan 23 19:50:14 2005
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Sun Jan 23 19:47:34 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] [GVL] bash and sh difference?
In-Reply-To: <a0c4f62705012306073613d955@mail.gmail.com>
References: <a0c4f62705012306073613d955@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <41F3B29E.60105@frodo.hserus.net>

Kumar Appaiah wrote:
> $ cd /bin
> $ ls -l sh
> lrwxrwxrwx  1 root root 4 Jan  2 17:01 sh -> bash
> 
> The same is true for Debian. Is it so on *all* GNU/Linux systems?

The same on slackware current too

For the simple reason that I dont think Bourne Shell is available under 
GPL.  It'd be under a bsd style license I guess - which is why it is 
available as a shell on freebsd (bash is something you'd have to install 
as a separate package - its not part of the base system on freebsd)
From trshash84 at gmail.com  Sun Jan 23 19:44:26 2005
From: trshash84 at gmail.com (T.R.Shashwath)
Date: Sun Jan 23 19:48:41 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] [GVL] bash and sh difference?
In-Reply-To: <a0c4f62705012306073613d955@mail.gmail.com>
References: <a0c4f62705012306073613d955@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <200501231944.27019.trshash84@gmail.com>

On Sunday 23 Jan 2005 2:07 pm, Kumar Appaiah wrote:
> Hello!
>
> In the Shell scripting class held last Saturday, I asked whether sh
> isn't just a symbolic link to bash on Linux systems, and that wasn't
> agreed upon.
>
> But I am now on an FC3 system, and here's the info:
>
> $ cd /bin
> $ ls -l sh
> lrwxrwxrwx  1 root root 4 Jan  2 17:01 sh -> bash
>
> The same is true for Debian. Is it so on *all* GNU/Linux systems?
>

Absolutely. At least, on all that I've seen...

It's a symlink just so that the admin can change it to whatever he wants. Some 
people prefer to have csh or ksh as default, for example. Bash is the 
standard, though. At least, de facto standard...

-- 
Shash

To know a thing well, know its limits. 
Only when pushed beyond its tolerances will true nature be seen.
--The Amtal Rule - Dune

From lug at chandrashekar.info  Sun Jan 23 21:21:20 2005
From: lug at chandrashekar.info (Chandrashekar Babu)
Date: Sun Jan 23 21:20:40 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] which linux brand teaches me linux better?
In-Reply-To: <41f3881d.S6DTBl8RMbSsJUFp%linux@frodo.hserus.net>
References: <b5e204a805012202366a7bbc87@mail.gmail.com>
	<8816fcf805012205073b322e06@mail.gmail.com>
	<20050123160239.6e869f63.lug@chandrashekar.info>
	<41f3881d.S6DTBl8RMbSsJUFp%linux@frodo.hserus.net>
Message-ID: <20050123212120.1d63e0d6.lug@chandrashekar.info>

> I started with an old redhat, moved to slackware and freebsd.
> 

I started with Slackware (coincidentally the same time when PCQuest
released it back in '96). After about 2 years of Minix+Linux+FreeBSD on
my home computer, I tried Redhat 5.2, Mandrake Linux, Debian (potato)
and found them all much different, yet interesting to play with.

With all the latter distributions, I begin tweaking their system
configuration files by hand to optimize boot time, reduce number of
processes running, and removing unncessary cruft (mostly left by the
various "standards committee") to make my system lean, fast and more
responsive - and I end up having them look/feel/behave like a Slackware
box.

In my office, I preferred using RH 6.1 and Debian potato on servers
(pre-2001). They are best installed once, and left running - perhaps
with security updates/kernel upgrades once in a while.

I was a bit impressed with Gentoo lately, but then two reasons had me
give up on Gentoo at home - net connectivity speed, and my CPU speed
(compiling Gnome 2.6 and KDE 3.2 took close to 3 weeks of continous
operation on my machine). Gentoo is simply not recommended for the
impatient (it might take several hours/days before you get gentoo
installed with all your favourite productivity tools). 

I moved back to Slackware 8.0 in 2002, and was impressed once again with
its consistency. Nothing really changed since the Slackware 2.0 days.
The installation screens, configuration files, package structure - all
remained the same. Even today, while I use Slackware 10, I feel most
comfortable for one of its greatest strengths - its simplicity.

-- 
Chandrashekar Babu
http://www.chandrashekar.info/

-r-xr-xr-x  2 root  wheel  650856 Apr  3  2003 /bin/tcsh

linux@frodo 22:51:48 [~]$ uname -mnrs
FreeBSD frodo.hserus.net 4.10-STABLE i386

Hi all

Firstly, thanks AE dept for running this listserv. Though I wish it was CS
that took initiative. I am CS alumnus. :-)

I am trying to buy a reliance cell phone for my parents that I could use
to connect to internet. Can someone suggest what is a good reliance cell
phone for Linux? I was thinking of buying LG RD 5130.  But I am not sure
that it supports Linux. The Linux driver etc on the webpage has
directories only for the following phones:

GTRAN_GCP_4020  LG_LST_250  LG_RD_2230        SAMSUNG_SCH_A603
KYOCERA_7135    LG_RD_2030  LG_RD_7130        SAMSUNG_SCH_A663
LG_LSP_-340E    LG_RD_2130  SAMSUNG_SCH_A563  SAMSUNG_SCH_N191

So I am wondering if Reliance cell phone internet works only on above
phones. Can someone suggest me a good cell phone with speaker phone that
works in Linux for Internet.


baud rate:

Also, the reliance baud rate in the scripts is 115200 in all the models.

http://www.relianceinfo.com/Infocomm/pdf/rconnect-cmdline-1.0.tar

[20:12:28]opus::~/p/rim $ grep pppd --no-filename rconnect1.0/|grep port|
grep -v 115200
pppd $PORT connect '/usr/sbin/chat -v -t 15 "" at+crm=1 OK'
[20:12:49]opus::~/p/rim $


Now, reliance advertises that the phone can support upto 144Kbps. (I
suppose this is bits and not bytes per second). Can someone tell me why
the two numbers (144Kbps and 115200)  can differ?  Also, is there a way I
can get faster Internet on a diff phone on Reliance? I would be willing to
pay money to get good internet in my small town.


What are the options to get on Internet for a small town guy?

Sudhakar.

PS:
<propaganda>
I really think that the govt should allow any company to use BSNL's
last mile infratructure. After all, BSNL is owned by the govt and is built
out of tax payers' money. It is unreasonable to expect someone to lay new
wires in small towns/rural areas. Me town boy will have to wait long for
internet. So no competetion in rural areas/small towns to BSNL. Which
means that we (small town people) will have to live with the lousy BSNL
for ages. My father is the boss of the BSNL phone exchange at my small
town. And I am still having trouble to get onto internet reliably.  What
about others?

India has a lot to learn from South Korea.  On another note, broadband
definition in India is 256Kbps.  In London, firms get sued because they
are advertising 512Kbps as broadband.  We have a long way to go! Atleast,
we are running. Nice to see that.
</propaganda>

Dear sathish,
I just downloaded the kernel RPM from fedora update
site and just installed it.
I didnt customise nor compiled the kernel by myself.
And also I use gedit[editor],Kalarm,OOffice,.. till
gammu/gnokki[mobile PL USB cable driver].
Never did I experience any error.
One thing I have noticed is that if you shutdown
without disonnecting the net connection, it will throw
some kernel errors/outputs...
But, its not a problem... You can't make the eciadsl
modem driver work with the kernel that comes with
fedora core 2[ CD].

If any doubts please get clarified...

On Sun, 23 Jan 2005 21:23:56 +0530, Sridhar Ratna
<sridharinfinity@gmail.com> wrote:
> Why not share your distro/experience thoughts in Ilugc Wiki?  In
> future posts, we can direct the OP there.

> --
> Sridhar Ratna - http://srid.bsdnerds.org
> _______________________________________________
> To unsubscribe, email ilugc-request@ae.iitm.ac.in with
> "unsubscribe <password> <address>"
> in the subject or body of the message.
> http://www.ae.iitm.ac.in/mailman/listinfo/ilugc
> 

Hi!
  
        I would like to share my experience of trying out distros
before I finally settled for  to 10gb FC1 and 30gb Debian ( Unstable )
( original, official debian i.e or however  you call it )

1.  FC1 - My first linux try out . Burnt the cd's myself and installed
with my friend who also was on the same lines as me. (both  know
nothing about linux at that time )
2. Knoppix - My very good friend Kumar Appaiah ( to whom I owe all my
knowledge of OSS and Linux, also a member of this group ). I made the
radical step of removing Windows totally from my system. It was
radical as said by my friends at that time.
3. Mandrake 10 - Really felt as if my hands had been tied up. Used it
only about six -seven times  and it was on my computer for 3 months
4. Mepis  ( Again Debian based ) - Really meant only for newbies. I
was really angry at this distro. I couldn't use lokkit to configure my
iptable. All my settings were being controlled from somewhere else and
I didn't know where. This is just one of the many pains that it caused
me.

             After all this I feel that a newbie should go for Fedora
Core distributions. It gives him the ease of a gui and also allows him
to get used to the linux way of doing things. People afresh from
W!n$&#s definitely cannot accept the debian installer. People would
feel the same way as if they are entering the BIOS setup ( which most
people (running  W!n$&#s) would be afraid to enter ). O.K Knoppix has
a much better installer . The Fedora installer ( Anaconda ) is a much
better when it comes to the ease of installing. Most people falter
only at the partitioning step and then it's a breeze even for a
newbie. I have also seen that most newbies are  always interested at
first in making their desktop look good rather than learn the
technicalities of linux and it's powerful features. ( I have been so
and I have installed it for a few of my friends who too have followed
similar lines ) It is unfair to expect a newbie not to be so. So


             Fedora Core --  My choice for newbies .


Bye!
 
-- 

Ganesh V
Undergraduate student,
Aerospace Engineering,
IIT Madras, Chennai-36.

It is nothing short of a miracle that modern methods of instruction
have not yet entirely strangled the holy curiousity of inquiry.
-- Einstein

Air Conditioners and Computers are similar in some ways. Both are
useless when you open 'Windows'.


I blog at http://www.livejournal.com/~ganesh_iitm/

From suraj at symonds.net  Sun Jan 23 20:49:36 2005
From: suraj at symonds.net (Suraj)
Date: Mon Jan 24 10:19:45 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Reliance + cell phone + modem + linux
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0501232249370.2649@willy>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0501232249370.2649@willy>
Message-ID: <20050124044936.GA19680@symonds.net>

sudhakar+ilugc@CS.Princeton.EDU wrote: 
,----
| I am trying to  buy a reliance cell phone for my  parents that I could
| use  to  connect to  internet.  Can someone  suggest  what  is a  good
| reliance cell  phone for Linux? I  was thinking of buying  LG RD 5130.
| But I am not sure that it  supports Linux. The Linux driver etc on the
| webpage has directories only for the following phones:
`----

...

,----
| pppd $PORT connect '/usr/sbin/chat -v -t 15 "" at+crm=1 OK'
`----

As you  see above, "at+crm=1"  is the magic  word for LG  phones. Just
find  out  if  the  model  that  you are  looking  at  can  work  with
at+crm=1.  Also  note   that, for some weird reason,  these phones end
up dialing #777  or whatever no matter what is  the number you specify
in your dialing software. So  that means you cannot use another dialup
ISP. I use  an indicom connection (which I will  soon ditch) in favour
of the BSNL broadband.

,----
| wires in small  towns/rural areas. Me town boy will  have to wait long
| for  internet.  So  no  competetion  in  rural  areas/small  towns  to
| BSNL. Which means  that we (small town people) will  have to live with
| the  lousy BSNL for  ages. My  father is  the boss  of the  BSNL phone
| exchange at my  small town. And I am still having  trouble to get onto
| internet reliably.  What about others?
`----

The same goes  with even "city-boys" like me who  dont exactly stay at
the heart of the city. Most ISPs just say "sorry sir, your area is not
yet 'wired' by us".

cheers,

  -Suraj

From prabu333 at hotpop.com  Mon Jan 24 12:03:41 2005
From: prabu333 at hotpop.com (Senthil Prabu.S)
Date: Mon Jan 24 12:04:16 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Repost|To build a product using only static dependency
	libraries
Message-ID: <04ab01c501de$a6d54790$1f0110ac@sesco>

Hello List,
        I am wondering whether is it possible to build a product using only the 
static version of
it's dependency library by default. Normally when we compile any product, the 
compiler looks
for the shared version of it's dependency library. And when the shared version 
is not present,
it take the static version of the dependency product ( I use to fix this, by 
editing the configure
scipt sometime manually).

       My question is, Will it possible to tell the compiler to take only static 
dependency library by
default through some "flag values", when both static and shared version of the 
dependency libaries
are present. Is any better way out there.

      Also, I knew that using shared  dependent library will occupy less memory. 
But is there any
other valid reason to go with shared libraries. Can anyone in this list give me 
a detailed answer
on this issue.


--
Senthil Prabu.S

If you are smart enough to know that you're not smart enough to be an
Engineer, then you're in Business.
_________________________________________________________________




From midhun at unm.edu  Mon Jan 24 01:16:29 2005
From: midhun at unm.edu (Midhun Kumar Allu)
Date: Mon Jan 24 13:47:09 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Repost|To build a product using only static dependency
	libraries
In-Reply-To: <04ab01c501de$a6d54790$1f0110ac@sesco>
References: <04ab01c501de$a6d54790$1f0110ac@sesco>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501240109490.13593@egor.unm.edu>

On Mon, 24 Jan 2005, Senthil Prabu.S wrote:

> Hello List,
>       I am wondering whether is it possible to build a product using only 
> the static version of
> it's dependency library by default. Normally when we compile any product, the 
> compiler looks
> for the shared version of it's dependency library. And when the shared 
> version is not present,
> it take the static version of the dependency product ( I use to fix this, by 
> editing the configure
> scipt sometime manually).
>
>      My question is, Will it possible to tell the compiler to take only 
> static dependency library by
> default through some "flag values", when both static and shared version of 
> the dependency libaries
> are present. Is any better way out there.

If you would like to override the present libraries with the ones you have 
written, place the path in /etc/ld.so.preload and that should take a 
precedence over others which are in /etc/ld.so.conf

For more details look at : 
http://www.faqs.org/docs/Linux-HOWTO/Program-Library-HOWTO.html


>     Also, I knew that using shared  dependent library will occupy less 
> memory. But is there any
> other valid reason to go with shared libraries. Can anyone in this list give 
> me a detailed answer
> on this issue.

You should try a shared library when the program is likely to be used by 
more than one user on the same machine. That way it will be more efficient 
for the reasons known to you. More acceptance of your program. I guess 
that is a good incentive enough.

Midhun.

______________________________________________________________________________

Midhun Kumar Allu
Masters Computer Engineering
URL : http://midhun.allubrothers.com
_______________________________________________________________________________

From sudhakar+linuxindia at CS.Princeton.EDU  Sun Jan 23 22:48:49 2005
From: sudhakar+linuxindia at CS.Princeton.EDU (sudhakar+linuxindia@CS.Princeton.EDU)
Date: Mon Jan 24 15:34:07 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Reliance + cell phone + modem + linux
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0501232236510.2649@willy>



Hi all

Firstly, thanks AE dept for running this listserv. Though I wish it was CS
that took initiative. I am CS alumnus. :-)

I am trying to buy a reliance cell phone for my parents that I could use
to connect to internet. Can someone suggest what is a good reliance cell
phone for Linux? I was thinking of buying LG RD 5130.  But I am not sure
that it supports Linux. The Linux driver etc on the webpage has
directories only for the following phones:

GTRAN_GCP_4020  LG_LST_250  LG_RD_2230        SAMSUNG_SCH_A603
KYOCERA_7135    LG_RD_2030  LG_RD_7130        SAMSUNG_SCH_A663
LG_LSP_-340E    LG_RD_2130  SAMSUNG_SCH_A563  SAMSUNG_SCH_N191

So I am wondering if Reliance cell phone internet works only on above
phones. Can someone suggest me a good cell phone with speaker phone that
works in Linux for Internet.


baud rate:

Also, the reliance baud rate in the scripts is 115200 in all the models.

http://www.relianceinfo.com/Infocomm/pdf/rconnect-cmdline-1.0.tar

[20:12:28]opus::~/p/rim $ grep pppd --no-filename rconnect1.0/|grep port|
grep -v 115200
pppd $PORT connect '/usr/sbin/chat -v -t 15 "" at+crm=1 OK'
[20:12:49]opus::~/p/rim $


Now, reliance advertises that the phone can support upto 144Kbps. (I
suppose this is bits and not bytes per second). Can someone tell me why
the two numbers (144Kbps and 115200)  can differ?  Also, is there a way I
can get faster Internet on a diff phone on Reliance? I would be willing to
pay money to get good internet in my small town.


What are the options to get on Internet for a small town guy?

Sudhakar.

PS:
<propaganda>
I really think that the govt should allow any company to use BSNL's
last mile infratructure. After all, BSNL is owned by the govt and is built
out of tax payers' money. It is unreasonable to expect someone to lay new
wires in small towns/rural areas. Me town boy will have to wait long for
internet. So no competetion in rural areas/small towns to BSNL. Which
means that we (small town people) will have to live with the lousy BSNL
for ages. My father is the boss of the BSNL phone exchange at my small
town. And I am still having trouble to get onto internet reliably.  What
about others?

India has a lot to learn from South Korea.  On another note, broadband
definition in India is 256Kbps.  In London, firms get sued because they
are advertising 512Kbps as broadband.  We have a long way to go! Atleast,
we are running. Nice to see that.
</propaganda>

From Toufeeq_Hussain at infosys.com  Mon Jan 24 16:27:00 2005

Subject: [Ilugc] help

Hi,

You could try the time command in UNIX.
Read `man time`

Also /proc/cpuinfo for general CPU related information.

This is Not supposed to be here but here goes :)
In windows, ctrl + alt + Del (Win NT) will give you the task manager,
Select the proceses tab and you will get the CPU time and usage for each

Process.

HTH.

Regards,
Toufeeq Hussain

From antonypaul24 at gmail.com  Mon Jan 24 17:17:14 2005
From: antonypaul24 at gmail.com (Antony Paul)
Date: Mon Jan 24 17:17:20 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] which linux brand teaches me linux better?
In-Reply-To: <dc538c3f05012321182a076d1b@mail.gmail.com>
References: <b5e204a805012202366a7bbc87@mail.gmail.com>
	<dc538c3f05012321182a076d1b@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <2989532e0501240347204d26b6@mail.gmail.com>

One's choice always depend on what he want to learn and availability of CD. 

If he is looking at using GUI based desktop applications he should go
for FC3 or Mandrake 10.1 or Ubuntu. If trying to master command line
and server applications go for a server class installation of any
distro. If want to become a developer(C/C++/TCL/Python) use any distro
which offer these tools.

Only after learning the basics one can go for linuxfromscratch and such things. 

   If he have any book in hand to learn Linux use the distro which is
used in that book.

   I studied linux at a training centre. It was no matter to me which
distro it is. They were using RHL 7.0. My goal of learning linux was
to know something that others dont know. But soon I fall in love with
linux. Then I bought PC and I was in a position to try out different
distros. First I installed Caldera Linux which I got along with
PCQuest. Then tried various RHL versions, Knoppix Live CD and Ubuntu.

    Now I have two objective in learning and using Linux. 
1) It should help my career.
2) For my personal joy of learning linux.

    For the first objective I learn to use RedHat flavor (RHL and
mandrake). For the second I try out various Linux distros(and
different versions) of Linux distros.
    

rgds
Antony Paul

Hi,
       For Linux, in addition to /proc/cpuinfo (which has predominantly 
hardware informations) we can use
     /proc/stat to get individual and overall processor(s)  
system/idle/user/nice time.
    
    
Joe.

From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Mon Jan 24 18:06:58 2005
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi S)
Date: Mon Jan 24 18:03:28 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] One Day One Command
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501241751330.1364-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

One Day One Command :-
-------------------

comm - Compare 2 Sorted files line by line

Summary : 

Compare two sorted files F1 and F2 line by line.

Examples :

$ comm F1 F2 -- Output contain 3 col. 
                Col 1 - Uniq to F1, Col 2 - Uniq to F2 
                and Col 3 - Comman to F1 & F2

$ comm -1 F1 F2 -- Suppress lines unique to F1

$ comm -2 F1 F2 -- Suppress lines unique to F2

$ comm -3 F1 F2 -- Suppress comman lines to F1 & F2

$ comm -13 F1 F2 -- Show lines from F2, which is not in F1

$ comm -23 F1 F2 -- Show lines from F1, which is not in F2

Read : man comm

Bye :)
-- 
Bharathi S

From andyetitmoves at gmail.com  Mon Jan 24 18:28:59 2005
From: andyetitmoves at gmail.com (Ramkumar R)
Date: Mon Jan 24 18:29:06 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Repost|To build a product using only static dependency
	libraries
In-Reply-To: <04ab01c501de$a6d54790$1f0110ac@sesco>
References: <04ab01c501de$a6d54790$1f0110ac@sesco>
Message-ID: <9a9bfc1705012404581ca25354@mail.gmail.com>

>       Also, I knew that using shared  dependent library will occupy less memory.
> But is there any
> other valid reason to go with shared libraries. Can anyone in this list give me
> a detailed answer
> on this issue.

Importantly, it allows you to improve on the library (provided there
is binary compatibility) independent of the clients (the programs).

it moves on...

> 
> --
> Senthil Prabu.S

> Engineer, then you're in Business.

On Mon, 24 Jan 2005 17:17:14 +0530, Antony Paul <antonypaul24@gmail.com> wrote:
> One's choice always depend on what he want to learn and availability of CD.
> 
> If he is looking at using GUI based desktop applications he should go
> for FC3 or Mandrake 10.1 or Ubuntu. If trying to master command line
> and server applications go for a server class installation of any
> distro. If want to become a developer(C/C++/TCL/Python) use any distro
> which offer these tools.
> 
> Only after learning the basics one can go for linuxfromscratch and such things.
> 
>    If he have any book in hand to learn Linux use the distro which is
> used in that book.
> 
>    I studied linux at a training centre. It was no matter to me which
> distro it is. They were using RHL 7.0. My goal of learning linux was
> to know something that others dont know. But soon I fall in love with
> linux. Then I bought PC and I was in a position to try out different
> distros. First I installed Caldera Linux which I got along with
> PCQuest. Then tried various RHL versions, Knoppix Live CD and Ubuntu.
> 
>     Now I have two objective in learning and using Linux.
> 1) It should help my career.
> 2) For my personal joy of learning linux.
> 
>     For the first objective I learn to use RedHat flavor (RHL and
> mandrake). For the second I try out various Linux distros(and
> different versions) of Linux distros.
> 
> rgds
> Antony Paul

From kums at gmx.net  Mon Jan 24 23:34:32 2005
From: kums at gmx.net (Kumaraguru)
Date: Mon Jan 24 23:34:57 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] [GLV] January 22, 2005 Shell scripting session I
References: <1bf09ec1bf17f3.1bf17f31bf09ec@vsnl.net>
	<8816fcf805012406002a9386a6@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <002001c5023f$2852fe10$0d07a8c0@kums>

Hi Sridhar,

I agree allowing non-image uploads will lead to abuse
but .bz2 or .gz should be exemptions.

For MediaWiki, you need to edit the includes/DefaultSettings.php
and add bz2, gz to $wgFileExtensions so that it becomes
something like..

$wgFileExtensions = array( 'png', 'gif', 'jpg', 'bz2', 'gz' );


Regards
Kumaraguru

> On Mon, 24 Jan 2005 13:55:47 +0500, rhariram@vsnl.net
<rhariram@vsnl.net> wrote:

From fred at bytesforall.org  Tue Jan 25 00:37:44 2005
From: fred at bytesforall.org (Frederick Noronha (FN))
Date: Tue Jan 25 01:40:41 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Linux-India.org is slowly coming back to its feet -- Raju
	Mathur
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0501250037390.1502@news.goa.bytesforall.org>

---------- Forwarded message ----------

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

[Cross-posted]

Hey, in case you hadn't noticed, the linux-india.org site is slowly coming
back to its feet.  Where're some statistics, followed by requests and
finally some dos and don'ts:

STATISTICS
==========

Users:  We have 68 registered users now.  I don't know who you are, but
thank you for registering and trying things out.

LUGs: We have 6 LUGs/GUGs/FSUGs/GLUGs registered.  More entries welcome. The 
LUG list is at:

   http://linux-india.org/index.pl?iid=2198

TODOS
=====

1. Please learn how to use the portal.  MetaDot is an extremely powerful
online portal, and you can do incredible things with it without once having
to (a) leave your browser or (b) have administrative rights on the site. You 
can add all sorts of interesting stuff (RSS feeds, formatted HTML, JS,
FAQs, News items, forms, polls, etc.) to your own site, and you can have
multiple pages within your site.

1. If you're a LUG, please send me your entry.

If you don't already have a web site you can create an account and your
complete web site within your account on linux-india.org itself.

If you already have a site, please do create an account and at least a
single page in your account that summarises your LUG.  Send me the account
information and I'll link your page to the main LUG page.

2. If you're a user, please create an account and populate your site. If you
feel your site is of general interest, please send me your user ID and I'll
be happy to link to your site from the Users' Pages section.  Let's get some
content on!

3. If you're a well-wisher with 1/2 hour per day to spare, please handle one
or more of these sections:

   News
   Press Releases
   Job Postings
   Job Requests
   Events

You will become the contact point for that section and you will have full
administrative rights within your section.  More than one person can share
the load of handling one section -- it's group-based.

I'm currently handling the security section.  However I'd be glad to hand
that over to someone else if anyone wants it.  Another alternative would be
to hand it over to one of the Linux Security News RSS feeds.

4. Keep the feedback flowing in.  Suggestions on how to improve the site,
useful new sections, etc. are welcome.

DOS AND DON'TS
==============

Please DO look at the site, figure out how to use the system and add
content.

Please DO NOT add content that is not Linux- or FLOSS-related.  Of course,
you can add whatever interests you in your personal page (e.g. I have
received a request for a Tsunami Relief page), but try to stay at least
loosely on topic :)

Please DO NOT DO NOT DO NOT DO NOT DO NOT add any content that violates the
laws of India or any other country.  CD images or activation keys of Winduhs
XP Home Edition are completely ruled out, as is pornographic material, links
to not-free-to-copy materials on the 'net, etc.

Please DO NOT send me feedback about how the site design sucks, how the
colour scheme looks ghastly, etc.  If you are willing to add content, please
go ahead and do it.  If you are only coming up with alternative suggestions
on portal systems to use, forget it -- I have done the best within the
constraints that are available to me and I'm not really interested in
looking at or evaluating 1000s of other portal systems.  Each person has her
own favourite and I really can't keep up with the gazillions of portal
systems that are released each month.

Regards,

- -- Raju
- -- Raj Mathur                raju@kandalaya.org      http://kandalaya.org/
        GPG: 78D4 FC67 367F 40E2 0DD5  0FEF C968 D0EF CC68 D17F
                       It is the mind that moves
-----BEGIN PGP SIGNATURE-----
Version: GnuPG v1.2.4 (GNU/Linux)
Comment: Processed by Mailcrypt 3.5.8 <http://mailcrypt.sourceforge.net/>

iD8DBQFB9KGzyWjQ78xo0X8RAm/oAKCLlNzU9YJ/7sEMvXjbytF2y5qquwCfcPqr
lb9pfNBNAQ9LxMBdxJmFEQg=
=CuHN
-----END PGP SIGNATURE-----
_______________________________________________
linux-india-help mailing list
linux-india-help@lists.sourceforge.net
https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/linux-india-help

> Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 13:51:23 +0100

> Subject: [MDK] translations into Tamil language (ta)

> Kaixo!
 
> The next realease of Mandrakelinux distribution, 10.2, is entering
> its final developement phase (you can see the schedule on the wiki
> page 

> http://qa.mandrakesoft.com/twiki/bin/view/Main/Mandrakelinux102 ); 

> however, the level of translations for Tamil language has stagnated
> or regressed compared to previous releases (you can see the current
> translation level on the status page
> http://www1.mandrakelinux.com/l10n/ta.php3 ).
 
> Are you still interested in the translation of Mandrakelinux tools?
> If not, it would be very helpfull if you could pass the word to
> others that may be interested into translating for Tamil language;
> people interested can contact me (pablo@mandrakesoft.com) for
> details.

> Those who contributed to the translation of a given release are
> awarded with a Mandrakeclub accoutn with VIP level, which gives to
> the full PowerPack version of the distribution.
 
> Thank you very much
> Pablo Saratxaga
> Responsable of i18n/l10n for Mandrakelinux

From kums at gmx.net  Tue Jan 25 09:28:43 2005
