From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Tue Jan 25 12:48:30 2005
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi S)
Date: Tue Jan 25 12:44:46 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] One Day One Command
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501251222040.10780-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

One Day One Command :-
-------------------

touch - Change File Timestamps

Summary : 

Update the access and modification times of each 
FILE to the current time.

Examples :

$ touch myfile -- change the time stamp to current time.
                  If myfile is not there then touch will 
                  create it.

$ touch -c myfile -- Same as above. But If myfile is not
                     there, then it won't create it.

$ touch -r f1 f2 -- Set f1's time to f2 instead of current time

$ touch -a myfile -- Change only access time.

$ touch -m myfile -- change only the modification time

$ touch -t 200412251122.33 -- set this time instead of current time

$ ls -lu myfile -- Shows the last access time

Read : man touch

Bye :)
-- 
Bharathi S


From rsubr at pcomm.hfi.unimelb.edu.au  Thu Jan 27 19:42:18 2005
From: rsubr at pcomm.hfi.unimelb.edu.au (Raja Subramanian)
Date: Tue Jan 25 12:49:46 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] [GVL] bash and sh difference?
In-Reply-To: <200501231944.27019.trshash84@gmail.com>
References: <a0c4f62705012306073613d955@mail.gmail.com>
	<200501231944.27019.trshash84@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20050127141218.GA1831@arkenstone.pvt.u1.newgenimaging.com>

Hi,

T.R.Shashwath wrote:
> On Sunday 23 Jan 2005 2:07 pm, Kumar Appaiah wrote:
> > In the Shell scripting class held last Saturday, I asked whether sh
> > isn't just a symbolic link to bash on Linux systems, and that wasn't
> > agreed upon.

> > The same is true for Debian. Is it so on *all* GNU/Linux systems?

sh is a part of the POSIX standard.  Bash is backwards compatible with sh and
provides POSIX compliant sh like syntax/behaviour.  And since it's the default
on several linux distros, it naturally plays a dual role as sh.

> Absolutely. At least, on all that I've seen...

If you install the "dash" package on debian sarge, your sh will be
symlinked to dash instead.

> It's a symlink just so that the admin can change it to whatever he wants. Some
> people prefer to have csh or ksh as default, for example. Bash is the
> standard, though. At least, de facto standard...

People who link sh to csh, ksh, etc. are all asking for trouble.

See this thread -
    http://lists.debian.org/debian-devel/1998/08/msg00258.html

- Raja

From g.bharath at gmail.com  Tue Jan 25 19:19:17 2005
From: g.bharath at gmail.com (Bharath.G)
Date: Tue Jan 25 19:19:25 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: Reliance + cell phone + modem + linux
In-Reply-To: <20050124063002.2456E1DB265@www.ae.iitm.ac.in>
References: <20050124063002.2456E1DB265@www.ae.iitm.ac.in>
Message-ID: <4937d2e8050125054912ff3eb4@mail.gmail.com>

Hi,

    The reliance phone is connected to the PC via a serial cable and
via a USB cable. I have worked on interfacing the reliance phone with
a Linux Point of Sale terminal, once you have a modem device detected
on linux the reliance script is just used to point the ppp to the
device detected(a symb link) . In short you just use his scripts for
connecting via PPP, the drivers for usb are usbserial,ftdi_sio(depends
on your serial-usb converter , mostly the ones available in ritchie's
/ reliance dealers are ftdi). Most of the kernels have the ftdi driver
in their source or alternatively you could download the source from
the ftdi site.You would not need a driver for the serial cable.

The at+crm= is used to specify between FWT and Handsets as far as i
know, they are all there in the scripts.You could just figure out what
he is doing by just looking at his script.It has been quite some time
since i worked on it.

I had some problems in an embedded kernel where the reliance server
autheticated me with a Local RAP (Reliance Application Platform) IP
(when i used his scripts).I had to goto DAKC (Reliance HQ) and found
out the CHAP/PAP was not autheticating me.If anyone gets into such a
problem use  -f option and specify your password filename in pppd.It
should work.

The 114kbps he promises is just another Sales slicker.Your serial port
would support 115200 , but dont even think of going beyond 10 kpbs
(even that if you are damn lucky) .

You could also look here for more details, 

http://www.hackgnu.org/ril-howto.html

this is where i started off from a year back.

Cheers,

Bharath.G


"The best accelerator available for a Windows PC is one that causes it
to go at 9.81 m/s2."

> become dead.Mine is a  usb mouse .what is the module
> to be 
> 
> included.

Check if hotplug is installed ,dpkg -l hotplug .
If not do a apt-get install hotplug, as root.

Regards,
Toufeeq Hussain

From rajsekar at cse.iitm.ernet.in  Tue Jan 25 20:12:16 2005
From: rajsekar at cse.iitm.ernet.in (Rajsekar)
Date: Tue Jan 25 20:12:54 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Media WIKI + PHP upload limit
Message-ID: <m3fz0plgdz.fsf@rajsekar.pc>


I run a Wiki page on my comp (just for fun).
I tried uploading an ogg file (around 4MB).  It said that the file is
empty.  I assumed that this has to with mediawiki and hacked around
include/SpecialUpload.php

I found that it wasn't really mediawiki that was causing trouble.  The size
that it gets from php itself seems to be zero. I checked this by making it
output (as reply) the size it gets.

Now I found that some php variables like upload_max_size, post_max_size,
memory_limit need to be adjusted to take big uploads.  I changed my
conf.d/php.conf (included by httpd.conf) and still am not able to upload
big files.

Can someone help me on this issue?

I have pasted my php.conf

This is my php.conf 
---------------------------------------8<---------------------------------

LoadModule php5_module        lib/apache/libphp5.so

#
# Cause the PHP interpreter handle files with a .php extension.
#
<Files *.php>
    SetOutputFilter PHP
    SetInputFilter PHP
    LimitRequestBody 9524288
</Files>

AddType application/x-httpd-php .php 
AddType application/x-httpd-php-source .phps 

#
# Add index.php to the list of files that will be served as directory
# indexes.
#
DirectoryIndex index.php

php_value upload_max_size 102400000
php_value post_max_size  102400000
php_value memory_limit   102400000
-------------------------------------------8<------------------------------



-- 
    Rajsekar Manokaran
    IIT Madras

From rajsekar at cse.iitm.ernet.in  Tue Jan 25 20:21:27 2005
From: rajsekar at cse.iitm.ernet.in (Rajsekar)
Date: Tue Jan 25 20:22:44 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Media WIKI + PHP upload limit
In-Reply-To: <m3fz0plgdz.fsf@rajsekar.pc> (rajsekar@cse.iitm.ernet.in's
	message of "Tue, 25 Jan 2005 20:12:16 +0530")
References: <m3fz0plgdz.fsf@rajsekar.pc>
Message-ID: <m3brbdlfyo.fsf@rajsekar.pc>


Rajsekar <rajsekar@cse.iitm.ernet.in> writes:
>
> Now I found that some php variables like upload_max_size, post_max_size,
> memory_limit need to be adjusted to take big uploads.  I changed my
> conf.d/php.conf (included by httpd.conf) and still am not able to upload
> big files.
>

that should have been upload_max_filesize you dumbo (scolding myself).
Now it works like a charm.

sorry to have disturbed you guys.

    Rajsekar Manokaran

From topa_007 at yahoo.com  Tue Jan 25 11:02:21 2005
From: topa_007 at yahoo.com (Toufeeq Hussain)
Date: Wed Jan 26 00:32:42 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] post installation tips of linux
In-Reply-To: <b5e204a805012510542f11ebdc@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20050125190221.7196.qmail@web30204.mail.mud.yahoo.com>

Hi Gopal,

--- Srinivasan Gopal <srinivasan.iitm@gmail.com>
wrote:

> hi everyone!
> thanx i was able to install fedora core 3 without
> any so called
> "confusion" .........now that i have installed can
> you all suggest how
> should i start learning from terminal.........also
> can i access
> "windows" files ??........learning from "man" is a
> big herculean
> task...any other better or user friendly methods??

Visit tldp.org, it's the Linux Documentation Project.
It has HOWTO's for almost any linux related query.

The best way would be to select a topic of your
interest and pick up a HOWTO from the list.

The best thing to start off would be BASH, the Linux
shell (command line).

Also of interest is www.google.com/linux , here you
can search for linux related problems etc.

Have fun with GNU/Linux,

> cheers to all,
> srini
> _______________________________________________

Cheers,
Toufeeq Hussain

=====

# mail me @ toufeeq at computer dot org    #

mode in HDD].

From deepak.sarda at gmail.com  Wed Jan 26 17:42:56 2005
From: deepak.sarda at gmail.com (Deepak Sarda)
Date: Wed Jan 26 15:13:04 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] post installation tips of linux
In-Reply-To: <b5e204a805012510542f11ebdc@mail.gmail.com>
References: <b5e204a805012510542f11ebdc@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <eaac783a05012601421c3416aa@mail.gmail.com>

On Wed, 26 Jan 2005 00:24:14 +0530, Srinivasan Gopal
<srinivasan.iitm@gmail.com> wrote:
> hi everyone!
> thanx i was able to install fedora core 3 without any so called
> "confusion" .........now that i have installed can you all suggest how
> should i start learning from terminal.........also can i access
> "windows" files ??........learning from "man" is a big herculean
> task...any other better or user friendly methods??

Going to tldp.org and just reading random howtos is ineffective imho.
Instead, try to learn new things as you use Linux on a day-to-day
basis. Like you said, how to access windows partitions. Look up tldp,
search google for this particular topic. You'll find answers to your
questions and also learn some other interesting things along the way.

Tomorrow, you'll want to play mp3 files. More task based learning :-)

deepak

--

http://eminor.antrix.net/

From kums at gmx.net  Wed Jan 26 21:05:26 2005
From: kums at gmx.net (Kumaraguru)
Date: Wed Jan 26 21:05:48 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] [OT] problems with microsoft
References: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0501260837030.10983@chi.spunge.org>
Message-ID: <002901c503bc$a83137e0$0d07a8c0@kums>

Hi,

If you google

"site:ae.iitm.ac.in  microsoft" (without the quotes)

you can get all the messages containing microsoft
in the ILUGC archives.

If you want to include messages forwarded to other
mailing lists and the replies to them.

"intitle:[ilugc] microsoft"

But this covers only pages indexed by Google.
If you need a live Search(to include even the messages
posted a few minutes before) you can use

http://search.gmane.org/search.php?group=gmane.org.user-groups.linux.ilugc

But it doesn't seem to include last year's messages
in its search and gmane is very slow. If your browser is
Firefox, you can make it a little easier. See..
http://www.aero.iitm.ernet.in/pipermail/ilugc/2004-November/014144.html


Regards
Kumaraguru

> Is there any way to find whether any topic had already been
> discussed in the list from the mail archives.?

> regs,

From ramanraj at iqara.net  Wed Jan 26 22:58:25 2005
From: ramanraj at iqara.net (Ramanraj)
Date: Wed Jan 26 23:02:38 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] FSF-TN Mailing List
Message-ID: <1106780305.41f820916ba9d@sumail01.iqara.net>

Richard  Stallman, founder  and leader  of  the GNU  Project and  Free
Software Foundation,  will be inaugurating  the Tamil Nadu  Chapter of
Free  Software  Foundation  of  India,  at the  Vellore  Institute  of
Technology, on Sunday, the 6th  February, 2005, at 9:30 AM and deliver
the  keynote  address.  All  are   welcome  to  the  event,  and  more
information   about   the   inaugural   function   is   available   at
http://www.swatantra.info

One of the prime objectives of  FSF-TN is to take free software closer
to people in all the  districts in Tamil Nadu, by organising meetings,
events,  demos, and  user groups  wherever possible.   An  open public
mailing list to  discuss and promote the adoption  of free software in
TN, has been started at:
http://gnu.org.in/cgi-bin/mailman/listinfo/fsf-tn

Please volunteer to join fsf-tn and lend your support.

-Ramanraj K

to see it on a FSF site.

Rajsekar <rajsekar@cse.iitm.ernet.in> writes:

> A nice article (more of a report).

The best part was: 

Only 32 kilobytes of RAM in the Apollo capsules' computers was enough to
put men on the moon. The Voyager deep space probes have on-board computers
based on a 4-bit CPU. An 80C85 CPU with 176 kilobytes of PROM and 576
kilobytes of RAM controlled the Sojourner rover that drove across the
surface of Mars and sent us a wealth of scientific data and high-resolution
images in full-color stereo. But when I have a 233MHz Pentium II with 128
Megabytes of RAM and 30 Gigabytes of disk space, and I try to type a letter
to my grandmother using Windows XP and Office XP, the job will take me
forever because my computer is underpowered!!

-- 
    Rajsekar Manokaran
    IIT Madras

From fred at bytesforall.org  Thu Jan 27 05:20:13 2005
From: fred at bytesforall.org (Frederick Noronha (FN))
Date: Thu Jan 27 06:23:22 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] FLOSSNews: Bangalore, Pune, Jodhpur, Ahmedabad, Mumbai,
	Kerala...
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0501270520030.2010@news.goa.bytesforall.org>

======================================================================
News from Linux-India * http://www.linux-india.org
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
[Website being relaunched, by Raju Mathur of Delhi. Contributions in terms of 
content and tech support are welcome!]
======================================================================

Linux India: The India Linux Organisation Portal

NGOs, searching long for alternatives, find flavour in alt.software
Frederick Noronha reports -- Asia Source, being held in Bangalore from Jan
28 to Feb 4, 2005 hopes to bring together over a hundred people from 20
countries to increase the use and awareness of FLOSS among the non-profit
sector in South and East Asia.

GNUnify ... at Pune, Feb 13 to 15, 2005 Vidyadutt S <vidyadutt at gmail.com>
has announced the GNUnify festival of Symbiosis at Pune, a regular event
that takes place at this time of the year -- and has continued over the past
two years -- at the central Indian city of Pune.

GNU/Linux... in the life sciences Tarun Kant <tarunkant at linuxmail.org>
from the SunnyLUG from Jodhpur for this useful piece of information. He
says: "For people who are into life science research/bioinformatics, there
are a few good linux distros available." This includes the VigyaanCD, the
live Linux CD containing "all the required software to boot the computer
with ready-to-use modeling software". Says Kant: "And let me tell you this
(Vigyaan) is an effort by an Indian. Kudos to you Pratul K Agarwal for such
a nice package."

>From software... to culture Crimson Feet coordinator Prayas Abhinav is
working on a "showcase" of audiovisual -- film, animation etc -- work
produced by alternate methods, and plans an exhibition on February 5 and 6,
2005 at Ahmedabad.

Open Source in Education, Mumbai meet on Feb 11, 2005 Sameer D Saharabudde
<sameerds at it.iitb.ac.in> has sent in an early intimation of a program
scheduled for February 11, 2005 on "Open Source in Education". Says Sameer:
"Some 50 people involved in the education system, like university department
heads, college heads, etc will be invited." Further details awaited. Sameer
is a research scholar, KReSIT, IIT Bombay.

Microsoft at the KSEB (Kerala) Satheesh S Pillai <satheeshpillai2000 at
yahoo.co.in> recently drew attention of the Free Software User Group-Kochi
to the report made by Centre for Computer Aided Power Sector Studies
(C-CAPSS) in Kerala about the billing software developed by "a famous
consultancy along with M$ as part of the e-Governance project". This report
makes interesting reading, and has immense implications for many government
computerisation plans.  You can find the full report at
http://www.kseboa.org/KSEB%20LT%20billing%20computerisation.pdf

LaTeX for Malayalam 0.9 released TUG-India -- http://www.tug.org.in -- has
announced that an update 0.9 for 'LaTeX for Malayalam' has been released at
sarovar. This update enables the use of Type1 Malayalam fonts available with
CDAC ISM Publisher, according to Alex. Download the package from:
http://malayalam.sarovar.org/ .

IITIANS Develop Linux-Based Cell Phone Tracking Software CXOToday.com writer
Julia Fernandes has reported on how "three young Mumbai-based IITians, who
have developed a Linux-based software application that tracks the location
of mobile phones."

Nithin Kamath's LinTux Newsletter A made-in-Mangalore product. Interesting
compiliation of news and updates from the world of FLOSS across India and
the globe. Check it out at Now in the 14th issue. Keep it up Nithin. 
http://groups-beta.google.com/group/lintux

THE HINDU: A whiz-kid's tryst with Linux What do people do when they hear
that doing a particular thing is very difficult? Most of them try to avoid
it. But some people meet the challenge headlong. Sarath Lakshman a Standard
X student of the Jawaharlal Nehru Government Higher Secondary School, Mahe,
belongs to the second category. This article is from the national newspaper
THE HINDU, reproduced here with gratitude to this publication for
highlighting an issue which is important to understanding what makes sense
to the young techies-in-the-making of South Asia.

Low-cost CD outlet http://www.linuxbazar.com is run by Srinivasan
<LinuxIndia at hotmail.com>. Says he: "I sell CDs at Rs 50 per CD. Spreading
the word on my website is difficult .. still I have managed to ship Fedora
to remote corners in India incl. Jammu."

L10N How-To and Toolkit On Jan 19, 2005 Sunil Abraham <sunil at apdip.net>
announced that the IOSN-CDAC L10N How-To and Toolkit is ready for a "final
round of comments and feedback." The main page contents listing of the CD is
available at http://anakin.ncst.ernet.in/~aparna/consolidated/CD. It has
links to the guide, as well as the list of tools we will include in the CD.
You can see the current version at:
http://anakin.ncst.ernet.in/~aparna/consolidated in the HTML format.
Feedback welcome!

Font developer's guide Sayamindu Dasgupta <sayamindu at clai.net> is
offering what he terms a "preliminary version of a font developer's guide".
Check out what this determined young man has to offer at
http://sayamindu.randomink.org/conv_guide/

Listing Indian LUGs, GLUGs, FSUGs and more... a list of links to various
user groups in the Free/Libre and Open Source Software (FLOSS) world. Please
visit it at http://wikiwikiweb.de/LugsList/

Punjabi translation of Debian Installer comes closer to realisation
Christian Perrier <bubulle at debian.org> said January 19, 2005 that the
Debian Installer team has been contacted by Amanpreet Alam, who offers to
start working on Debian Installer (and further Debian translations) in
Punjabi. Says he: "The work on Hindi started about two to three months ago
after a discussion here where Ravi Shrivastava offered to initiate it."

ET's software stories Indian business daily, 'The Economic Times', has this
link for software-related stories. Unfortunately just a few related to
Free/Libre and Open Source Software in India ... a field where so much is
happening!

C-DAC launches Janabhaaratii FLOSS localisation project C-DAC, the Indian
government-run Centre for the Development of Advanced Computing, has
announced in October 2004 the launch of the launch of its "janabhaaratii"
project for localisation of FLOSS. It suggested the goal would be
"development, deployment and community building, and the work would be put
out under the GPL/LGPL licenses.

Govt open to open source software ... or just hedging bets?  India's
business newspaper reported in end-December 2004 that the Government of
India "continues to evaluate options for using open source software, a move
which would proliferate the usage of IT by bringing down its costs". IT
secretary Brijesh Kumar was quoted as telling the Federation of Indian
Chambers of Commerce and Industry, an industry lobby group, that the
"government continues to consider options available in open source
software". There was a suggestion that "India should force proprietory
software makers to share source code by threatening to shift to open source
software", the ET reported, citing the case of China.

News from Linux-India * http://www.linux-india.org
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
[Website being relaunched, by Raju Mathur of Delhi. 
Contributions in terms of content and tech support are welcome!]
======================================================================

Linux India: The India Linux Organisation Portal

NGOs, searching long for alternatives, find flavour in alt.software
Frederick Noronha reports -- Asia Source, being held in Bangalore from Jan
28 to Feb 4, 2005 hopes to bring together over a hundred people from 20
countries to increase the use and awareness of FLOSS among the non-profit
sector in South and East Asia.

GNUnify ... at Pune, Feb 13 to 15, 2005 Vidyadutt S <vidyadutt at gmail.com>
has announced the GNUnify festival of Symbiosis at Pune, a regular event
that takes place at this time of the year -- and has continued over the past
two years -- at the central Indian city of Pune.

GNU/Linux... in the life sciences Tarun Kant <tarunkant at linuxmail.org>
from the SunnyLUG from Jodhpur for this useful piece of information. He
says: "For people who are into life science research/bioinformatics, there
are a few good linux distros available." This includes the VigyaanCD, the
live Linux CD containing "all the required software to boot the computer
with ready-to-use modeling software". Says Kant: "And let me tell you this
(Vigyaan) is an effort by an Indian. Kudos to you Pratul K Agarwal for such
a nice package."

>From software... to culture Crimson Feet coordinator Prayas Abhinav is
working on a "showcase" of audiovisual -- film, animation etc -- work
produced by alternate methods, and plans an exhibition on February 5 and 6,
2005 at Ahmedabad.

Open Source in Education, Mumbai meet on Feb 11, 2005 Sameer D Saharabudde
<sameerds at it.iitb.ac.in> has sent in an early intimation of a program
scheduled for February 11, 2005 on "Open Source in Education". Says Sameer:
"Some 50 people involved in the education system, like university department
heads, college heads, etc will be invited." Further details awaited. Sameer
is a research scholar, KReSIT, IIT Bombay.

Microsoft at the KSEB (Kerala) Satheesh S Pillai <satheeshpillai2000 at
yahoo.co.in> recently drew attention of the Free Software User Group-Kochi
to the report made by Centre for Computer Aided Power Sector Studies
(C-CAPSS) in Kerala about the billing software developed by "a famous
consultancy along with M$ as part of the e-Governance project". This report
makes interesting reading, and has immense implications for many government
computerisation plans.  You can find the full report at
http://www.kseboa.org/KSEB%20LT%20billing%20computerisation.pdf

LaTeX for Malayalam 0.9 released TUG-India -- http://www.tug.org.in -- has
announced that an update 0.9 for 'LaTeX for Malayalam' has been released at
sarovar. This update enables the use of Type1 Malayalam fonts available with
CDAC ISM Publisher, according to Alex. Download the package from:
http://malayalam.sarovar.org/ .

IITIANS Develop Linux-Based Cell Phone Tracking Software CXOToday.com writer
Julia Fernandes has reported on how "three young Mumbai-based IITians, who
have developed a Linux-based software application that tracks the location
of mobile phones."

Nithin Kamath's LinTux Newsletter A made-in-Mangalore product. Interesting
compiliation of news and updates from the world of FLOSS across India and
the globe. Check it out at Now in the 14th issue. Keep it up Nithin. 
http://groups-beta.google.com/group/lintux

THE HINDU: A whiz-kid's tryst with Linux What do people do when they hear
that doing a particular thing is very difficult? Most of them try to avoid
it. But some people meet the challenge headlong. Sarath Lakshman a Standard
X student of the Jawaharlal Nehru Government Higher Secondary School, Mahe,
belongs to the second category. This article is from the national newspaper
THE HINDU, reproduced here with gratitude to this publication for
highlighting an issue which is important to understanding what makes sense
to the young techies-in-the-making of South Asia.

Low-cost CD outlet http://www.linuxbazar.com is run by Srinivasan
<LinuxIndia at hotmail.com>. Says he: "I sell CDs at Rs 50 per CD. Spreading
the word on my website is difficult .. still I have managed to ship Fedora
to remote corners in India incl. Jammu."

L10N How-To and Toolkit On Jan 19, 2005 Sunil Abraham <sunil at apdip.net>
announced that the IOSN-CDAC L10N How-To and Toolkit is ready for a "final
round of comments and feedback." The main page contents listing of the CD is
available at http://anakin.ncst.ernet.in/~aparna/consolidated/CD. It has
links to the guide, as well as the list of tools we will include in the CD.
You can see the current version at:
http://anakin.ncst.ernet.in/~aparna/consolidated in the HTML format.
Feedback welcome!

Font developer's guide Sayamindu Dasgupta <sayamindu at clai.net> is
offering what he terms a "preliminary version of a font developer's guide".
Check out what this determined young man has to offer at
http://sayamindu.randomink.org/conv_guide/

Listing Indian LUGs, GLUGs, FSUGs and more... a list of links to various
user groups in the Free/Libre and Open Source Software (FLOSS) world. Please
visit it at http://wikiwikiweb.de/LugsList/

Punjabi translation of Debian Installer comes closer to realisation
Christian Perrier <bubulle at debian.org> said January 19, 2005 that the
Debian Installer team has been contacted by Amanpreet Alam, who offers to
start working on Debian Installer (and further Debian translations) in
Punjabi. Says he: "The work on Hindi started about two to three months ago
after a discussion here where Ravi Shrivastava offered to initiate it."

ET's software stories Indian business daily, 'The Economic Times', has this
link for software-related stories. Unfortunately just a few related to
Free/Libre and Open Source Software in India ... a field where so much is
happening!

C-DAC launches Janabhaaratii FLOSS localisation project C-DAC, the Indian
government-run Centre for the Development of Advanced Computing, has
announced in October 2004 the launch of the launch of its "janabhaaratii"
project for localisation of FLOSS. It suggested the goal would be
"development, deployment and community building, and the work would be put
out under the GPL/LGPL licenses.

Govt open to open source software ... or just hedging bets?  India's
business newspaper reported in end-December 2004 that the Government of
India "continues to evaluate options for using open source software, a move
which would proliferate the usage of IT by bringing down its costs". IT
secretary Brijesh Kumar was quoted as telling the Federation of Indian
Chambers of Commerce and Industry, an industry lobby group, that the
"government continues to consider options available in open source
software". There was a suggestion that "India should force proprietory
software makers to share source code by threatening to shift to open source
software", the ET reported, citing the case of China.

wow !
well....my heartburn for quite some time...I just can't use Anjuta for
all its features, cause it's no match for the editing capabilities of
emacs....how I wish emacs had a bonobo wrapper...(I know you are
rotfl...but I have a right to dream :))

ede is actually quite good...(if you haven't heard about this... check
out http://cedet.sourceforge.net ... cedet includes ede - cedet is the
most ambitious emacs based project I have seen so far...in fact, w3 is
no match)...but expecting glade like functionality is a bit too
much...

it moves on...

From andyetitmoves at gmail.com  Thu Jan 27 09:45:54 2005
From: andyetitmoves at gmail.com (Ramkumar R)
Date: Thu Jan 27 09:46:00 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Which distro is suitable for PIII 700MHz and 128MB RAM
In-Reply-To: <20050126083401.5229.qmail@web50203.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20050126061706.84516.qmail@web30202.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
	<20050126083401.5229.qmail@web50203.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <9a9bfc170501262015487f95cb@mail.gmail.com>

please check your configuration well before changing the distribution
- most often the config is the problem rather than the distro - may be
you have unnecessary servers running....choice of applications also
matter - gnome/kde apps tend to be bloated - e.g. xterm is much better
and faster than gnome-terminal sans the backgrounds - maybe aterm if
you really insist on the backgrounds...changing distros may not really
help...

it moves on...

Hi,

Wiki model is meant to be open to everyone. I believe that if some
unwanted editing happens oldstate could be restored easily. I am not
very sure about the method for resoration but this is bulit into Wiki.
Its possible to block specific IP from accessing wiki if we have
issues.

Regards,
Muthu

> > > Its possible to block specific IP from accessing wiki if we have
> > > issues.
> >
> > Is it right ???

Its possible to do this. 
http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?WhyNobodyDeletesWiki
http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?WhyWikiWorks

These two links answers most of the questions.

> if we block the ip address, then what happen if one uses dialup
> connection for whom dynamic ip is assigned???

If someone using dialup is making harmful changes then what kind
of life will that person be having ?? most problem will come from a
broadband user which still uses dynamic IP only but if there are
issues offending people can be easily traced back.

If the problem araises then we can think about restricting access.
until then we can try it as free for all.

but the issue we will really face is Flame wars on distros and applications !! 

Regards,
Muthu

> If the problem araises then we can think about restricting access.

> but the issue we will really face is Flame wars on distros and applications !!

In general,

* The society is not bad enough (assumption 1).
* There are enough good people to revert back. (assumption 2).

I think, all we need is many sysops.  We can decide (in this thread itself
IMHO) who all would be sysops.  sysops have more previls. 

In the worst case (if assumption 1 fails), we can restrict editing to only
registered users (free registration implies that no freedom is removed) and
deleting an account can be done much faster than creating an account.
-- 
    Rajsekar Manokaran
    IIT Madras

Heh.  You, of all people, need no help to install Debian, man.  The
only tip I can give you is - avoid dselect like the plague.  You can
install debian without getting anywhere near it.

I like Debian not because of dselect, but inspite of it.  I have made
two major upgrades first from potato -> woody and then from woody ->
Testing (distributed by PC Quest).  Not a hitch ( Well, discounting a
hard disk crash in the interim) ...  Now, what was that recommeded
upgrade path from FC1 again ? :-)

From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Thu Jan 27 18:23:09 2005
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi S)
Date: Thu Jan 27 18:19:33 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] One Day One Command
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501271809460.30322-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

One Day One Command :-
-------------------

nl - Number lines of files

Summary : 

Write each FILE to stdout, with line numbers added.
With No FILE or -, read stdin

Examples :

nl myfile -- Writes all non-empty lines with number.

nl -ba myfile -- Number all lines.

nl -ba -l2 myfile -- Count 2 empty line as 1 and display

nl -nln myfile -- Numbers are left justified.

nl -nrz myfile -- Numbers are right justified and leading zeros

nl -w2 myfile -- Uses 2 column for the line number.

nl -s"> " myfile -- Insert "> " in between number and line.

ls | nl -- ls Output with line numbers

Read : man nl

Bye :)
-- 
Bharathi S

On Thu, 27 Jan 2005 20:47:12 +0530, mohana sundaram <ksmoha@gmail.com> wrote:
> It should be possible to block porn things from getting posted ONLY if
> it is routed through the moderator. ie the moderator evaluates the
> content and then see if it is apt to be put it in.. Is it the case
> with wiki s??
> 
> 
No. Such thing is not possible with wiki. The contest gets posted
first and then only the SysOp can decide whether to delete the picture
or not.
But ordinary users can edit the content and delete the tag containing
the image. Also the user can message the SysOp about the illegal
content and ask it to be removed.
This is the best thing to do.

Ages ago (maybe in 2000), when I was a quasi-active participant of
ILUGC, I tried getting ILUGC to either shift or come down once in a
while to my office (HCL Technologies Ltd) on Nelson Manickam Road
(Aminijikarai) so that it'd be easier for people from that end of the
world to commute easily, amidst several other reasons. However that
didn't work for a variety of reasons then.

At that point of time, I left an open ended note saying that if ever
ILUGC wanted such a service/facility ever in the future, our doors could
probably be pried open once more. _Now_, if there is an interest/need in
such a location once again, I can try and talk to the relevant
authorities to see if it can be made possible once again.

What do you folks think ?

Sridhar Ratna <sridharinfinity@gmail.com> writes:
> Emacs is NOT a better IDE. Read 
> http://www.emacswiki.org/cgi-bin/emacs/EmacsIDEWishList (a wiki page
> started by me)

I'm just wondering. Supposing, you were stuck with a plain old
text console.., how will you develop using Anjuta/Glade/`any other
gui based ide`. ?? Emacs was not originally build for
GUI. However, they added that because GUI became popular. But the
main motive was to retain the basic functionality when running in
both console and on the X.

Anjuta is a good IDE alright., but comparing it with Emacs is not
proving a point. Emacs has tonnes of features which are not even
imaginable with Anjuta/Glade/*. The main thing that Emacs users
love (atleast me) is that, it provides integration with all your
day to day work. Emacs is _not_ an IDE. It can be used as an
IDE. And it does do a pretty good job at it too. 

You got to use Emacs to really get the feel of it.

.O. A proud GNU user

From sridharinfinity at gmail.com  Fri Jan 28 08:35:01 2005
From: sridharinfinity at gmail.com (Sridhar Ratna)
Date: Fri Jan 28 08:35:08 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Fwd: Announcing Ubuntu LoCo Teams
In-Reply-To: <20050127033721.GA32113@kiste>
References: <20050121140227.GA6206@kiste> <20050127015207.GZ1843@nozomi>
	<20050127033721.GA32113@kiste>
Message-ID: <8816fcf8050127190524b711ad@mail.gmail.com>

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Matthias Urlichs <smurf@smurf.noris.de>
Date: Thu, 27 Jan 2005 04:37:21 +0100
Subject: Announcing Ubuntu LoCo Teams
To: ubuntu-announce@lists.ubuntu.com


Greetings,

Many people ask for ways that they can give back to the Ubuntu project
or participate in the community. One great way to do this is through
promote Ubuntu in your local community!

To help with this, we are pleased to announce the creation of Local
Community Teams (LoCo Teams) to promote the use, adoption, and
localization of Ubuntu.

Ubuntu's philosophy states that:

 Every computer user should be able to use their software in the
 language of their choice.

This means that we need advocacy, promotion, documentation, support,
and (of course) translations of Ubuntu, in individual languages.
It also means a geographically distributed user community for
coordinated promotion. LoCo Teams can help tackle all of these problems.

If you are interested in getting involved in a LoCo Team (or starting
your own), we can go ahead and learn more at:

  http://www.ubuntulinux.org/LoCoTeams

We have set up a common set of domain names in the form of
ubuntu-CC.org [*]. Most of those domains are just placeholder domains,
waiting for someone to come along and take control. That could be you!

In other cases, there are already folks working on Ubuntu in a
location, country, area, or language. We will happily point
ubuntu-CC.org to those web sites and your mailing lists.

Please don't hesitate to ask me if you have any questions or would
like to get involved!

Regards,
Matthias

[*] CC stands for "country code" -- the last two letters on
    country-specific URLs. If necessary, we can also create other
    domains for communities which don't easily associate with a country
    or language.


--
ubuntu-announce mailing list
ubuntu-announce@lists.ubuntu.com
http://lists.ubuntu.com/mailman/listinfo/ubuntu-announce





-- 
Sridhar Ratna - http://srid.bsdnerds.org

I *didn't* wish to start a flame war, but sridhar is forcing me in :)
exactly joe...anjuta is hardly comparable to emacs...and it all
depends on what you exactly mean by an IDE...the most versatile
programmer friendly editing features, a far superior highlighting
system, and cedet to extend all this, apart from innumerable other
features...emacs is THE best IDE (if IDE means an environment
conducive for coding - cmon, writing glade apps isn't the only thing a
programmer does...)....

all said, I guess your wiki has most of my wishes over there...now,
how to bring that to the notice of the emacs developers ???

it moves on...

PS: Hmm...if I was loud above, it's just my passion for what I call
the editing environment (it is just not an editor)...

On Fri, 28 Jan 2005 08:53:25 +0530, Ramkumar R <andyetitmoves@gmail.com> wrote:

> features...emacs is THE best IDE (if IDE means an environment
> conducive for coding - cmon, writing glade apps isn't the only thing a
> programmer does...)....

If emacs can do everything (gnus, erc,..) why cannot it do glade?

>
> all said, I guess your wiki has most of my wishes over there...now,
> how to bring that to the notice of the emacs developers ???
>

I never bothered after starting that wiki page. May be some one should
post it in the emacs-devel list.  And btw, emacs cvs has gtk2 support
which is still not well architectured.  Gtk2 is only used for the
menus, scrollbars, .. The buffer is still the same old emacs buffer
(no anti-aliased fonts).  Extensions like tabbar.el (for eg.) could
make use of GtkNotebook if emacs was made extensible with the toolkit
(rather than just the menus).  No more buffer hacking then.

-- 
Sridhar Ratna - http://srid.bsdnerds.org

Sridhar Ratna <sridharinfinity@gmail.com> writes:
> pretty well (in well architectured manner, instead buffer
> hacks), as I said in my earlier mail.

Hmm.. I dont exactly understand what you mean by buffer
hacks. Thats how Emacs works. There are no hacks in it. They chose
to keep everything as buffers so that it is easy to extend
it. Even the cutomize widgets are basically text inside the
buffer. Just to make them look pretty on X, they've some widgets
here and there.. But still, the point is to keep it simple.

Sridhar Ratna <sridharinfinity@gmail.com> writes:
> If emacs can do everything (gnus, erc,..) why cannot it do glade?

Ok., I'm going to be biased again. I've never used Glade. I do
program a bit of GTK+, but again only in Emacs. Usually one of my
friends does the packing of widgets. He uses Glade for that. But
once the code gen is done, he copies the code into the project and
uses good ol` Emacs to continue with it. 

I find Emacs more comfortable than using glade. I'm used to
writing my own autotools based build system., so I find the build
system given by Glade as cumbersome..

From: suraj at symonds.net (Suraj)

Subject: [Ilugc] anjuta2 IDE .. integrating glade .. releasing this Feb
In-Reply-To: <871xc6njnn.fsf@deck8.enterprise>

Joe Steeve wrote: 
,----
| Ok., I'm going to be biased again. I've never used Glade. I do program
| a bit of GTK+, but again only in Emacs. Usually one of my friends does
| the packing of widgets. He uses  Glade for that. But once the code gen
| is done, he  copies the code into the project and  uses good ol` Emacs
| to continue with it.
`----

The  code-generation   is  just  one   aspect  of  GLADE.    The  most
advantageous thing with glade is  the GladeXML library where you don't
have to bother  with how to place the widgets and  where _in_ the Code
but instead use Glade to "build" the UI, generate the XML and ask your
Gtk app to use the XML file. You can even assign actions to call backs
and things like that with the GladeXML.

cheers,

  -Suraj

-- 
,-----------------[http://www.symonds.net/~suraj/]---o
| Muttuswamy Dikshitar not only brought rains with amritavarshini, but also
| brought a halt to the torrentous pour with the same composition by just
| replacing the last three words to become `sthambahaya sthambhaya sthambhaya
| !!`
`------------------------------[suraj@symonds.net]---o
From joe_steeve at gmx.net  Fri Jan 28 13:20:37 2005
From: joe_steeve at gmx.net (Joe Steeve)

Subject: [Ilugc] anjuta2 IDE .. integrating glade .. releasing this Feb

Kumar Appaiah <akumar@iitm.ac.in> writes:
> On Fri, Jan 28, 2005 at 11:49:58AM +0530, Ayan Chakrabarti wrote:
>> Nice try, emacs - with its evil indentation styles - is a
>> blasphemous piece of work. Vim rules !!

> Well, you can customize your indentation anyday on emacs. Please
> don't bebiased just forthe sake of it!

I've been programming in C for nearly 4 years now.. I find the
Emacs indendation a lot better than Vi indentation
(IMHO). Personally I like it because, I nest a lot of code into
`if` clauses or `for` loops and still they fit beautifully into
the 80 column console.

I have tried out the 8spaces indenting recommended in the Linux
kernel, and various other styles.. (even camelcase). But
personally I dont find the code that readable as in Emacs
indenting. However, this is purely a personal choice and a project
policy rather than a point of debate of efficiency. All that
matters is consistency throughout the project

-- 
.O. A proud GNU user
..O http://www.joesteeve.tk/
OOO http://joe.bsdnerds.org/

Joe Steeve wrote: 
,----
| Hmm., interesting I did not  come across this before. However, is this
| a part of libglade? And is libglade portable across to w32?
`----

Yep, its  part of  LibGlade. I dont  know about the  win32 portability
part. (sridhar  has sent  a link in  a different  sub-thread, probably
that explains it).

The good thing with libglade is  that you can 'theme' your app without
having to even make _any_ modifications in the Code.

From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Fri Jan 28 17:36:15 2005
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi S)
Date: Fri Jan 28 17:31:54 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] One Day One Command
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501281721170.22414-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

One Day One Command :-
-------------------

ulimit - Control the resources available to processes

Summary : 

ulimit, Bash Built-in Command, provides control over the 
resources (Virtual Mem, Max no .of process, Core file 
size, ...) available to processes started by the shell.

If Max no. of user process is set to 5, then the particular
user can't run more then 5 process.

Examples :

$ ulimit -a -- Show All current limits.

$ ulimit -c -- Show core file size.

$ ulimit -c 1000 -- Set new core file size.

$ ulimit -u 3 -- Set max no .of user processes

$ ulimit -n -- Show max open files.

Read : info bash

Bye :)
-- 
Bharathi S

From sudhakar+ilugc at CS.Princeton.EDU  Fri Jan 28 08:45:39 2005

Date: Fri Jan 28 19:15:56 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] DNS reverse lookups on Reliance and  BSNL
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0501280838470.11067@tux>


Hi all,


	How are Reliance and BSNL as far as reverse lookups are concerned?
Does they do a good job of their DNS server?  Do reverse lookup give a
good entry so that it is consistent with forward lookup entry?

	To me it it important because our dept servers accept incoming ssh
only if the reverse lookup is good.  I know that some people can run into
problems like this with bad revsese lookup:

	"I had problems with this many times, including issues like email
tagged as SPAM because reverse lookup turned blank, inability to edit
certain wiki sites as they check reverse lookup, etc.."


How is the tech support usually?


Comments?


--Sudhakar

On Fri, 28 Jan 2005 15:32:10 +0530, Ganesh <sganesh@hclp.com> wrote:
> Hi All,
> 
> Is there any way in Linux to determine Ethernet Port status like network disconnection. One can use ping, but I can't assure whether the failure is due to network disconnection.

If your NIC supports the MII standard (most modern NICs do), then you
can just run the "mii-tool" program to figure out the link status.

Some more details:-
HOWTO Reach the Central Lecture Theater (CLT):-
[Courtesy: Bharathi <sbharathi@MidasComm.Com>]
---------------------------------------------
Reaching CLT is very easy. Bcoz it is opposite to Open Air Theater (OAT).

1) Enter thru Main Gate.
2) Reach the Gajanthra Circle (GC) (~2KM)

3) Take the Hostel Road.

4) CLT is 100 meter away from the GC. On the road, you can see Central
  Library & OAT in Left side and Admin block on Right side

Thanks,
Ramanraj.

Subject: [Ilugc] System Restore feature

Hi,
--- Karthikeyan
<karthikeyan.balasubramanian@aspiresys.com> wrote:

> Hi Everybody,
> 
>   Does linux has "System Restore" feature like
> windows.  If yes
> anybody have tried it?.
> 

"If you break it, you get to keep both the pieces"

You might find some commercial applications that
provide this.However the safest "system restore" would
be to have separate partitions [/usr , /home , /boot
], so that if something goes wrong you'll not be left
completely stranded. In this way you can backup the
important partitions (/usr ..).

Regards,
Toufeeq Hussain

From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Sat Jan 29 16:01:20 2005
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi S)
Date: Sat Jan 29 15:56:35 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] One Day One Command
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501291536560.15464-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

One Day One Command :-
-------------------

sort - Sort lines of text files

Summary : 

Sort the file contents based on options given to it.
By default the output is showed in the console.

Examples :

$ sort  -- Take the input from stdin, sort and output 
           in stdout.

$ sort myfile -o myoutput -- Sort the myfile content 
                             and store in "myoutput"

$ sort -b myfile -- Ignore the leading blanks and sort.

$ sort -br myfile -- Same as above but in reverse order

$ sort -c myfile -- Only Check whether myfile is already 
                    sorted

$ sort -f myfile -- Ignore the case and sort (a == A)

$ sort -u myfile -- Sort and output only unique lines

$ sort -t : -k 2,2n -k 5.3,5.4 myfile 
     
     -- Sort numerically on the 2nd field and resolve 
        ties by sorting alphabetically on the 3rd and 
        4th characters of field 5. Use `:' as the 
        field delimiter

Read : man sort

Bye :)
-- 
Bharathi S

the wiki grows we may need more SysOps.

> All moderators please focus on the uploaded files/hack
> attacks, rather than trying to filter the content
> being put up.

user(if there are any objectionable content). But regarding the file
uploads, only the SysOps can delete the illegal uploads.
I see that the Bash_session1.tar.bz2.jpg file is still present on the
wiki. Someone(Sridhar ot Toufeeq) delete it ASAP as we still are not
SysOps.

From sudhir at openlx.com  Sun Jan 23 17:44:40 2005
From: sudhir at openlx.com (Sudhir Gandotra)
Date: Sun Jan 30 03:40:07 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] which linux brand teaches me linux better?
In-Reply-To: <b5e204a805012202366a7bbc87@mail.gmail.com>
References: <b5e204a805012202366a7bbc87@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <1106482479.2859.36.camel@laptop.censusindia.net>

On Sat, 2005-01-22 at 16:06, Srinivasan Gopal wrote:
> sir,
> which linux teaches me better ?
> 1.fedora core 3
> 2.mandrake
> 3.slackwire
> 4.debian 
> 
> plzz tell me as i'm new to this completely.....

As you have seen, you will get a variety of advise from different users,
all trying to make it easy for you.
One suggestion could be : Try the one you get your hands on first and
once you get a little used to it (unless you want to try many of them -
one after the other in the first 2 weeks), try another one to see the
variety.
Gradually, you will get sued to the one that you find most convenient
for you and that's the one good for you.
All of them will surely give you a lot of learning and enjoyment.
Get back to the list to clarify your doubts/issues while trying them and
friends will help you.

All the best.
--

Hi,

C Ravindran wrote:
> Is there any easily usable package in Linux (not a
> geek stuff) that can be used for making a live
> webcast?

Real Networks has a suite of applications for creating, streaming,
viewing live or recorded audio and video.  The journey starts at -
    https://www.helixcommunity.org

But be warned, content streaming by itself is complex technology.
There is no easy way out.

- Raja

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Sun Jan 30 09:47:35 2005

Subject: [Ilugc] [GLV] February 5,
	2005 Anand Babu "Introduction to Hacking GNU/Hurd"
Message-ID: <20050130174735.35565.qmail@web50208.mail.yahoo.com>

Greetings!

This is a confirmation and announcement of the
February 5, 2005 (Saturday) session (part of GNU/Linux
Vidyashram) by Anand Babu on "Introduction to Hacking
GNU/Hurd" at CSD#320, Electrical Sciences Block, IIT-M
at 1300 HRS IST.

You can view the poster from here:

http://www.geocities.com/cyborg4k/anandbabu.feb.5.2005.pdf

Please note that the session starts at 1300 HRS IST.
We have advanced the timing because Anand Babu, Joe,
Ramaraj will have to receive Richard Stallman and have
to travel to Vellore for February 6, 2005 Swatantra at
VIT.

A brief introduction about Anand Babu:

Anand Babu is a very active Free Software developer
and a full time GNU Volunteer. He is the
author/maintainer for various Free Software projects
like FreeIPMI
System, HDB/RPCI, Hymn, Freehoo, bios-config... He
leads the Free Software Division of California Digital
as Chief Software Architect and VP, and built world's
second fastest super-computer (code named Thunder). He
had given us a lecture earlier in June of 2004 about
Thunder and FreeIPMI.

http://www.californiadigital.com/thunder.shtml

With regards,

K Shakthi

the BIOS. It worked for me.

From igni_linux at yahoo.com  Sun Jan 30 21:04:28 2005
From: igni_linux at yahoo.com (ignacius nallu)
Date: Mon Jan 31 10:34:36 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: Re: Re: linux boot problem
In-Reply-To: <20050130075924.5486.qmail@webmail17.rediffmail.com>
Message-ID: <20050131050428.72017.qmail@web30205.mail.mud.yahoo.com>

Dear Boovarahan,
Is it true that you have deleted your partitions using
fdisk.Then how you are able to boot into linux.
My question is at present what is the structure of
your partitions...
Have you created the same partition structure as:

Initially I had XP in /dev/hda1.
 5 GB space was free in /dev/hda3
 /dev/hda4 was 500 MB swap.
 /dev/had/5 was mandrake 10.1
 /dev/hda6 was swap 500MB.
/dev/hda7 was home directory.
 /dev/hda8 wad usr directory.


Or else if you have deleted those /dev/hda5 and 
/dev/hda6 /dev/hda7 and /dev/hda8 you have to
reinstall mandrake again.Moreover ME is the most
crappy OS that MS has produced.I prefer XP[enable XP's
default firewall to get rid most viruses and attacks].

I have also played with OSes and partitions but I had
backedup -MBR,partition table and my important
datas...

My advice is that you partition you disk from scratch
and reinstall in the order XP,Mandrake...
And install MDK grub boot loader in  the dedicated
partition[/ or /boot based on your choice of
installation].
Later install XOSL...


--- Boovarahan Srinivasan Iyengar
<varaahan@rediffmail.com> wrote:

>

> 
> This space and swap were used for testing of various
> linux distros but were not included in the MBR.
> 
> /dev/had/5 was mandrake 10.1
> /dev/hda6 was swap 500MB.
> /dev/hda7 was home directory.
> /dev/hda8 wad usr directory.
> 
> This was the original configuration.

> antivirus S/W , I decided to install ME and so usinf
> fdisk I deleted the logical and extended DOS

> ME in C drive. Automatically the partition table got
> changed. To get MDK linux I used the install CD (
> first CD) and used the rescue option to reinstall
> the boot loader but could not succeed. Then I
> downloaded XOSL and installed  it. Even after

From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Mon Jan 31 14:36:44 2005
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi S)
Date: Mon Jan 31 14:31:22 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] One Day One Command
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501311415440.17597-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

One Day One Command :-
====================

tail - Output the last part of files.

Summary : 

Print  the  last  10  lines of each FILE to stdout.
With more than one FILE, precede each with a header 
giving the file name. 

Examples :

$ tail midas.txt -- Show only the last 10 Lines.

$ tail f1 f2 -- Show the last 10 lines of 2 files 
                with small header.

$ tail -vn 5 myfile -- Show only last 5 Lines with
                       header.

$ tail -c 12 myfile -- Show only last 12 Bytes.

$ tail -q myfile -- Don't show headers.

$ tail --retry myfile -- Keep retrying to open myfile.

$ tail -f maillog -- Output appended data as the file 
                     grows. Useful to monitor logs.

$ tail -f -s 10 maillog -- Once in every 10s update the 
                           output.

$ tail -f --pid=200 myfile -- Terminate tail after PID 
                              (200) dies.

Read : man tail

Bye :)
-- 
Bharathi S

Your BIOS battery is dying. Replace it.

I think Windows syncs with time.microsoft.com without telling you
(calling home?). Maybe you should put the command:

ntpdate -b clock.isc.org

in your crontab or something.

Subject: [Ilugc] USB - Webcam

ensure that you have the corresponding usb-* modules (in most cases,
the generic ones should do), hotplug should take care of the remaining
- if you have something like updfstab / fstab-sync, a new fstab entry
should appear seconds after you plug the device in...

Subject: [Ilugc] One Day One Command
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501311415440.17597-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

xtail in fact does the monitoring job better by providing for
monitoring multiple files...pipe it (or for that matter even tail -f)
through osd_cat (a sample program in the xosd distribution - a cool
library for displaying stuff like it appears in the osd
displays...like say, the volume display on your tv)...you will never
miss any important notification...provided you are running X...

it moves on...

From akumar at iitm.ac.in  Mon Jan 31 18:45:59 2005
From: akumar at iitm.ac.in (Kumar Appaiah)
Date: Mon Jan 31 18:46:10 2005
Subject: [Ilugc] Debian needed
In-Reply-To: <41fd660a.1334dfd1.7edc.1732@smtp.gmail.com>
References: <41fd660a.1334dfd1.7edc.1732@smtp.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20050131131559.GA9992@athreya.ee.iitm.ernet.in>

On Sun, Jan 30, 2005 at 11:56:09PM +0100, Paulo R. M. Serra wrote:
>             I have found your message in ilugc about installing debian on
> 915 motherboard.
> 
>             I have solved the problem of the SATA disks by choosing the
> "compound" driver mode on the bios setup, but it does not recognize the
> sound board. I am not a linux expert, have you been able to make it work
> (with sound) on the intel 915 ?

The sound works fine. There are just two steps.

1.Find the version of the kernel you are running (using uname
  -r). Then get the kernel headers corresponding to your kernel using
apt-get install
kernel-headers-x.xx.. (e.g. kernel-headers-2.6.8-386-2).

2.Get the ALSA drivers from http://www.alsa-project.org (1.0.8 or
  later). Extract the archive and do the customary ./configure;make;
  make install. Of course, make sure you specify the correct directory
  to configure to look for the kernel headers, e.g. ./configure
  --kernel-src-dir=... or the like. Also do the same for
  alsa-utils. Finally, run /usr/sbin/alsaconf to get you sound card
  on.

As for the graphics, I have not had any success, as XFree86 in Debian
doesn't have support for i915. However, the proper kernel and the DRI
drivers from http://dri.sf.net should do the trick. But I haven't done
it yet, as the package given there is for kernel source. But I'll try
it soon. Any pointers from others using similar hardware would be
helpful.

Thank you.

-- 
Kumar Appaiah

tamil linux <tamillinux@gmail.com> writes:
> Good comparision would be cost of cars in US and India. Price of
> Laptops and list goes on.. reason for this is Patents. You have
> to pay royality. Thats why Open source community is opposing
> software patents.

Wait., neither the Open Source Community nor the Free Software
community are opposing patents for the reason "paying
royalty".. though that is an annoyance. The reason they oppose
patents is because in the case of Software, patents are completely
irrelevant. Stating that "not paying royalty" as the motive
undermines the "irrelevance of Software patents" factor.
